reviewText:
I am the very model of a shadowrunning samurai;
I've razorclaws and dermal plates and target-sensing cybereyes.
I know the gangs of Redmond and I ride a wizzer motorbike,
I'm very well acquainted with a fixer known as Magic Mike.

I may not hack the Matrix but I know just how to swing a blade,
In such a way to guarantee my target simply won't evade.
I understand unwritten rules of mercenary ettiquette... (ettiquette...)
Like splitting loot or stealing kills or how Yakuza settle bets!

I'm very good at cleaving skulls or stabbing things without a fuss,
or taking trophies from awakened critters animalculous...
In short you'll find no better suited member for your team than I,
For I'm the very model of a shadowrunning samurai!



I'll take the toughest missions, always eager to test out my skill,
No matter the opponent, I can register another kill.
I've made my reputation as a warrior decked out in chrome,
I've worked for folks named Johnson breaking in to the Tacoma Dome.

I'm stronger than a wendigo, with muscles cultured in a vat,
My lungs can filter toxins and I've not an ounce of body fat,
I'm swifter than a cheetah thanks to wired reflexology, (reflexology, hmm...)
I'll get your decker in and out of Renraku Arcology!

Then I can get the nuyen we were promised for the datasteal,
I'd celebrate but essence loss has left me unable to feel.
Don't bother even trying 'cause I'm never taken by surprise,
I am the very model of a shadowrunning samurai!



They never see me coming when I work to infiltrate a place,
I move so fraggin' swiftly that you'd swear I thought it was a race.
But if you see a cyber psycho coming at you like he's nuts,
You'll never even realize I've already sliced out your guts.

That's not to say that I don't have affinity for gunnery,
I've got a smartlink Ingram that I use for long-range funnery,
In short it doesn't matter if I'm using swords or pistolry (pistolry... aha!)
You'll say my quarry never even stood a chance in history!

So take me on your run because I'm plucky and adventury,
More talented than anyone you'll hope to meet this century,
If anyone says different then they're tellin' you a god damn lie,
'Cause I'm the very model of a shadowrunning samurai!

>>>>>>>>>>>>[ WELCOME TO SHADOWLAND ]<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<

...sorta

UPDATE:  So far so good!

OK so i am very much a completionist--thus i am reading and talking to anyone and everyone in game so my progress might be a little slow.

So far though?  AMAZING!  If you love Shadowrun, then you have come to the right place.  As the games go (Shadowrun Returns or Dragonfall) This is the obvious evolution.  All the polish you saw in the directors cut of Dragonfall is here and it shines like a new set of chrome arms.

The story is engaging, each character--from your fellow runners to random people you chat with on teh streats has their own personality.  It really makes the world feel alive.

As gameplay elements go, the Matrix has been redesigned.  Even with modern hacking--the goal is to avoid/supress the defenses of the system you are hacking.  This element was completely absent in previous iterations of the Matrix (SRR and DF)
This new matrix is totally awsome--you could jsut run in there and fight through---but with a little skill you can avoid it altogether!  On top of that, there are new hacking mini-games that add some flavor to trying to get that paydata.  overall i am very impressed--kinda wish i rolled a decker now.

Anyways, the game continues--I just got 3 jobs and am about to head off

See you in the shadows, chummers!  more to come as i get through it...

UPDATE:  ok--been playing for many hours now and i can safely say that the game is great.  As stated before, the writing is top notch---and it really shines through in every character you meet.  I find myself wanting MORE from each character--they each have thier own backstory that really tugs your interest.

Also, the game time i have?  I haven't even made it through the first 3 side" missions you get.  And no i haven't just left the game open.  There have been a few re-loads (matrix runs are much more challenging when you get caught...) but a lot of the time is spent just reading--there is SO much lore in this game and each of your fellow runners seems to have a full range of dialogue to flesh it out.

So to sum up--if you like Shadowrun and/or old school RPG's (i guess the official term is cRPG?) then this is the game for you."

tl;dr Oh my GOD, they listened to the fans! â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ at how stupid the UI was in the first 2 with the lack of interparty trade and/or ability to control your team? Its fixed now!

I remember writing somewhere in the Shadowrun:HK forums before it came out how annoying and stripped the UI was of the older games. That you couldn't trade items within missions, and that you had no way to position your party tactically before battle, not so bad if you're a street sam - really â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ if your main guy is a squishy mage or decker.

I believe my exact words were something like ...do you see real-world SWAT or military have the tech specialist wander up and open the door with all the burly armored dudes with assault rifles randomly grouped around behind picking their noses?

The UI is still stripped. But now its got the ability to ambush, giving you a few rounds to place your team before the shooting starts. You can trade items inter-party too while on missions, and give found items to anyone with a free inventory space. Its way better. People had been complaining about how stupid the inability to trade and the inability to control your party out of combat was, so Harebrained fixed it. Good on them! Now to get them to put some kind of minimap, especially since the levels have gotten huge.

They cleaned up the models too, so dwarves and orks dont look so ridiculous. Overall, the models are much cleaner. The running animation kind of reminds me of The Venture Bros though...

Some sequels suck. This one does not. HS has learned from the first 2. Theres more of everything, including plenty of awesome char portraits for each race/gender, unlike the first one where female trolls had what...5? You can see that HS has found their stride, listened to their fans, and cleaned up some of the glaring flaws of the engine and game.

If you liked the first 2, even if you thought they were flawed - get this game. If youre a fan of Shadowrun, get this game. Its way better than the others. Dragonfall:DC was good, this is better. If you havent played the first ones, pick up Dragonfall:DC first, otherwise I can pretty much assure you you'll be disappointed going backwards.

I cannot WAIT to see what fan-generated content shows up!

reviewText:
What can I say? I'm a sucker for the Shadowrun lore and setting. So, my opinion might be kinda biased.

But with that out of the way, the game, to me, feels amazing - as others have said before me, if you liked SRR and Dragonfall, this is absolutely a must have. The story, at least as far as I've gotten into it, is on par with Dragonfall, along with interesting supporting characters and personal stories. The enviroments feel much more alive and vibrant with the new setting, getting in an even more colorful, exotic enviroment.

Loving the serie, I can't say much of the story, since despite the time I played I'm still pretty much at the start, but the writing is very good. And I could already see some interesting puzzles and hints to make your life easier on at least one run. Just a little hint, don't dismiss poetry slams.

There's comedy, there's intrigue, there's a mistery that I hope to solve, and there's characters I love.
The new Matrix is a really good step forward from the old interactions, in all aspects: artstyle, musical score and expecially mechanics. Not to mention some glimpses of other places as well, but I won't go much further discussing them, I'm still not sure how much they've been implemented.

The game isn't devoid of problems, obviously.

The artstyle is amazing, but the models do seem a bit dated, and despite that in opening/closing the menus I've seen some weird loading times or framerate issues. Nothing major, and with the nature of the game definitely not a dealbreaker in any way, but still something to keep in mind.

The animations, expecially the running one, still feels slightly off, BUT, spell, lightning and other visual effects HAVE definitely been improved.

Alas, I do have some gripes with the new Matrix system: mostly, on the controls. While the addition of free matrix movement and the new system are really amazing, point-and-click controls in my opinion don't meld really well with the nature of the minigame (For those of you who played Dragonfall, the AZT tower first room is a good reference to have an idea), and the camera sometimes works as much against you as the IC that you encounter.

IN SHORT:

Pros:
-Looking nicer and quite slick, with a lot more modelwork and with some snazzy effects here and there.
-Voice acting in some parts and animated cutscenes!
-Interesting characters and story
-New Matrix system!
-Lots of new stuff and mechanics, like spells, augmentations, different spirits etc.

Cons:
-Still some really really minor framerate issues in navigation/opening menus/etc.
-Matrix system is nice, but with some control and camera issues.
-Some animations look slightly off.

IN SHORT:

If you liked SRR and Dragonfall, this is an absolute yes. More of what you love, with some extra cherries on top.

If you are new to the serie and curious about the setting, this is a good chapter and it's self contained (as Dragonfall was self contained from Dead Man Switch.) Pick it up and give it a whirl, but be warned you might find the first games somewhat less enjoyable after getting used to the new mechanics and stuff.

If you don't like CRPG's, lots of text, and a slower, more methodical approach, or you didn't like the first two games, then chances are you won't like this.

See you in the shadows!
~Jariel.

The first Shadowrun game by HS, Shadowrun: Returns was good, but not great. Then Dragonfall came along and that improved on the aspects I thought could be better after the first game. Mainly the writing for the dialogue, characters and story improved a good deal, which I was very happy to see (reminded me of how Obsidian improved on the writing for Mask Of The Betrayer after NWN2 vanilla campaign).

Now we have Hong Kong, for  me I just wanted more of the quality that Dragonfall had and a little bit more open ended. Sure enough the maps are pretty huge, the graphics looks improved and the same great writing from Dragonfall. If you loved Dragonfall you will love this. If you thought Returns was cool but could be vastly improved I would highly reccomend you get Dragonfall and then Hong Kong, these two are pretty nice improvements over the first game imo.

Another big thing is this is the first Shadowrun game of this series that is built for JUST PC and not other platforms aswell. You can see that aspect helping things out to, as I said above the levels are bigger, graphics and art design is improved I think that is partly do to them just focusing on pc this time.

If you want another good crpg style rpg or if you like the Shadowrun universe give this a go! It is very very hard to do a game in a a series after it has hit it pinacle like it did with Dragonfall, thankfully this is more of the same, but in a good way. Dragonfall was brilliant ana vast improvement over the first game, Hong Kong does the impossible and keeps up the wonderful roleplaying at high levels like Dragonfall did.

reviewText:
Shadowrun: Hong KongDeveloper: Harebrained Schemes
Publisher: Harebrained Schemes

Note: A key for this game was provided by the developer for the purpose of writing an unbiased informative review. No other compensation was given.

Introduction
==========
Since 2013, we have seen the re-emergence of a classic RPG IP: Shadowrun. Boasting some fantastic storytelling and art direction, Shadowrun has been very successful thus far. With Shadowrun: Hong Kong, we have a third, equally well done entry into the series. Being a fan of this series since the SNES title in 1993, as well as the tabletop game, you can imagine my elation each time they have announced a new Shadowrun title.

The title Shadowrun is taken from one of the setting's main premises â€“ that corporate espionage runs rampant in the near-future of the setting. A shadowrun â€“ a successful data theft or physical break-in at a rival corporation or organization â€“ is one of the main tools employed by both corporate rivals and underworld figures. Shadowrunners are the mercenaries who take on these jobs. Let's dive into what you can expect as a Shadowrunner working in Hong Kong.

Gameplay
==========
This game has a lot to offer, and I will do my best to cover everything. I will probably forget *something*, so please forgive me!

Shadowrun: Hong Kong retains alot of the same mechanics and features as the previous two titles: You can create a character from 5 different races and 6 different character archetypes or classes. Human, Elves, Orks (yes, with a k), Dwarves, and Trolls are all available, with Street Samurai, Mage, Decker, Shaman, Rigger, and Physical Adept as professions. Each race has it's own perks and weaknesses, and each archetype has it's own strengths and downfalls. Street Samurai excel at physical combat and are typically heavily augmented with cyberware: cybernetic physical enhancements. Mages have access to a wide array of devastating spells, while Riggers can controls drones and vehicles from afar with them minds. Deckers access the Matrix with a datajack to search for an obtain important information, while Shamans commune with spirits to cast magic. Lastly, Physical Adepts are like Street Samurai, except that their melee attacks are magic-based, channelling them through their bodies.

Shadowrun uses a tactical turn-based battle system, using AP (action points) as a resource for all characters. Starting with 2 AP, all actions consume 1 or more AP to execute. Moving, reloading your guns (ammo is infinite!), casting spells, or using items all consume a set amount of AP. Once a character uses their AP, their turn is over and the next character gets to act. Being aware of yoru surroundings and using cover effective is one of the keys to survival many encounters. Cover offers several advantages, including higher dodge and higher defense against attacks.

Instead of the standard experience points system of many RPGs, Shadowrun uses a Karma system: completing objectives awards you with Karm points, which can be used to increase several stats and skills. Body, Quickness, Ranged, and Will are some examples, as well as weapon proficiencies such as Pistol, Shotgun, SMG, and Rifle. More points in each stat means more powerful skills and abilities. Certain character archetypes utilize certain stats, so make sure you invest your karma wisely!

The majority of the game is presented in text form, from the point of view of a storyteller/dungeonmaster. Dialogue takes place often, and you are given many choices for how to respond to certain situations during dialogue. Depending on how high some of your stats are, you will have different options during certain situations. For example, if you have a high intelligence stat, you might be able to hack a computer to access it, when you would otherwise be unable to. You also have a small handful of etiquettes to choose from, which allow you to respond to things in a certain style. Academic, Shadowrunner, and Street are a few examples.

Graphics
==========
Hong Kong retains the same fantastic art direction of the previous games. During character creation, you are able to choose from dozens of highly detailed character portraits to represent your character. Environments are absolutely stunning and highly detailed. Character models are equally impressive and sharp. If you zoom in while in-game you can take a look at these detailed character models, which you are able to do at anytime. Even the loading screens feature some beautiful artwork, as well as a detailed description of the area you are heading to or a short summary of the most recent events.

Sound and Music
==========
Hong Kong features alot of tracks with an Eastern influence, which works extremely well for the game's setting. The sound direction for this game is just as good as the art direction. Every track is designed to help immerse you into the story and every situation you encounter. Everything has a sound effect, including your gunshots, magic, even your footsteps (which can get annoying after awhile).

Performance
==========
Shadowrun: Hong Kong runs very well. I observed 60 FPS in most situations, with no lag, stuttering, massive frame drops, or random crashes. The game has no controller support that I noticed, and I wouldn't recommend it anyway. The entirely game is best played using just your mouse.

A feature added in Dragonfall makes a return here: the ability to save your game almost anywhere. The only notable exceptions are during dialogue or during battle.

Final Thoughts
==========
A worthy addition to the Shadowrun series of game, Hong Kong boasts enhanced features that originated in Dragonfall. An improved Shadowrun Editior allows for the creation of your own campaigns, utilizing the Steam Workshop to upload and share them with others.

If you are a fan of this IP, a fan of RPGs, or just a fan of great storytelling, Shadowrun: Hong Kong is a great game that deserves your attention.

Gameplay Demo
==========
https://youtu.be/D9jN1uVtlCU

Nerd House Verdict:
==========
Highly Recommended
Be sure to check out Nerd House Gaming for more reviews!

As  a lover of both SR:R and SR:Dragonfall I simply refuse to recommend this piece of unfinished, glued-together, atrocities.

What is the reason?

Pros: Aesthetically pleasing, atmosphere is okay-ish, but lacking compared to either installment of the series. Most of the setting seems to consist of empty space, lots of running around from A to B, npcs lack that certain something in this game that made you feel for them (compassion, anger, disgust, etc.) in the other installments of HBS's shadowrun campaigns.

Some interesting characters, but far too few compared to Dragonfall.

Cool new Cyberware, new skills, awesome new spells, pretty sick unique weapons and for all the adept lovers out there: weapon foci and of course, revamped matrix, wow, am I tuned for this!
That's it!

Cons:

Almost everything.

Bugs over bugs, starting with missing equipment of followers (that you had to unlock via skillpoints!), over vanishing equipment (be it spells, weapons, or support items) up to mission breaking bugs.

Dialogues are ridiculously slow paced, arduous and options are rare and even if you find options, don't bother to try out different ones, as 90% of them will merit the same outcome, especially fun in the few final missions. Oh, and what is more, one cannot substitute the attributes of their followers in 50% of all cases. You need strength 5 for something? One of your team has it... Too bad, that does not count, joke's on you, logic! Obviously a character needs to be the leader to bash in a damn bookshelf. reviewText:
I am really impressed with the game so far. The writing and story seem to be great. The visuals, sound effects, and music have definitely been upgraded. The UI in particular has been optimized and is far more open. I personally love the asian styling in the art and music. However, Hong Kong is still the same game as Shadowrun Returns and Dragonfall. If you loved those games then this is defintiely for you. If you didn't like them, you should probably look elsewhere. I have heard some complaints about the story in the long term, but I have not delved deep enough to confirm.

Pros
-More expansive backgrounds
-Better Atmosphere (Sounds and Art)
-Much Better UI
-Animated Scenes (Soemthing like cutscenes but shorter)
-Writing
-More Polished art (Cyberware finally shows up on the character model)
-Polished Visuals
-Much better Matrix

Cons
-Some technical bugs
-No tutorials for hacking (I had no clue what I was doing and I tripped the alarm)

This is a polished version of the Shadowrun Returns experience. If you liked those then you will love this.

reviewText:
Shadowrun Hongkong is a great turn-based strategy game combined with role playing elements.
Btw, this is my first time playing Shadowrun series. This game made me interested in playing the other series (Returns and Dragonfall)

Pros :
- Good character creation. There are 6 distinct classes, but you can make your own customized class if you want.
- Beautiful level and environment design.
- Memorable characters with great background story for each.
- There are tons of choices you can make in this game. That makes you really involved inside the game. Not to mention that your choices have consequences.
- Good writing. Every conversation is interesting. Even without voice actors, you will always get hooked into what the characters are saying. Seriously, it's like you're acting as a character inside a novel.
- Good, balanced, and challenging combat.
- I love the fact that sometimes you can complete your mission unscratched by talking your way through. But of course, some conditions must be met. A high amount charisma and some other status will be required.
- Okay story, but not that great.

Cons :
- I encountered a few small glitches, but not game breaking.
- If I already scrolled to certain point of the stash and I dragged an item to change my equipment, the scroll keeps coming back to the top of the stash. This is a bit annoying. If I want to drag multiple items and those items are located near each other, I must drag, scroll again, drag again, scroll again.

Overall, I give this game 9/10. A must have for turn based strategy fans.

reviewText: Alright, wrapped this one up today. Really another excellent game by Harebrained Schemes. As with previous games, this one is a stand alone adventure, but of course, community mods mean you can keep playing with the updated game engine and new adventures. Additionally, this one has multiple story arcs and several endings, meaning that even with the base game, there is a ton of replay value. The story was excellent, the gameplay solid and with solid improvements to the game mechanics, most notably with the Matrix, which I thought was markedly improved. There are some aggravating bugs such as equipment given to henchmen disappearing after missions, but overall it was a seamless experience beyond that particular aggravating bug. Really, a solid gaming experience that is easy to recommend.\n\n8 servants of the queen with 1000 teeth being destroyed by my bad â™¥â™¥â™¥ party out of 10. *The other 2 were banished back to their plane of existence of course*

reviewText: If you enjoyed SRR and Dragonfall you can't go wrong here.  As much as I enjoyed it, I do wish they'd taken another month or three to finish polishing the game and filling out all the story lines.  Particularly near the end of the game a lot of the minor characters' stories seemed lazily finished or in the case of the magic shop owner, just NULL txt after the climactic ending battle... kind of disappointing.  I played a decker on this, my first playthrough, I liked the revamped matrix overall.  I wasn't sure how I felt about the blocker ICE mini-games... I disliked the idea of it but was good at them and found it enjoyable at the same time.  It also seemed unimportant to ever get more than a mid-level deck which is fine I suppose... I was saving up for a Fairlight Excalibur but then I just kept buying more cyber and better armor and pistols and it never seemed like a major detriment.  I hope they continue making and improving upon these games, it's been a blast to inhabit the SR universe again!  Next major step would be an engine revamp/overhaul.  I don't have a problem with the graphics quality per se, but it would be great to have more... freedom and dynamism: movable camera, bigger maps, NPCs in motion more, etc.

reviewText:
Unlike the other Shadow Run games, Hong Kong falls short on several avenues. In this iteration, only two of the five characters have their back stories flushed out, with personal missions garnering comparable intrigue to the main story line. That said, the main story line was not terribly interesting; however, the final chapter did have an appropriate climax and resolution.

The engagements in the Matrix have changed dramatically and you will either love or hate the change. Personally, some changes such as the password component associated with firewalls is an interesting addition. Also the ability to disconnect from interface at any time is a nice change. A less welcome change is the addition of the frogger sequence where you need to dodge the path of the security programs.

While the main story line and personal stories of some of the characters are lacking, the brief interactions you have with NPC's in the world are short but very interesting.

Mission and gear:
There don't seem to be very many missions. I think there were maybe 10 missions before the final chapter?
There are some additions in terms of weapons but, in my playthrough at least, there were no special armors with attribute/skill bonuses - only cosmetic differences.

Overall, the game, the story, and the changes are quite disappointing.

If you're desperate for a new shadow run game, I would save your money until the game goes on sale.

reviewText:
Update: I've finally gotten around to finishing the game and I still don't recommend it.

The Matrix is still really, really annoying. The ending of the game didn't quite give me the closure I wanted and worst of all, three months after release, there are still a lot of bugs and typos. I had to restart the epilogue because one crew member wouldn't go back to their spot so I could talk to them. The final fight was acceptable, I suppose.

It wasn't all bad, but you're better off playing Dragonfall - Director's Cut. I did like the new cyberware-affinity stat, cyberweapons, and cooler portraits, but overall the whole game felt a little lacking. Gaichu and Racter are still the best companions out of the group and Is0bel was needlessly irritating throughout the game. Nothing about her character design, just her actions, motives, and backstory painted her as someone who was....not very pleasant or agreeable. I'd like to also point out that I am ranking a post-humanist psychopath and a ghoul samurai above her in terms of agreeability.

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Want to love it, can't do it. Doesn't live up to Dragonfall - Director's Cut. Wait for a Director's Cut version of Hong Kong before buying.

I'm a good ways into the game, and I have a couple big complaints.

1. Feels like QA was non-existent. Scripts are poorly proofread and have tons of spelling or grammatical errors. At first I thought it was some idiosyncracy due to the fact that everyone is speaking Cantonese, but after a while the errors became more and more obvious and it became apparent that proofreading teams didn't do their jobs.

Additionally, programming leaves a lot to be desired. The fact that I have to wait 10 seconds to enter the matrix whenever Is0bel jacks in? What is up with that? Sometimes character models don't get their run animations and just ice skate around. I'm doing Racter's story mission at the Ares facility, and the poor AI programming I ran into there is what drove me to write this review. The other team of Shadowrunners has been naively programmed to simply run to the exit point and just stand there. They never leave the level or move out of the way. If you had someone left behind, they're stuck there and you either pray one of them moves out of the doorway for a turn to let you in or you restart the level from your last save (which is, unfortunately for me, back at the start of the mission). I'm not even to the end yet. Countless people I know have complained about even worse gameplay issues near the end of the game (portraits not switching, other strange behavior, unexplainable lag). I was going to continue with one run a day because of how long missions take, but at this point I'm too tired to continue the game at all if this is what I have to deal with.

2. Story is great, it's good. Story is what defines the Shadowrun games. Somehow, with Hong Kong, it feels like too much influence is put on dialogue in between missions with NPCs and side characters. I'm a completionist, so I try to talk to every NPC until they repeat dialogue, wasn't a problem in Dragonfall. For Hong Kong, it feels like every character gets their own sideplot, and it's a little too much. Talking to every NPC after a mission takes up to an hour, and I'm stuck in a Catch 22, either I speak with the NPCs and waste my time taking in details that may or may not matter, or I avoid them and possibly lose out on a side quest for nice gear/karma or some important story detail needed for an ending. All of them seem to speak with a heavy sense of foreshadowing, so a very fake sense of obligation is placed upon the player instead of genuine interest.

I'm hoping a Director's Cut will fix the programming issues, at the very least. I enjoyed Dragonfall a lot, and I saw a lot of elements from Dragonfall making their way to Hong Kong, and I think the setting and overall plot is interesting enough to warrant a thumbs up, poor programming and story pacing aside. The crew is more or less just as interesting as last game's crew (Gaichu, Racter, and Kindly Cheng are great). The game's heart is definitely in the right place, it's just implemented poorly.

reviewText:
Returning back to the franchise with Shadowrun: Hong Kong feels very familiar yet fresh thanks mainly to its own Asian flavor we didn't really get to see in previous two entries. As befitting my take on these other games, this one is also not a singular experience and is most definitely worth talking about.

If you're not familiar with my previous Shadowrun reviews I'll give you a quick summary: it's a cyberpunk future meets fantasy; meaning you have your cybernetic orc-augmented street samurai running around with their group of freelancers-for-hire aka shadowrunners, but the twist this time around is we've going to Hong Kong. Specifically, second incarnation of the Kowloon Walled City mostly. I believe this game's big draw lies in exploring the Chinese part of Shadowrun setting where myths and legends are more real then anywhere else and vicious mega corporations aren't as massively influential as much as they ARE the government.

Not everything is perfect, of course. With such a great setting in-hand and for the most part likable and varied characters, I'll get back to that in a second, you might be thinking it's an amazing game story-wise. Sadly that was not the impression Hong Kong left on me. Not in a sense it's a bad game or even badly written as much as the fact it comes off as disjointed with main story missions just kinda connecting without any real investment. That of course depends on how much you care about a particular character in your party and his connection to the main character as well as overall story motivation for good three quarters or so of its run time. If you're not emotionally invested in what you're being told instead of shown, and you spread out with side missions, this story will not do much for you until it escalates later on following some pretty decent foreshadowing. One thing that took me by surprise, but was something I enjoyed because it played into my tendency to explore and talk to everyone, was that some resolutions and options only become available to you after following up on unrelated and completely optional side activities or dialog. This even affects the very last decision you get to make in the main game, which might irk someone used to games clearly presenting your options.

As far as gameplay and mechanics overall go it's your familiar Shadowrun package â€“ that of tactical turn-based RPG, although they did commit to some tweak. Primarily in the Matrix in a sense that now you can move around in real-time until you engage in combat. I'm heavily split on guard programs running their patrols and having you avoid them, but I did enjoy the new pattern matching hacking mini-game. I assume this feeling is not unanimously shared by everyone. It is worth noting that unlike the previous two games Hong Kong seems to have either pushed the Unity engine to some limit or memory leaks lead to game running choppily after couple of hours of continuous play. Bad experience also came from scripts not playing properly couple of times and game hanging up during some engagements, but that's nothing worth really dismissing it over.

In closing I'd like to mention the bonus campaign Extended Edition introduced by saying it certainly had some meat on its ones and ran for at least good four or so hours. I do wish it gelled better with the main campaign or continued it in some more meaningful way as opposed to having you chase an antagonist you may or may not even remember at the end. Good point is that it does offer you a pretty big decision at the end, even if the entire campaign comes of as weak compared to what you did earlier.

Time for me to say I do recommend this game wholeheartedly although your mileage will vary depending on how much you end up caring about the emotional angle. See you around, chummers.

reviewText:
Mmm... yeah it's alright.

Stuff hasn't changed much since Dragonfall, with only a handful of new things in the gameplay. Probably the most notable is the changes to the matrix, though I'm not really sure I like them since dodging and evading opposition isn't as fun as making it go boom. At least there were plenty of booms outside of the matrix, as well as non violent and stealthy options for most of the missions. There also were not quite as many skillchecks as in the last game, so that is kind of nice. And if there is a skillcheck, then it usually lets you pick one of your party members to fill in unless it involves charisma.

The story is decent as to be expected, with a cast of characters that tend to have pretty interesting backstories and development. Gaichu, the ghoul samurai, is an easy favorite, but the rest of your crew is plenty good as well. I'm not really a fan of setting the game in Hong Kong and the inevitable heavy involvement of triads in the plot, but it did fine with what it had. I still prefer the last game being set in Berlin, but that's probably just my own personal biases at play. Oh, and there are some cookies here and there for people who did play Dragonfall where stuff from that game gets mentioned. You even can meet one of the characters from that in this game too.

Honestly, it's basically Dragonfall again but in a different setting and a few minor gameplay changes. I'm not really compelled to put much effort into this review, since most of what I said about the last game applies to this one as well. Good thing that Dragonfall was excellent. So I guess that means this is excellent too. :o

If you liked Dragonfall, you probably will like this too. Have funs!

With as much written content as a novel, branching storylines intimately linked to your character choices, and a real tabletop feel where intrigue and negotiation can supplant the need for bloodshed; Shadowrun: Hong Kong is the commensurate single player RPG experience.  It is best suited for avid readers who love video games, and for gamers who love interactive fiction.  The tactical combat, the freedom of character creation, and the a-la-carte missions should appeal to the more goal-oriented RPG fans among us.  But if you don't like to read, you'll find the game (and its predecessors) to be a bit of a turn-off (even though they are a much better read than basically every other RPG these days).  For me, the game's writing and art are on par with Dragonfall, and its gameplay has been dramatically enhanced.

The Writing:

S:HK's writing is its single greatest feature.  The narrative voice and descriptiveness of the prose is unlike any you'll read in a modern game.   Even so-called indie titles whose primary content is text--housed in a minimalist frame--cannot compete with the evocative style of the narration.  Each intro scene paints a vivid picture in a concise few paragraphs.  At no point does the game talk down to its player, who is quickly immersed in the language and style of the setting with little primer.  Those familiar with the first two games may earn more from the reading experience: The lingo and dialogue of the Shadowrun universe are unique and endearing.  It is not Star Trek"-style technobabble; it all makes sense in this dark

reviewText:
I love the world of Shadowrun, but much as I love it, it's just not enough to make up for lame game design.

The writing is sometimes interesting, but rather than feeling like I'm part of the story, I usually feel like I'm being talked at. I don't feel like my choices really matter. The many curious conversations available in the game hub should have been connected with small playable storylines and quests. The fact that they (mostly) are not, means that these conversations ultimately feel hollow.

Worse, the game mechanics often feel awkward. Why can't I use Is0bel's mine skill before battle, to prepare the battleground? Why can't I use medkits after battle? And what's up with the stealth? Stealth is a fun mechanic, and a huge part of the Shadowrun world ... but the implementation is terrible. The realtime controls are so loose that I sometimes can't get my characters to do what I want, and alarms are raised - not because of any tactical error on my part, but because the controls just didn't support my needs.

Which brings me to technical issues. The most obvious issue is the level load time. Even with a mid-level SSD, levels require 10-60 seconds to load. This wouldn't be so bad, except that I in the stealth sections of the game, I often have to reload a lot, because I'm unable to control my characters well enough to stealth effectively.

The other big technical problem is the AI. In one of the side missions, I gained the support of several NPS's, but they were almost useless in combat. Mostly, they lagged behind my team, such that they weren't even useful as damage sponges. When they did get near the front line, they made terrible choices. For example, the physical adept would power up ... then run back and forth till he ran out of AP.

So, sorry Harebrained Schemes. I love the world, and I love the idea of this game, but I can't find much to like about the execution. I like the art, but I wish you'd spent more time on story and gameplay, and less time on graphic art.

reviewText:
Note! Finished game at 3.0.5 version, so some points herein may not be accurate with upcoming patches.

Tl;dr- Hong Kong is an interesting stab at the lore of eastern Runner hub. Typical to the setting, betrayal and intrique with nice eastern twists while you work out while people are out to kill you. Several interesting party members with well-fleshed personalities. Varied and interesting missions.

Review in Full
Now, as for the actual review. I was curious to see HBS's next scheme- certainly, Seattle has always been the heart and soul of the Shadowrun world, which often sadly leaves out the other interesting hubs and lore. Dragonfall gave us a nice glimpse at the Flux state and Berlin. Hong Kong delivers it's titular city, or at least, the less savory parts of it. But I savored them regardless.

Now, I'll try and keep my review as spoiler-free as possible, so expect certain amount of vagueness. After the initial tutorial level.

You're basically fresh outta prison, when you receive a call from your estranged step-father to meet him in HK. Keen on dusting off the Barren's crud from your boots, you fly off to adventure. Reunited with more than one estranged family member, you are soon embroiled in a plot involving your step-father's mysterious dissapearance and his captor's persistent attempts at having you killed. Welcome to HK.

The story unfolds pretty free-form from hereon in- you're allowed a choice of party members covering each base and skillset, as per usual, with some of them joining in on the ride later on. I found the starting party very affable and ended up having them on the team 90% of the time, if not for their obvious proficiency in getting things done, then for their dialogue and banter. For reference, I was playing a Rigger.

The missions provide a good number of choices between stealth and taking the thrillgang approach. I found myself talking my way in and out of trouble more than 'go loud', and found the game very accommodating to having your main as the Face of the party. Cheers to that.

There seem to be various skill checks of all sorts, and calls for Etiquettes almost constantly- maybe it was the smaller scope of the campaign as opposed to Dragonfall, but I definitely enjoyed having these options open, or at least, present.

As far as difficulty is concerned, I think the game was too easy by far. Then again, I've been playing Returns from the get-go, and maybe I've picked up a few tricks here and there, but I found most of the time I had no need for medkits nor revival kits. Maybe if I had been more combat-oriented rather than stealth-bluffing my way, things would've been different.

There's a lot of foreshadowing in the plot about the eventual Big Bad, but it turned out the final dungeon and the final encounters with the BBEG were almost too easy. Admittably, I had geared up with some of the strongest armour and weapons in the game, but I had expected a lot more fight out of this mysterous nemesis.

SUMMARY OF POSITIVE, NEUTRAL AND NEGATIVE POINTS:
+ Interesting take on the eastern Runner Haven.
+ Good cast of characters, with the forerunning Gobbet and Is0bel standing out as the most memorable due to their personalities, conflicted pasts and mannerisms.
+ Fun side missions with unexpected twists.
+ Remixed OST with an oriental flair
+ New items to enrich your Running experience
+ Devs had taken time to make custom portraits for small Scene events, something I could appreciate.
+ I'm sure any and all UGC modders will appreciate the plethora of new assets for making our own adventures.

+ / - Quite short in length. Naturally, you'd want good things to last longer. :P
+ / - Redesigned Matrix. While I am a fan of the old, and was somewhat wary of the new system, I do admit it has it's perks. Much better stealthing. Although, being of a poor memory, I did not like how the new system plays out like a memory game now. Discovered passwords should be visible at code prompts, instead of having to rummage thru your Scene notes.
+ / - Reward choices at the end of certain missions. Loot or allies, loot or allies...
+ / - Varied levels of dialogue ranging from excellent and funny to downright bad. Main cast dialogue tends to be on the upper scale of things, but the writer(s) just didn't seem to flesh out any of the secondary or tertiary cast, save a few merchants.
+ / - There are no clear benefits for using Duncan's Ziptie ability. Although it's probably good karma to spare foes, the game does not particularly reward going out of your way in not killing combatants but neutralizing them instead.

- Personally, as much as I found the plot interesting, I did not like to be hammered into a certain role in terms of the story. Having that freedom taken from me sort of put a damper on the roleplaying experience. Felt like taking stage cues from the GM or storyteller most of the time.
- As the game currently stands, having the Laser Sniper rifle combined with an autoloader and Monofilament Whip turn you into a one-man army, as they are ludicrously overpowered. I even gave up using drones mid-way thru the game after I had purchased this fearsome combo.
- Lack of Polish. At 3.0.5, there were still numerous instances of missing or wrong dialogue, formatting errors in the dialogue itself, some anomalies with armour item losing it's AC, Stash lag and surprisingly long load times which may be attributed to the updated game engine, dunno. Hopefully fixed in the future.
- Final fights pose no real threat. The main baddie does not live up to their reputation.

reviewText:
The jist of this post: I can safely recommend this as a *solid* game, with warts. Those familiar with the other games will want this game primarily for the updated editor, which allows a multitude of new options via UGC. Note: the Matrix environment is different to all previous HB games.

-`-`-`-`-`-`-`-`-`-`-`-` START `-`-`-`-`-`-`-`-`-`-`-`-

This is the 3rd modern iteration of Shadowrun to come from Harebrained Studios (excluding the original 'Dragonfall', which was an add-on for SRR), and it's another on-rails extravaganza. However, a lot of extra features have gone into this experience that will ultimately bode well for people keen to create their own adventures, via UGC (User Generated Content).

Shadowrun has a rich tabletop history, which HB have tried to bring to us three times before (Shadowrun Returns, the SRR DLC, 'Dragonfall', and the stand alone Director's Cut version of 'Dragonfall'). Each time, new features emerged; each time there were several flaws (that said, each iteration was satisfactory; low replayability, however).

This game was made from a tabletop perspective: create your own stories, to share with others. It's a noble goal, but tabletop games are meant to be played *with* other people, not *by* 1 person alone. This is the critical failure of the Unity-engine based Shadowrun games, and it's something that can't be fixed due to the nature of the game (sandbox, no multiplayer).

You can not revisit areas. You are on rails. The story that plays out tends towards linear (due to the complexity involved in properly branching choices taken in-game). You are not allowed to grind karma and nuyen indefinitely to build your little super shadowrunner.

People play Shadowrun to build a character, and a story, and essentially live vicariously through their created avatar(s) in a universe that can be *imagined* by a group of players. These games are very static & limited; what you see is what you get.

An example of some of my gripes: despite some *very* gorgeous art assets, once you've in an area & have completed the mission, you leave and (90% of the time) you can't return to the area. Once the game is over, most UGC won't let you import your character over. Just like SRR, when Telestrian offers to make you his executive, you're like Cool

reviewText:
This review was done with a key obtained from the developer.

Summary:
Choice is the name of the game of Shadowrun: Hong Kong, and while it rides that strength for most of the game, what you end up getting is a very inconsistent experience that has a lot of highs: but a lot of lows as well. Whether or not you'll be able to enjoy the game will be entirely based on who you are: are you a person who's willing to sacrifice consistency for high points, such as optional character's story telling and very indepth battling? Or will you have problem with the low points of missions that miss the mark completely and missing elements of narrative that tie things all together. In the end, I enjoyed my time with Shadowrun: Hong Kong, but the game will take a toll on you, and it's definitely going to cause a polar reaction out of people. Check the lists below for more details on exactly the positive and negatives that this game has.

Gameplay Footage and Video Review: https://youtu.be/1ypf7TJ4TzQ

Lists:

+:
Those who like choices making a difference in game will find Hong Kong right up their alley. Limited resources and plot changes will make every choice feel like it made a difference.
World is intriguing to say the least in terms of the cyberpunk/magic fusion. Do like how the story was woven with some of the smaller events to make it feel like a truly thought out experience.
Combat at the core is solid with lots of options and a lot of ways of dealing with your opponent.
Outside combat options and ability to pass checks never distracted but combat but felt like a welcome change to what was going on, and I did like talking my way out of things.
Layout of battlefields and different missions worked well. Lots of variation in cover and different combat scenarios.
Like the idea of future content being available through steam workshop.
The optional characters stories and back stories shine. Gaichu and Racter were my favorite characters, with Gobbet coming in a close third.
-:
The inconsistency. It feels like several elements were left on the cutting room for before they were finished, which hurts the game overall. Too many options may have been given here, as opposed to polishing some of the ones that existed. The game feels like it isn't the vision that the team had when all is said and done.
AI can do some dumb things, but it's all over the place for the most part. Those who I've talked to that are trying to get through hard mode are noting ridiculous hits and unfair challenge, but on normal, they'd follow up a smart play with a dumb one.
It takes a while to get everything under your belt, and with no real â€œteaserâ€ of what each class does, you may be restarting a couple of times.
The bugs. I'm not talking â€œoh, that's funnyâ€ kind of bugs, but the bugs that forced mission restarts. There's a lack of quality control here all over the place, and it shows up in the worst ways at times.
Hit percentages? Basically â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥t in my eyes. Don't know how many times I missed a 90% shot repeatedly in a row, but it got into double digits.
Really, no mage character besides mercs that you have to pay each mission? This feels like a real bad over sight.
Loading times are insane.

reviewText:
This is a neutral recommendation, and a review written for people who played previous shadowrun games. If you are a new player, look at other reviews.

The story is really intriguing but follows the same lines as the previous: Some big bad supernatural mojo is happening, and you have to do something about it.

Yeah, I have a lot of hours on this. The engine is still held together by masking tape and chewing gum, so I leave the game on while I do stuff like cook dinner instead of endure ridiculous load times. Even after all the patches, there are stuck dialog bugs and stuck NPC bugs from time to time. It's inconsistent and I've no idea how to reproduce them. It seems the more campaigns I play, the more bugs I encounter.

I've played 3 campaigns and each had different NPC bugs.  I had Crafty's conversations stuck on the same loop, and she is one of the most important NPCs to talk to regularly. I also had NPCs not appear where they were supposed to after cutscenes. Some of these bugs require restarting a level or even the entire campaign to fix and are incredibly frustrating, especially when you have lost progress. I've also seen buttons not trigger properly after cutscenes/dialogs. You have to make separate saves constantly to avoid these messes.

After 3 games, they still don't have a way to address combat UI problems like moving to a space behind another character because clicking on that space selects the blocking character instead. When you try to shoot from beyond weapon range, the game doesn't let you know that your character will leave cover to move foward before taking a shot. This is a very serious oversight especially since the game never actually tells you weapon ranges in actual numbers. I've also seen enemies move positions after reloading a game, and characters starting combat with wrong amounts of AP.

Things like line of sight and flanking angles are some times non-intuitive and really hard to figure out, and along with BS RNG, this makes combat a chore, especially when it loads 10 times slower than a fully modded Skyrim. Seriously, it's faster to terminate the game and restart than it is to ask it to load a save game while one is in progress. Some things that look like they should be cover are not, and things that look like they shouldn't block your vision does.

Pros:
* Best story so far (IMO)
* most interesting companions to date (IMO)
* better weapons (melee especially)
* better cyberware
* melee is very strong now late game due to new weapons and cyberware (still weak early)
* riggers can use 2 of the same drone
* a lot more missions where meeting etiquette and charisma checks will avoid all combat (good for role playing)
* ley lines cause spells to bounce and heal the caster every turn (makes up for being out in the open. In previous games, it was often not worth being on ley lines cause you can get chunked hard)
* you can boost essence by investing in to body stat. This allows magic users to get some nifty cyberware and not gimp themselves.
* creative placement of some paydata outside of the matrix

Cons:
* rifles still king of DPS, especially with auto-reload cyber armlaunchers
* mages/shamans still weak and boring
* haste 4 has been nerfed (shamans do not need more nerfs)
* new real time stealth matrix is terrible
* new simon says matrix hacking is terrible. Both this and the above relies on player skill, not character skill, which is stupid in a RPG
* End game missions seem much easier than in previous games, and not only because of new weapons. There seem to be fewer enemies, shorter levels, and the end boss is an anticlimactic pushover.
* there is still really no reason to make your main character a decker. The provided party member is more than adequate and the matrix doesn't really get too hard until the very end.
* money is still SUPER tight, especially if you want to get cyberware in addition to equipment.
* there is no reason to use the paid shadowrunners as money is so sparse
* companions still have mediocre builds and are unreliable in combat without shaman buffs, making it important to build your main character as a combat specialist

I guess in conclusion, only get this if you want more well written Shadowrun stories. Shadowrun Hong Kong is still a top notch narrative ride, but the road is full of potholes speedbumps.

reviewText:
Making a recommendation for Shadowrun HK is a pretty straightforward thing: Did you enjoy the previous Shadowruns by Harebrained? Then you'll most likely enjoy this one as well.
While it isn't as much of a clear case of a pure upgrade and improvement like with Dragonfall and the first official campaign SR:HK added enough small changes and toys so that you have some stuff to experiment with while keeping most of their tried and true formula intact. It uses the combat system of Dragonfall Director's Cut and also has the customizable perk systems for your fellow runners which was also introduced in Dragonfall DC which is a very nice addition.
Some of the completely new stuff include new spells, some changes to older spells, new more varied drones like sniper and auto fire variants, new decking rigs, a new cyber affinity skill for chrome and mostly more chrome itself, especially cyber weapons like cyber claws or a cyber leash.
The matrix segments also got overhauled, it offers more visual variations but the biggest change is that you can sneak around and crack firewalls with a minigame in order to avoid combat in the matrix almost completely if you wish. If you don't you can just let seekers spot you until defender drones spawn which makes the matrix pretty much play out like in the previous shadowruns. The sneaking in the matrix is frankly extremely clunky but the option to avoid fights is a very welcome one and even if you trigger the alarm the fights aren't as grindy/boring as in the previous games' matrix sections.
Another change which I really liked is that in general you have a lot more opportunities to use non combat skills and quick thinking to avoid a lot of fights, a lot more so than in previous instalments. Which is not only nice for roleplaying reasons but it also is very handy in situations where you would be kinda under-equipped and the fight pretty darn difficult.

The story/mission structure hasn't really changed, you eventually end up in an hub area from which you launch your missions, and you're mostly free to chose which mission to tackle next.
Your fellow Runners are a pretty interesting bunch again with entertaining/interesting dialogues between missions even though I have to say that some tended to be a bit less memorable than in Dragonfall. I feel that especially with Is0bel they could have done more - while her personal quest was very enjoyable the hub interactions with her felt rather bare bones. Props for the other companions though.
Another nice touch is that you get a chance to have a small conversation with each mercenary runner you can hire. Similar to what Dragonfall DC did with Lucky Strike just a bit less detailed but for all mercenary runners.

The plot itself is arguably more simple than Drgaonfall but personally I feel that Hong Kong has the best atmosphere of the Shadorun games yet which is saying something because I always enjoyed the setting and its atmosphere a lot. The music is spot on and helps to reinforce the atmosphere and the cutscenes and writing further cement it.
And the basic point remains that I very much enjoy the setting of Shadowrun, its cyberpunk and its bleak dystopian world and HK does a good job of bringing the setting to life yet again.

In conclusion it's easy to recomment Shadowrun HK to fans of the series, the only real flaws I can think of is that the pure plot is rather simple if that is very important too you - or that if you feel like you've grown bored of the previous games' formula then this game prolly doesn't add enough new things for you to to shake things up.
Otherwise I really enjoyed the game, especially that you have more dimplomatic/non-combat opportunities than ever. But most importantly for me I absolutely adored the atmosphere of the game and the mystery of it. It's gonna be interesting to see how a replay feels after the mystery has been lifted - I guess we'll see soon enough ;)

reviewText:
Shadowrun: Hong Kong is an isometric tactical cyberpunk RPG. The year is 2056, a dark and dystopian world, a world filled with Orc gangers, Elf corporate wadge-slaves and dragon dictators, a world where magic and cybernetics mix. Raymond Black, the man who took you off the street as a teen and raised you, makes a desperate call to you and your step-brother Duncan to meet him Hong Kong, but you arrive to a chaotic conspiracy where you must burn your former life and survive as a Shadowrunner mercenary for the triads.

Pros: Once again an improvement over the previous games of the series, from the UI to a brand new selection of equipment. The background stills are just as gorgeous as we got used to, but character models are much more defined, especially Orcs and Trolls that are much less stocky-looking. The writing is as good as ever: Your crew but also merchants and crooks have their own story to tell, many of which have funny moments very reminiscent of (and likely inspired by) tabletop RPG player experiences. Your hub, Heoi, feels more dynamic, with NPCs such as other pay-for-hire Shadowrunners that come and go in between missions, talking about their expertise and past experience when you catch them while they're around. Your crew is much more involved in runs: each mission's progression, conversations and resolution will play out differently from one crew combinations to another, adding to the replay value of the game. You even get to chose your own character's past and history through conversations, choices that carry over throughout the game in future interactions and relationships. Music is just as immersive, some are Asian-inspired remixes of familiar tracks, others brand new compositions that really contribute to fleshing out the atmosphere of Hong Kong. The Matrix feels more alive with a sleeker look & feel and reimagined puzzles and behavior patterns for surveillance and defensive software and ICE.

Cons: The main story is still rather linear, and the ending feels short or rushed, likely in an attempt to leave it opened for the upcoming Shadows of Hong Kong mini-sequel DLC. Although there's a wider variety of combat animation, the tactical combat still falls short of other more combat-oriented games, like the XCOM or Shadowrun Chronicles games. Combat in general feels too optional, and can too often be avoided completely.

Verdict: â˜…â˜…â˜…â˜…â˜† - Next on your list!

This is the best Shadowrun game to date, with truly excellent writing on par with Shadowrun: Dragonfall, and that offers a large variety of ways to approach every interaction and mission. Of course, if you found no appeal to those past games, the improvements in this one won't change your mind. But to others, this is a great CRPG that I definitively recommend! I can't wait to see what the new and improved editor will allow the community to create for Steam Workshop!

reviewText:
Shadowrun: Hong Kong is the third standalone game in Harebrained Schemesâ€™ critically-acclaimed Shadowrun cRPG series. From early on with the first edition ruleset when I played the paper and dice version with friends, to the SNES version to today's offerings I have always been keen on the hybrid, genre smashing world of Shadowrun. One part Cyberpunk and one part Fantasy.

With several decades of both table-top roleplaying books and novels to pull from HBS has taken many of the important elements and injected them into this series of games. SR:HK promises a revamped matrix (something my Decker is keen to jump into!), better 'maps'/lanscapes, improved choice and more interesting non-player characters.

The world is controlled by massive mega-corporations who do battle with one another by using 'Shadow Runners' as their illegal proxies.  Much of the time in the Sixth Wolrd (another name for the Shadowrun Universe) the strings are ultimately being pulled by a powerful entity such as a Dragon and thus the term - Never Deal With A Dragon which was lifted from the title of a SR novel. At the beginning of this tale we recieve a message from our past, urgin us to travel to Hong Kong. What will be waiting there for us? My guess, trouble, what else?

So far I am enjoying my time with Shadowrun HK. The NPC interactions can get a little wordy but pacing seems solid and the story ramps up quickly. Circumstances are not what they seem and the story unfolds in comfortable layers. If you enjoy Cyberpunk, tactical RPGs and games like XCOM, then this is likely a game you want to check out!

If you care to join me, as I play my Decker/Rigger you are welcome to: https://youtu.be/R3GW-6mQjMA

Peace,

reviewText:
Updated now that I've finished the game.

Extremely similar to Dragonfall. It's not deviated strongly from the formula established by the previous game - you have a hub area and you go on runs while waiting for the plot to move forward, getting to know NPCs and team members during the down time. Not necessarily a bad thing, though I do wish they would've mixed things up a little bit with the format. The story does rely a bit too much on telling rather than showing (we're often told that conditions inside the Kowloon Walled City are real bad, but we see precious little of that, for example), and the game does not have an antagonist as interesting and well-characterized as the previous game's.

The writing is all around great, as expected, and the gameplay is likewise solid. All the same, it feels like it's retreading old ground - beyond a few minor improvements to interface and the gameplay, it does nothing new - the structure of the plot is similar in that your central goal is revealed early on and much of the game is spent doing other things before you can pursue it. Unlike in Dragonfall, you're not actively working towards a goal, but rather passing the time until plot-related events crop up automatically, which I felt was an unwelcome change, as it deemphasized the player character's role as principal actor, though this is a bit of a minor quibble.

Furthermore, there seem to be less impactful choices to be made than in Dragonfall, and there's less of Dragonfall's bits of cleverness, like the metacommentary on RPG dialogue conventions that was Eiger's throwing back your empty compliments at you. Some things did leave me guessing - a character I thought to be a minor NPC turned out to be regularly recurring character who hated my guts, and I'm unsure whether this was because of my conduct towards him or whether it was pre-determined by the writers. If it was indeed the former case, I suppose I'd have to be quite impressed - nonetheless, regardless of how he feels about you, that entire subplot amounts to exactly nothing by the end.

Overall though, I'd call this game an excellent work that nonetheless fails to reach the heights of its predecessor's glory. If you liked Dragonfall, you'll definitely enjoy this a great deal.

9/10 (I took one point off because you can't romance Gobbet)

reviewText:
Shadowrun: Hong Kong the third entry in the Shadowrun Returns franchise, following up on Shadowrun Returns and Shadowrun Returns: Dragonfall. This title is stand alone and playing the previous games is not mandatory to enjoy it, though you will miss out on a few nods here and there. Players control a team of Shadowrunners - mercenaries performing illegal operations for anyone with enough cash - while trying to work through a complex and vibrant plot of family secrets, mystical danger and corporate espionage.

Fans of earlier entries in the series will find that the mechanics have received some much-needed polish: my own experiences noted hefty changes to the Shaman class and to decking in the Matrix. Combat feels mostly tight, and you seldom feel you have wasted your karma, no matter which skills you have invested in.

I don't want to discuss the plot very much, because that's the main reason why you play titles like this, but I consider it on par with Dragonfall's in terms of quality. I cannot gush enough about the characters - no other series comes to mind that has managed to produce so many well thought out and well-written individuals, both on the team and off. If background information  and dialogue are big sticking points for you, then the game will not disappoint.

The only real negative I can discuss for SR:HK is the frequency of bugs. Every patch fixes things further, but there's nothing more frustrating than eating a load of damage because the game decided to lag out and skip half of your characters' turns in combat. I see a big dip in the number of issues that people are having since release day, but in a game that can be sometimes unforgiving, it just takes that happening once to leave you raging.

Ultimately, I would say this is worth it at full price and a must buy if you can snag it during a seasonal sale. Play time for me clocked around 30 hours for one run through with full completion, so I absolutely got my money's worth. Highly suggested for fans of strategy RPGs and excellent writing.

Having completed S:HK, I figure it was time to share Wot I Think about the game.

Game Length: About 12-13 hours and that included every mission I found but one.

It's easy to start this review. If someone liked the other games, they'll probably like this one. It has the same music style. Same art style. Same character leveling. Same skills. Same gameplay. It's basically the same game with a different story. As such, you could easily call this a new DLC adventure of Shadowrun: Dragonfall. So that's the basic recommendation - if you like the others, you should buy this. I did and I enjoyed it. Somewhat...and that's the kicker.

I'm not nearly as happy with this game as with the past games and I know why:

Empty
Derivative
Disjointed
PCs and NPCs
The Matrix


Empty: Tthe maps appear to be bigger. They're lovingly created and visually appealing. I've always loved the art style in this game. But they often feel empty and underutilized. There's very little compelling content that rewards you from straying the least little bit from your course. There are no quests off the beaten path, no interesing rabbit holes to fall down into.

Derivative: The game and story are entirely derivative. It's impossible to play this and not feel like you've played this before multiple times. FAs I said above, it's bascially the same game with a different story. But even the story isn't all that different - you run into a problem, watch someone get killed in the opening adventure, end up working for a broker who feeds you jobs, interact with the same computer terminal, do the jobs and finally advance the story. It's Dragonfall's premise all over again.

Disjointed: Unlike Dragonfall, where the above quest-system made great sense, this is a wasted opporutunity. Instead of nibbling around the main plot line by facing some weird incidents to build tension towards the final climax, you're off on entirely unrelated missions that aren't all that interesting. As I said, this made sense in Dragonfall because you had to make bank to advance the plot line. Here, they're just something to do for a while. So the plot is very disjointed. You go to the Walled City early and then never again until the final battle. The plot about dear old Dad isn't all that interesting and doesn't even make all that much sen sense. The denouement attempts to explain it, but by that time it's far too late. Missing Dad is just a plot device and an illogical one at that. So the missions and the mission structure are a massively WASTED opportunity to bring a more cohesive adventure to the story.

PCs and NPCs: The ghoul was a nice touch. The others...forgettable. Your brother? Annoying. The NPCs here really took a step back and weren't all that interesting. And there's still no control of their leveling. The specials are an attempt to give you some control, but frankly they're not all that great or that useful. I'd much rather have the ability to shape my party the way I saw fit. And it didn't help that my character - a sword-wielding street Samurai - happened to be the same exact type as the only interesting NPC out there. As for the player character, I didn't see how any of their responses would have changed the story much if at all (with the exception of keeping the vampire girl alive). In short, the PC doesn't matter except to be the wall that everything bounces off. When will HBS learn that the best stories often have the PC to go through a journey and not just move through the story without impactng it?

The Matrix: The gameplay in the matrix is still incredibly annoying. Even more this time with their Simon Says" hacking game and the overall detection meter. It's not fun and it's not interesting at all. It sucks. I finally started using the deathray cheat to make it through these parts. And at times you simply can not avoid it. It's terrible and HBS should entirely dump the systems and start over there because they're making it worse

Shadowrun: Hong Kong

They've done it again ladies and gents.

reviewText:
Shadowrun: Hong Kong is an excellent addition to the Shadowrun series that will not disappoint fans of the previous games  As most have probably assumed, the setting is the legendary city of Hong Kong and the story is kicked off with a series of events that lead to you and your brother becoming shadowrunners for a powerful Yellow Lotus crime boss.  There are several twists and turns that lead to a climactic ending as well as the usual side missions that are available if you choose to complete them.  The additional missions are not directly tied to the story, though, I would still recommend them as I had a blast playing them.  The personal story missions of your teammates, as always, were a highlight of the game as well.

Combat, for the most part, is how you would remember it from Dragonfall.  You choose four of your team for each mission which plays as an isometric RPG until you enter combat where it becomes a turn-based tactical game similar in many way to XCOM: Enemy Unknown.  Cover, action points, RNG-based accuracy, and abilities galore are all present here.  Decking in, however, has been upgraded.  Now instead of fight after fight you have the opportunity to stealth through most of the areas and avoid cyber combat if you so choose.  There are a few mandatory cyber battles that are unavoidable, however.

Dialogue in the game has been improved further as well.  Most noticably are the options based on your character's skills.  High strength?  Bash down that barrier or intimidate that thug with your bulging biceps.  Talented rigger?  Those drones that were previously set to activate hostile to you will now start firing on their operators as soon as they power on.  Impressive charisma?  The new executive will see the wisdom in your suggestion to hand over his passcode to the company intranet so that you (a maintenance worker, of course!) can fix a few errors that would cause management to be very upset with the next quarterly report that they receive.

All in all, a great tactical RPG with a story that kept me entertained throughout.  Be aware, however, that this game has a ton of dialogue in it.  If you're not a fan of reading it may turn you away from the game but if you're a lorehead and want to learn more about the Shadowrun universe it will definitely hold your attention.  I recommend the game to Shadowrun fans of all kinds and those who enjoy deep RPGs with an assortment of interesting characters and locations.

reviewText:
I never understood why it seems so hard to make a decent cyberpunk(ish) game. Shadowrun Returns is on the right track, definitively.

As a longtime player of the P&P-RPG Shadowrun, I thoroughly enjoyed this latest installment. Of course it has its problems, but on the whole I can recommend it to anyone not too hooked up on graphics or other shinies. This game further improves on the original Shadowrun Returns and its first official successor Dragonfall.

As with Dragonfall in regards to vanilla Shadowrun Returns, Hong Kong makes further small improvements on the gameplay and mechanics that I personally welcomed as good additions (for example having a Mass Effect 3 like skilltree for your team to give them certain powers as they progress in level).

PROs:
- Story is very good. In fact I'd say it is the best so far.
- Very well written dialogue with interesting special options if you developed the right skills, providing a satisfying RPG experience
- Atmosphere is very immersive, the texts (yes reading! see below under CONs) are painting a pretty good picture of the Awakened Hong Kong in all its corrupt glory and misery
- Quite a few points in the storyline where you have to make decisions influencing your later game in small ways.
- Interesting characters as fellow runners with good backstories and their own missions. I never used hired help.

CONS:
- A LOT of reading involved (didn't mind that myself, but it is not for everybody). Nothing (exept pro- and epilouge) is voiced over
- Limited possibility to equip your fellow runners. They mostly have their own weapons and equipment and don't need stuff you might want to give them. That is on one hand fine, as you won't earn enough money to equip everybody with the best stuff anyway but it takes away some of the fun (for me at least).
- Occasionally ATROCIOUS AI in regards to neutral NPCs in combat (had a physical adept - supposedly helping me - run circles for the whole fight while his mates and my team died)
- Same for the odd enemy AI (not to spoil anything but the final boss hardly even attacked my team during the whole fight).
- The hacking minigames during matrix runs are an interesting feature but it gets old very quick.
- the odd bug (had bought equipment like spells disappear between runs occasionally)

While on first glance the number of cons does seem to outweigh the number of pros a little, this is mitigated by the fact that the cons are - to me - minor annoyances as I play primarily for the story experience not the gaming challenge.

If you played and liked Shadowrun Returns and Shadowrun Returns Dragonfall, Hong Kong is a must have in my opinion. If you didn't, you might want to check them out first, as Hong Kong features improvements over them that you will probably miss when going back and the lack of which might lessen your enjoyment of the earlier installments (especially of the original).

reviewText:
Harebrained Schemes have improved the sequels immensely since the first game, overall what you have here is a really solid Shadowrun story.

Pros:
- Good plot/writing (including most side quests)
- Characters that you get curious about, even those not on your team (I frequently checked in with the Club 88 among other places)
- Hacking is implemented in a way that makes being a decker interesting for the long run (hacking in itself is akin to combat)
- Lots of combat styles to pick between (Want to be a hacker with a flair for magic? Sure! Want to be an â™¥â™¥â™¥ kicking monk with cybernetics? Go ahead! Be creative, have fun)
- Not all situations have to end with blood splattered on the wall, often you can use other methods to solve problems
- Some characters from previous games show up
- Free DLC
- Good Workshop community - they make good stories / changes to the game worth checking out

Cons:
- AI can be questionable at times (instead of attacking, they'll move back & forth)
- Re-loading takes WAY too long, between loading times I'm reading several paragraphs of a novel, news story etc)
- Bugs which won't be fixed (Conjecture on my part, but seeing as they still haven't fixed bugs that was reported almost a year ago...); see next point
- Choices can sometimes carry over to older saves (Example: I killed someone for blabbing, wanted to try a new approach but after loading my older save, the person was already dead and replaced)
- Talking to people can be a clumsy process if you need to do it repeatedly
- Memory leaks (Longer you run game, slower it gets - the more saves the slower it loads them)
- At least one puzzle is nigh-impossible to solve without googling despite the hint(s)

Not really cons but:

- Being unable to use hacking skills to disrupt enemies with cybernetic augmentations, smartlinked weapons etc
- Sometimes the RNG is ridiculous, missing twice in a row with 91% chance of hit? Yeaaahhhh....


A rough gem that could do with some more polishing, worth checking out - especially when the game is on sale.
