reviewText:
Great story, dialogs and characters, and it's the only reason i didn't drop shadowrun after the first game, as everything else in the series continues to stay on barely above the average level, but let me cover it step by step.

Graphics: It's not very good looking, but it's subjective as i don't like isometric view in general, especially when it's 2.5D, with everything being 2D except characters and enemies, this also leads to annoying situations and misclicks so you have to zoom in often to be precise, which is a pain.
There is low level of details overal and few interactions with the game world.

Story, characters and longetivity:Lasts for about 10 hours, maybe a bit more. Don't look at my time stats, as i am pretty lazy and left the game minimized often for a whole week.
Story-wise, it's pretty great. The script isn't surprising but offers lots of different runs (missions) and jokes are quite good as well =)
Your crew and other NPC's have their stories that you need to unfold along the main quest, and every time you talk to crew member or surgeon in the city you learn something new about them, it keeps you going and digging into their past.  You feel very close to them when you finally learn their secrets.
Game is worth buying only thanks to writing.
Engine and bugs: Game engine sucks. Big time.
Optimization is okay, but everything else is a mess.
I got quest bugs(even after patch 3.0.7), game icons shift from their places after some time, I have to click several times on the same â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ icon over and over to finally trigger it, many animations should be at least 2x times faster.
There should be at least combat speed adjustment in the settings. Seriously, third game and i still have to wait through long boring fights with enemies that suck, just because there isn't simple combat speed setting and animations take ages to play.
Music plays when the game is minimized.
Developer doesn't seem to care about feedback because those are same technical mistakes as in previous games.
Sound: Soundtrack is good(though i'd love to have more tracks) and complements the overall mood of the game. There are not many ambient sounds and sometimes game feels a bit empty but sound is good overall.

Overall: So i'd say game rightfully deserves 7/10 for it's story and writing but there are many annoyances that could keep you from enjoying it.

reviewText:
Shadowrun: Hong Kong is twice as big as the previous two games, but that doesn't make it lose focus. The missions are more varied and have a unique narrative and mechanical twists to them. Your crew of runners are the most varied bunch so far, although unlike Dragonfall, they're almost always on your side with no sense of winning anyone over (which makes sense in HK's story).

The only two issues I've had so far have been the redesigned Matrix (which is real-time stealth until you trigger an encounter). It's clunky, frustrating and bugs out if you enter the Matrix in the middle of real-world combat. The other issue are the bugs themselves, and rather than gamebreaking ones, there are many moments where dialog seems to bug out, is lost, or doesn't properly advance (not for the main missions, rather side stuff like NPCs in your hub or optional dialogs in missions).

Shadowrun still manages to pull off the closest atmosphere to a pen-and-paper RPG among modern games, setting the stage so well and not having its lower production values get in the way. And the devs still manage to deliver a very satisfying ending each time, even after three games.

reviewText:
While I still have a few issues with the game on a mechanical level (honestly calling them issues is overblowing it), this incarnation of the franchise is quite possibly one of the best cRPGs I've played in a long while.  Certainly the best of anything current (though it will never live up to Planescape: Torment of course, nothing can).

The closest thing I'd call to a complaint (and it really isn't a complaint, more of an observation) is that I suspect it will be perceived as being a little too verbose.  Certainly the game is FAR richer for it, but I suspect the average player will get rather impatient with the almost extravagant florid descriptions and dialogues, which concerns me in that I want more games to take this level of textual effort over something like eye-candy, but reality is unlikely to reward cerebral quality these days.  As far as I'm concerned, this is a good thing, I just worry that it will work against the game's success.

At any rate, this game is a more than worthy successor/expansion from HBS, despite a few niggling bugs and more than a few proofing/editing errors.  I'd have liked to see a little more character interplay (especially among the secondary and tertiary characters), but what's in the game is more than appetizing.  There were also a few missed opportunities, but I suspect deadlines played a factor into a few of those.

Definitely worth the asking price, especially if you like cRPGs and doubly so if you like the IP.  I just wish there was more on the way, but I suspect we'll need to wait on the community for the next couple of years, at least until HBS is done with Battletech.

Buy it fruitcake.

reviewText:
Shadowrun Hong Kong provides a hefty amount of tactical combat, cRPG mechanics and a decent dash of choice & consequence, fixed around a pretty good story. There is not that many additions for those who've already played Shadowun: Dragonfall, but the developers seem to have improved the overall gameplay nonetheless.

> Combat is straight-forward but more dynamic than SR: DF due to more abrupt means of enemy elimination, such as Duncan's Subdue, allow for much speedier resolution.
> NPCs are well fleshed-out and impressive in their backgroudn stories. The game's take on the Walled City is quite interesting and deserves praise.
> The game features some new character art (presumably via Kickstarter backer portraits), which are quite an upgrade on the diversified stock portraits from SR:R and SR: DF.
> Martix system seems to be overhauled (as per KS stretch goals) but it's a moot point whether it's better or worse. Aesthetically it's much better than in previous games but gameplay-wise it's often frustrating to get +20 Trace (increasing the alarm status) per round.
> Game length is acceptable, considering the side missions et cetera. Harebrained will also release an extra campaign to resolve some loose ends from the original campaign. Even without that, as per previous SR games, alternative means of gameplay are visible to the player (i.e. if you need a particular skill for a dialogue but don't have it, it'll often -not always- appear to you, so you may try that out during you next play-through).
> The soundtrack is very well executed and fits the game's theme extremely well.

Overall, the game is definitely worth every penny paid for it. There is also the level editor in the pipeline so further gametime can be obtained via Steam Workshop.

reviewText:
Although Shadowrun: Hong Kong was initially conceived of as a stand-alone game, it still builds upon the design of Shadowrun: Dragonfall.  Most praise and criticism in my review of that game applies to this game as well.  This review will primarily focus on the changes.

First, the positive aspects of the designâ€¦

This is perhaps the most non-linear game in the series.  At any given point there are usually 3 or more missions you can choose from.

I particularly enjoyed Ractor's and Gaichu's backstories.

Gaichu's stance mechanic is great!  It's a pity a similar system wasn't used to make all melee more tactical.

The new cyberware is really nice, and now has sane essence costs, so you can actually make use of it!

A few new spells have been added.  However, the spell list is bloated with â€˜moar harderâ€™ versions of spells, when statistics should have been used for that, making it appear as though there is more variety than there really is.

You can now click the holster button to ambush enemies.  Ambush isn't just for enemies any more!

Now for the negative aspectsâ€¦

As with Shadowrun: Dragonfall, the player may be waylaid mid to late game by having chosen to build a main character with a redundant class.  If you don't want to be redundant in this game, you need to play a mage.

Now armor only differs in its protection rating and aesthetics.  In previous games they also affected other statistics, requiring you to make trade-offs.

All companions have most of their slots locked, so you can customize your team far less than in previous games.

Completing a mission feels unrewarding due to being paid so little it feels like an insult.  Most of the time the payout is less than half of a single level-appropriate piece of equipment!

The music is not as good as in the previous games.  It's not grating, it's just so ambient you are unlikely to notice or remember it.

The walking sound effect seems to have been changed to someone stomping as hard as they can, as if they're trying to get caught, and you only ever hear one set of footsteps, even when your whole party is moving.

Now for the big one; the matrix changes.  We've been asking for a matrix that felt more unique; different from meatspace.  Apparently we need to learn to word our wishes more carefullyâ€¦

Remember that awful real-time stealth segment in Shadowrun: Dragonfall's Bloodlines quest that almost everyone complained about?  Apparently Hairbrained Schemes decided they could improve their game by making all matrix levels work like that, and requiring you to use the matrix on almost every mission.  Oh, and there's another meatspace mission (Whistleblower) like that in this game, in case you couldn't get enough.  But it's okay, because we gave them proper vision cones this time!  That might make it too easy though, so lets fill each screen with about 10 enemies, all frantically patrolling in tight circles, and hide most of it behind walls and fog of war so you can't anticipate the movement.

They also decided to add timed puzzles (in the same sense that the 100-yard dash is a puzzle) to barriers and nodes in the matrix.

If they wanted to involve stealth in a turn-based game, and improve the matrix, they should have looked to Invisible Inc. and the 3rd edition Shadowrun tabletop role-playing game rules for ideas.

Hairbrained Schemes, PLEASE revert these matrix changes in your next game.

I'm not sure whether to recommend or not.. I mean, this review will largely be negative, but ultimate it isn't a bad game, and might be worth a play...

I already own and have played Shadowrun Returns and Shadowrun Dragonfall. I enjoyed both of those games at the time and reviewed them very positively, especially Dragonfall which felt like a fully realized Shadowrun Returns.

So what do I have to complain about? Is Shadowrun: Hong Kong somehow worse than Dragonfall? No, in some ways it is an improvement. I think my problem with the game is, it is just more of the same; Hong Kong feels like just Dragonfall but with names and setting changed. Same sorta contrived story, same sorta hamfisted characters, etc.

I can get past all that, but maybe the big difference is that, in Dragonfall I felt invested; the opening where an old friend/partner dies tragically, you are left to pick up the pieces with interesting characters dealing with her loss. In Dragonfall I *wanted* to find out what happens, I wanted revenge, I wanted to develop my relationships with my team and city. But in Hong Kong, I can't be arsed to care about this father-figure, I can barely be arsed about the team or conflicts facing them, it just feels so bland and boring to me.

I want to say that the combat also feels bland and uninteresting, but it seems much like the same combat in Dragonfall which I recall reviewing as better than Xcom's combat. Did something change that I just can't put my finger on? Or maybe my tastes have shifted between Dragonfall and Hong Kong.

Ultimately, this game just feels like a cookie-cutter of Dragonfall, only with a story I can't seem to be interested in. It largely feels like the same game, when I guess I might have wanted more out of it.

If you like the Shadowrun series (boardgame or videogame) you will probably enjoy this game, but not as much as I would hope.

TL;DR: Play Shadowrun: Dragonfall" instead. If you've already played Dragonfall

reviewText:
WARNING: This review may have spoilers, please read at your own risk.

Welp time for another Shadowrun game. And this one I pre-ordered and have been waiting awhile to play, so here goes.

STORY: This is probably the 2nd best story out of The Shadowrun Returns Series (Next to the 1st being the best and Dragonfall being my least favorite imo.)

You start off in Hong Kong, getting a message from your foster father to head back so you can help him with an issue hes having involving some big megacorporations (which by the way practically own Hong Kong) you are not only dragged into the mystery but so is your foster brother and two other shadowrunners. Its up to you to figure out what happened to your foster father and maybe become a shadowrunner during the crossfire?

The story is really REALLY great, I just absolutly loved the characters, even though they have no voices, just reading their lines just gives me an impact.

Also there was really creepy final boss I encountered in the game, and it got more creepier by the 2/3rd time I faced it.

There are multiple endings to this game, and the one I chosen was really good, but I know it wasn't the only ending so more replayability there. 9.5/10

GRAPHICS: I want to say that the graphics here are mostly still the same, though I will admit the characters have been improved upon slightly a bit.

Still Its nice to see some areas that are inspired by real life Hong Kong and other cool art pieces and characters. 8.5/10

GAMEPLAY: Again everything is mostly the same, but the combat UI is changed a bit to resemble the 1st ones unlike dragonfall.

The upgrading is changed slightly as you can now use cybernetics along with it like upgrading to lvl 1 cyberarm and further and further by your body lvling system.

The team lvling is still the same but its still good.

Everything is slightly the same but slightly different too but its still awesome. 9/10

VERDICT: Shadowrun: Hong Kong is a great 3rd installment in the Shadowrun Returns Series.

It doesn't really changed much, but its still a great turn-based RPG, has a great story, and lots of replayability. 9/10

TLDR:

PROS: Great story, good turn-based combat, lots of replayability, slightly improved character models.
CONS: Really didn't changed much combat UI wise

Buying Price: Full-price

reviewText:
Hello folks,

As you can see by the hours played I am not basing this on only a little time in the game. I also backed Shadowrun Returns and had about two hundred of hours on that game, beating it quite a few times. I have about one hundred hours on Dragonfall. I have played every video game based on shadowrun, including the FPS that other than races had little to do with Shadowrun. I picked up my first first edition books in June of 1990 from a little bookstore across from the docks in Port Angeles Washington. I own all the books, both role-playing materials and novels. I have run more games than I care to count and have been a fore-runner in the cries for more video games based on Shadowrun.

The first thing I am going to do is give rave reviews on the puzzle system for decking. It is interesting, provocative, and makes me feel as if I am achieving more than the original games afforded. I am looking forward to the evolution where a character can choose from a set of their own preferred visuals for the matrix, but I understand that incorporating those concepts are a long way off.

I also like the new system where I can initiate combat if I choose too. It incorporates stealth elements to a video game based on a role-playing game where the use of stealth is essential to succeed. This is very challenging for a Turn-Based Strategy (TBS) game to reproduce.

I like the TBS game style of play. I always have and always will. The character creation system is not far from the system in the game. I have concerns about the lack of cost correlation between race and points at creation. In the roleplaying game, you place points into the attributes before the racial changes take effect. It makes it worth it starting out to have an elf for the racial increases to quickness and charisma. I can tear apart any game based on a roleplaying game for the lack of ability to incorporate elements from the RPG correctly. It does not really degrade from the enjoyability of the game.

This game is fun with a great storyline. The amount of the information is large and if you are not a fan of reading text in the game you are going to have problems with this game. If you like a world rich with story and history, this game will make you very happy.

There are issues with glitches, but I only ran across one during my play through where it did not acknowledge my charisma correctly to afford me an opportunity in the tower. Glitches happen at release and take the time to resolve.

Good Hunting chummers!

reviewText:
The *BEST* Shadowrun game to date! Finally, just about everything I wanted Dragonfall and Returns to be: Hong Kong is. Dragonfall was a vast improvement over Returns: much better storyline - characters you can actually converse with - the ability to level-up your squad as you see fit. Hong Kong keeps those improvements, and then even more.

+ Longer, more fleshed out storyline. Far more conversation options and a squad to actually care about (Gobbet <3). Feels like a vastly more immersive experience! Finally feels like there are some actual decisions to make in conversations with your squad, on missions, and even the shopkeepers around Hoei.

+ Updated UI and the ability to not just send every pickup to stash: can finally swap items around and send them to a squadmate if you're inventory is full. Very helpful feature that's finally been added. Also, you can now enter combat mode before (some) fights break out, allowing you to properly position your squad instead of finding yourself clumped up for grenades/mage AOE before a fight even starts.

+ Armor no longer gives stats (aside from armor rating) = You can buy anything to customize your looks rather than being locked into one particular armor set based on your class. Very cool! Can be a shaman and look like a decker if you really want. Personally, I just go with the ninja outfits from Shen... but that's just me.

+ Classes finally feel more balanced. My main gripe of previous Shadowrun games was how much better any gunslinger felt over any other class. But more cyberware (!!!) and cyberweapons = Melee classes feel far more competent in Hong Kong than they ever have. And Mages finally get a VERY useful spell: Chain Lightning! IMO, just what mages needed to really feel powerful. A cheap (AP-wise), multi-target spell that deals good damage and AP damage, and isn't limited by a 2x2 square AOE.

-/+ Updated Decking system: Still not sure about this. In some ways I enjoy it: it's different. But it's a little hampered by being a bit unresponsive and awkward at times. But at least it's no longer awkward battles in the matrix with Blitz..

- Still some bugs present. Nothing game breaking, but some minor lingering issues that can be a bit bothersome. Sometimes can't interact with NPCs/items until I spam ALT. Once got stuck in a conversation with Duncan while simultaneously picking up an item during a mission and had to restart because I couldn't get out of it. Matrix sometimes feels unresponsive and awkward. But all-in-all: minor and doesn't affect my experience too much.

** On the whole, absolutely love this game! It's been really fun playing all the Shadowrun games and seeing the progression. Returns was short, with a simplistic storyline and no real squad to care about. Dragonfall improved quite a bit on all fronts, and now Hong Kong improves on everything Dragonfall did over Returns: making for a much more fulfilling experience into the Shadowrun universe.

Would highly recommend Shadowrun: Hong Kong - 9.5/10 game for sure! And an absolute must play if you're super into the Shadowrun series and have played the previous games.

reviewText:
Game type -- Shadowrun's unusual setting (cyberpunk mixed with fantasy elements; entirely possible for a cybernetically augmented pistolero to be magically hasted by a shaman while dealing with hostile abominations from the astral plane) set in Hong Kong rather than Seattle.   Stats-based RPG, heavy emphasis on small-squad tactical combat, fixed-perspective isometric view, mostly-linear campaigns w/ a small number of non-random side missions available.  If you've played either previous Shadowrun Returns game, this will be pretty familiar territory for the most part.  Strictly single-player.


Played through main and bonus campaign w/ an elf pistol-specialist street samurai with a fair side investment in charisma; typically had a rifle samurai, a decker, and a shaman in the party.  Don't expect to build a character who's good at everything and wielding the best of everything as resources can be fairly tight and this isn't a game with repeatable quests to farm (in the included campaigns, anyway; UGC can be as generous as the author feels like).


Positives incl. -- true to setting (for a CRPG, anyway; can't really replicate a human GM's ability to incorporate and handle all the wacky ideas a player might have, so your options will always be limited), combines some tongue-in-cheek humor with a cast of suitably shady characters, revamped Matrix system (but can rely on a particular NPC decker if you don't build your player character as one) favoring stealth and timing, often multiple approaches to getting to the next stage.   Charisma isn't a complete dump stat, and knowledge of the right etiquettes can give you opportunities.  Still, do not expect to be able to avoid all bloodshed by any means; you will need to kill, and frequently.


Mixed -- There's Workshop support, but there seems to have been less modding done for it (notably few story UGC) than for Dragonfall or first SR iteration.  Combat mechanics are improved over original SR/Dragonfall with cover and positioning matter more, but it's still fairly light -- if you want a game where you can shoot an enemy on the floor above you through the ceilng or collapse a staircase with explosives, this isn't it.  You won't have to spend twenty minutes per turn meticulously planning, however, as if it's some hardcore complex military simulation with a gazillion things that you *could* do where many of 'em will eventually doom you from wasting too much time or too many resources or getting too many limbs removed from IEDs you didn't spot.   Complexity is a matter of taste.


Negatives -- pretty short game (main and extended don't take all THAT long to play through once), story isn't anything to write home about over the long run.   One can also argue that it's not terribly innovative over Dragonfall, aside from the revamped Matrix sections.  There's also one bit of cyberware that's fairly sketchy, because once it shows up (and it shows up pretty frequently in the bonus campaign) grenades are drastically less useful, and that removes options from the board.

reviewText:
I will disclaimer this review by saying I feel the need to give it two very distinct recommendations for two very distinct audiences.  For hard-core cyberpunk fans (such as myself) I give this game a very strong recommendation.  For the general public or fans of the RPG genre I give it an extremely tepid recommendation.

There is something different about this game compared to its predecessors other than the setting.  There is perhaps no other way to explain it other than to say something about it feels awkward.

Let's start by reviewing the elements of the game which are beyond reproach.  First is the music.  Like the previous games it is enjoyable yet unintrusive.  It reminds me strongly of the Mass Effect soundtrack.  This iteration, in a nod to the setting, has a subtle Asian tone which works well overall.

The art is similarly excellent, at least for the genre and style of game.  Like the music, the scenery was given subtle Asian flair and is overall very interesting.  Almost too interesting.  It makes you wish there was another zoom level to really allow you to sort of immerse yourself in the ambiance created by the art and music.  This almost-but-not-quite is a feeling I will come back to after addressing what is the best (and also the worst element of the game).

The writing.  Like in Dragonfall, the writing of Lead Writer Andrew McIntosh is thoughtful, gritty, and engaging.  I would buy cyberpunk novels from this gentleman.  At the beginning of the game you pick a sort of profession specialty which allows you to unlock certain dialogue options.  You can always see these options if not necessarily utilize them.  These options show you that the writers have dug down deep and wrote for these characters as if they themselves were playing a role-playing game.  Some of the dialogue, especially with Gaichu and Racter seem as if they were carefully researched.  This was obviously a labor of love.

Unfortunately, I am going to suggest that the writing is actually TOO good.  Unlike the music, which is nice but sort of disappears into the background, you cannot ignore the writing.  If you ignore the writing, you ignore what is arguably the best aspect of the game.  While it is possible to complete the game without engaging in much superflous dialogue the end result is that you end of up playing a long series of combat events.  Tedious and boring combat events.

The combat is, and has been, the Achilles heel of this franchise.  The turn based system is overly simplistic (most likely so they can sell it by the boatload to casual tablet players) and not well balanced.  A well equipped group can simply run-and-gun through nearly every level.  The magic-using classes are mere novelties.  Unlike in many fantasy games,  the magic is simply not worth it in comparison to a trusty AK-47.  The Matrix was revamped as a stretch goal during the crowfunding and is much improved compared to its former iteration.  To HBS credit, the Matrix is now much more engaging and gives the player a sense of urgency  and danger commensurate with how the deckers actual speak of their time out of meat-space.  Ultimately, though it still feels like a mini-game rather than an integral part of daily cyberpunk life.  It was great of HBS to make the Matrix not suck but I feel they should have integrated it into other aspects of the game.  Perhaps place data access points in non-combat areas.  Have areas where deckers congretate in cyber-space.  Allow decking to unlock dialogue options or perhaps access to hidden areas or quests.  It is actually somewhat frustrating that the Matrix is much improved because it highlights its continued poor implementation and utilization within the game

So here is what ends up happening.  You end up engaging all of the extra dialogue choices because you want to extract more life out of the video game, but there is something different in the dialogue department from the previous games.   As the setting of this game is a fantastic imagining of China perhaps you will forgive me when I bestow the following moniker to the dialogue:  Shadowrun: The Great Wall of Text.

Thats right, the dialogue goes on and on and on.  Don't get me wrong, I love it.  It devour it.  Unfortunately, it is simply not comfortable to stare at a computer reading text for hours upon hours at a time.  I do not exagerate by saying there is perhaps 1.5 hours of optional dialogue for every 30 mins or so of combat.  It feels less like you are playing a game and more like you are reading a book with music and pretty (if zoomed out) graphics.  But the alternative, as mentioned before, is an unsatisfying series of tedious combat events.

Here is where I think the game went wrong.  Not the writers, they should be awarded, commended, promoted.  The problem here is one of balance and the blame lies squarely with the game directors.  I think the directors realized the problem with the game:  it has no life to it.  Strip away the writing and it feels like an empty neon-lit diner at midnight.  Rather than attempting to imagine ways to inject life into the game they simply increased the volume of text.  Unfortunately, they leaned on the text to the breaking point and what was once a game became a book.

I will not though, offer empty criticism without suggestions.  I think what the directors needed were scripted events thoughout the game.  Don't have people stand there in town waiting for you to come by and give them complementary psychological counseling sessions.  Have people mug someone as you walk by.  Have something happen if you loiter in the wrong place at the wrong time.  Some of the third-party mods created by the community for Dragonfall feel like they have more life than this game because of their scripting.  I have not myself delved into the scripting tools and ultimately the limitation of how much scripting can contribue to the immersion and depth of the game may be hard-coded and limited by the engine itself.  If this is the case, my advice to Harebrained Schemes is if they wish to make another game in this series, either revert to more tight productions like Returns and Dragonfall, or, create an entirely new engine for the next iteration allowing players to finally sink in and completely enjoy the intelligent and beautiful world they have created.

This seems like an awful lot of criticism for a game I've given a thumbs up to but I hope I help potential purchasers of this game go into their purchase eyes wide open.  I'd also love it somebody at HBS stumbled upon this and took some of this message to heart.  I, and thousands of others love what you do, but you have to potential to turn something alright into a future classic with a bit of work.

reviewText:
Shadowrun: Hong Kong is a continuation of the Harebrained Schemes series of stories taking place in the Shadowrun universe. The predecessor, Dragonfall (Directors' Cut) was a gem in RPG-gaming and improved upon the original success. In spite of being a rather small developer, HBS has had some success in this series of games which is the reason why this is their third kickstarted game.

Shadowrun: Hong Kong starts on a story arc which is separate from the previous games, so you do not have to play those to get into this series, however if you are unfamiliar with this games series there are some precautions you should have to consider:

1. The game has a lot of text in it
2. While story-driven, there is no way to play it without entering many firefights and combat situations
3. It has bugs

The first point is definitely something to consider for the modern gamer, almost all dialogue is written text without speech, just like in the old days of gaming. The advantage of course being that there are a lot of dialogue and interaction in the game which immerses you, with well-written sequences that create a lot of atmosphere. If you like to read, then this will be a pleasant experience - but if you don't have the patience for it, the game will be frustrating.

The second point is rather frustrating for a role player, while you will meet characters that are prone to combat that will aid you, there simply is no easy way to say this: You will have to fight. If you don't like combat, Shadowrun isn't for you. Shadowrunners are essentially mercenaries hired to do mostly combat runs. You will be able to gain advantages through dialogue and hacking and such, but there is no way to complete this game without long tactical combat scenes.

And to the last, third, and possibly MOST aggravating issue with the game, its bugs. HBS has made three games and all of them suffer from similar bugs. Some of which completely block you off from doing certain areas because there is a problem with some trigger, or because of a general combat won't end"-bug. On top of this there are glitches where certain weapons won't show

reviewText: Outstanding overall experience.  I played the game immediately on its release, and it still had a few very minor issues (for instance, the wrong character's portrait being displayed during a conversation involving multiple people, or the player's name failing to display, or a dead NPC available for selection for one fight, or an object changing name- betraying loose ends not quite tied up).  But it was bug free and smooth gameplay for me, even smoother than the previous two games:  Shadowrun Returns and Shadowrun: Dragonfall.  As in the two previous games, the atmosphere was convincing, immersive, creepy, and exciting.  And the storyline presented choices that felt important, distinctly different, and complex.  Finally, the dialogue was entertaining and well-written.  This is an old-school game; it would have been cutting edge in 2005 and run of the mill in 2010 for graphics and mechanics. reviewText:
I am now several hours into Shadowrun: Hong Kong. At this point I feel I can confidently say that if you enjoyed the previous two entries, you will indeed love returning to this world.

Hong Kong offers an even murkier criminal underworld to navigate. As the story progresses you continually feel off balance. There is really only one party member you know you can trust, but they don't know if the same can be said for you. The story so far is on par with Dragonfall. The addition of the animatic cut scenes has been wonderful.

The core game has been tweaked in numerous areas: Character animation, models, environments (even more stunning), party gear trading, menus, magic, cyberware (looks to be hugely expanded and is now part of the skill trees), magic, elemental summon spirits are new and look amazing. Magic seems to have a larger place as well.

The great changes in the Director's Cut of Dragonfall are back. Party members can advance, achievements, and other concepts return.

These are just my early impressions.

reviewText:
It was a hot day in the summer vacation of 2014. I had broken up with my girlfriend and was looking for something to distract me. Because of the fact that I completed all my steam games I decided to check out my brother's games. There was 1 game that stood out. I believe it was the unique art that attracted me. My first ever experience with the Shadowrun series and fell in love with it. Since then I have bought and played all the Harebrained Shadowrun games (Shadowrun: Dragonfall directors cut and -Hong Kong). The reason why I love Shadowrun: Hong Kong in particular is because of the following:

- Amazing and unique storytelling

- Refined and solid combat system!
- Insane improvements from the last Shadowrun series!

The Shadowrun series keeps improving with each new release. If you like turned base strategy games like XCOM or Final Fantasy Tactics and want to be taken on an amazing and thrilling adventure.... then this is a MUST BUY.

reviewText:
Listen to what you know, instead of what you fear.Shadowrun: Hong Kong is another triumph from Harebrained Schemes, just perhaps not always as consistent as it's predecessor, Dragonfall. The new Matrix gameplay is fun and can be actually challenging, the characters are deep and realized as usual, and the final sequences where all the mysteries of the game start to get wrapped up are engaging.

Gameplay
If you've played a Shadowrun game before, you should know what to expect. Isometric point-and-click, turn-based combat, it's all pretty consistent, although throughout several points I found that the combat dragged on for some encounters far more than was necessary. Also, what's up with 70%+ to hit, I take three shots, all three miss. I understand that sometimes these things happen occasionally, but it's happened to me several times now. Normally I wouldn't nitpick on this, but because the previous two Shadowrun games didn't have this problem for me, I'm just a little disappointed with this. Other than that, the gameplay is still solid, with a new stealth+puzzle Matrix for deckers to jack into.

Story
You are invited to Hong Kong by your foster father, who wants to speak to you on a matter of utmost importance. However, both parties, you and your brother, Duncan, and your foster father, Raymond, are ambushed. The story unfolds from here as you discover that you have an entire city full of police out for your head, as well as strange dreams plaguing your sleep. The characters that accompany you on this journey are fleshed out and realized, and it's well worth talking to them between missions. However, if you hate reading, you will definitely miss out on the best parts of the game. It's not a game that you should always go with the 'attack' option. There is a lot of dialogue in this game, I like that, but be warned. The previous two games have less dialogue, which can be either good or bad.

Graphics, Atmosphere, Sound
Graphics are better than from last time, walking around Heoi (your home-base area) it is all very well done, with the graphics letting Harebrained Schemes get the most out of their environments and characters.
The atmosphere, is, as usual, impeccable. The game really draws you in, with detailed descriptions, awesome character portraits, interesting characters, usage of Chinese magics such as Qi and Feng Shui, and every environment feels just that *bit* different, and that's a good thing.
The sound is, again, still awesome. With gunfire, splatters of blood, exploding of heads with critical kills, and another epic soundtrack to accompany the game, it's up high on the scale of 'what's great about this game'. My favorite tracks are Bad Qi, DeckCon, The Walled City and Welcome to the Grid.

Ares!!!
This was easily the most frustrating moment in the game, and I'd like to outline it for anyone who is looking to buy this game. The mission called 'Misdirection' in which you have to steal from an Ares corporation and dodge Knight Errant Soldiers, has an infuriating bug if you take along Racter. You have to find a keycard to open a safe, and, on the lab level, be sure not to trip the Matrix alarms or bring in extra security *before* you reach the other Runners. If that happens, a dialogue will be missed and you won't receive the keycard. Unfortunately I didn't realize that the keycard couldn't be gained after fighting off extra security, so after completing that long battle I realized I had to start the entire mission again. You have been warned, there may be other glitches like this throughout the game.

Conclusion
A fun, detailed, immersive game that, although it has it's problems with gameplay and glitches, I'll still let it go because I found myself enjoying the game more than I was hating on it. If you are looking for one Shadowrun, buy Dragonfall, but if you are looking for another Shadowrun adventure, buy this, just acknowledge that there will be some problems. But, after all, what game doesn't?

reviewText:
Shadowrun Hong Kong is a third and last installment in Shadowrun returns series. And I am happy to say that in my mind it is almost as good as Dragonfall.

HK feels a bit weaker in story department, compared to Dragonfall - combining cyberpunk and fantasy cliches, it still however menages to deliver a well crafted and thoughtful story, with a diverse cast of interesting characters. It provides rich roleplaying options as well- both on mechanical and social levels of interaction with the game world.

Mechanically SR: HK shows a lot of improvement, in comparison to earlier games- while the combat is still slow and boring, most missions are designed in a way that allows you to minimize playtime spent fighting, if not outright skip most of the fights.

First hour or so feels a bit off-putting, with slow and downright boring exposition, but after that the story picks up and the fun begins.

So, to summarize :

Good story
Amazing characters
Nice writing
Boring fights
Slow first hour

The bonus campaign consists of 4 missions and holds up to the original game (if just barely), by providing a definitive ending to the story.

So, if you re into CRPGs, then do yourself a favor and play both SR: HK and Dragonfall- they are worth it. (Mostly, by being 1 of the best RPGs in recent years).

reviewText:
A suprisingly polished and lengthy 3rd game from Harebrained. (Lenghty if you are nuts and read every conversation)

Anyway much of the game technically is the same as the earlier entries, with the exception of non-lethal combat options, a game changing inclusion of cyber weapons, and several other combat paths to follow. I thought the city environments were in general fresh and compelling, SR Dragonfall by contrast had more beautiful environments overall, but it's home town was forgettable, it wasn't funny and amusing like Hong Kong. The focus Harebrained made on making the hometown lively and intriguing was evident and welcome.

I found early parts of the story to be a bit overly circumstantial, but it only serves to build up the plot and in the end it all wraps up rather nicely.

I'll point out a silly yet interesting minor detail in the overall polish the game has that I liked (and unfortunately the programmers and music artist might never hear it said), I love that the music now changes with the tide of the battle. It really helps establish the energy you should feel as an epic battle draws to a close.

Great game. $14 seems like a fair price for as much as I got out of it.

reviewText:
I loved SRR & SRR DF a mega ton. Heck, I even loved the SNES Shadowrun - which is probably my favorite, actually.

I haven't played the game super long at this point, but am definitely towards the early mid range in terms of completing content. But omg HK's story is soooo boring. Dialogue goes on WAY too long. I may have made a bad decision in terms of deciding on which missions to take on first, but there is no indication that it would be super chatty mission vs one that actually has fighting in it. In fact, I don't even know for sure if missions with less dialogue and more action (of some variety, e.g. fighting, matrix runs, puzzle/problem solving objectives...) even exist.

The backstory of the characters is not particularly interesting, either. The case of characters are cool in overall concept but are kinda bland overall. You're supposed to even care about your foster father's disappearance, but the game does not even get you to 'care' about this seemingly random person. So why would I care about finding him? It's just like that with most of the characters...there are moments of vulnerability but there's no real depth yet, no conflict among team members, or anything even close to what the last two iterations have done in terms of building strong, memorable and lovable personalities.

I like that they beefed up the weaponry, the Matrix changes, and carrying some upgrades from SRDF:DC with the character development.

I'm going to keep trying to push this on, but I sincerely hope it picks up or I will never finish this game. The story is extremely boring so far and I've played for 16+ hrs now. I would expected a better narrative than this.

reviewText:
The biggest change Hong Kong makes is to the Matrix system, the virtual world that deckers, Shadowrunâ€™s version of hackers, inhabit whenever they â€œjack in.â€ Decking is a common occurrence in these games to collect important data and shut off electronic dangers like turrets and cameras, but itâ€™s no longer just a different coating of paint on the combat system. A stealth system has now been implemented with the player having the ability to avoid detection from patrolling defense programs. Accessing nodes containing information now requires the decker to participate in a mini-game of sorts that involves playing a game of â€œsimon saysâ€ with the number pad, and matching an encrypted password that is easier to find depending on how well the decker performed in the previous mini-game. Failure in either the sneaking or the mini-game results in the decker being easier to track in the system, filling up the system trace meter. Getting discovered by a patrol forces you to fight it, and there are still defense programs in certain parts of the Matrix that will automatically attack you when entering an area. While the movement controls arenâ€™t particularly adequate to perform these stealth sections, it is still more than doable. Personally, Iâ€™m glad that the Matrix finally feels like its own component and not a re-hash of whatâ€™s already in the game. The additional hacking mini-games provide a much welcome change of pace, and at any rate, not going for stealth in the Matrix is still viable albeit more difficult. As it should be.

Aside from the Matrix redesign, not much has changed from Dragonfall, but thatâ€™s in no way a bad thing. Hong Kong provides a new campaign, a new setting, a new tileset for those interested in building their own campaigns with the built-in editor, and many incremental improvements to an already good game. Get it if you like Shadowrun, get it if you liked either of the last two games, get it if you like strategy or tactical rpgs.

It's a very solid game and the definitive Shadowrun experience for now. It's extra special for me because HK is my home. Every time I hear the MTR announcement the rush of pride that washes over me is quite priceless.

The core gameplay was never particularly great nor broken so I'm not suggesting it warranted an overhaul (Shadowrun was always clunky on pencil and paper anyway). I got a great package out of Kickstarter. And people who played neither Shadowrun nor Dragonfall will get a steal for their money. Well I do still think it's great value but the competition is great.

Hope it's not the end of the franchise though. Sure hope there are more cities to come!

reviewText:
Firstly, Shadowrun Hong Kong is 100% worth your time and money if you are a fan of the series or of cyberpunk in general.

(( Note: I write this review in response to naysayers citing DF's superiority to HK ))

With that out of the way...

I definitely think HK could've used a month or two's more worth of polish before launch to iron out all the bumps. Additionally, the overall pacing, length and cohesiveness of the story weren't nearly as strong as they could've been, and I think this is where the majority of complaints about the plot stem from. Not necessarily that the plot was bad per se, but that because of its awry execution, people were not able to fully appreciate it.

Nonetheless, there were still a number of noticeable improvements made to the actual gameplay and the music was quite stellar too, especially the main menu theme. All in all, I believe people are having a difficult time judging HK objectively due to their rose coloured lens tinting their experience with DF.

Personally, I find the biggest flaw with HK not to be how badly ( or well ) it sizes up with DF, but with how it seemingly passed up on a lot of easy/simple potential to improve the game.

Ultimately, if you consider their budget, the development time frame and the size of their team, you really can't fault them...as they need to cover their bases financially first and foremost, as a smaller independent studio.

HBS' hard work has paid off all the same, and their surging fame and popularity can be witnessed in how quickly their recent kickstarter gathered steam. I wish them all the best, for so long as they remain passionate and grounded in their work, a successful HBS means a successful Shadowrun series.

And from what we've seen and what we know, HBS is very much down to earth and in touch with their community.

Now, enough of this doom and gloom...GIVE ME THE NEXT SHADOWRUN ALREADY

Edit: Whatever discontent I had with the base SR:HK game have been completely dispelled by the Shadows of Hong Kong mini campaign, and transforms SR:HK into the clear better as compared to SR:DF.

This, here, is the complete Shadowrow experience, and the feels this game gives you by the end, all the personal and tough choices you will have to make throughout, the blurred lines of morality and the shades of grey, all of them resound with you. Though it saddens me to say goodbye to the game for now, it couldn't have ended more poignantly. This game has captured the essence of cyberpunk and made it its own.

I'll miss my team :')

Aside from the Matrix redesign, not much has changed from Dragonfall, but thatâ€™s in no way a bad thing. Hong Kong provides a new campaign, a new setting, a new tileset for those interested in building their own campaigns with the built-in editor, and many incremental improvements to an already good game. Get it if you like Shadowrun, get it if you liked either of the last two games, get it if you like strategy or tactical rpgs.

reviewText:
Hong Kong is the latest iteration of the Shadowrun series, and it really doesn't deviate much from it's popular predecessors.

The new stuff worth mentioning:

- A more complex Matrix, with stealth elements, and a little memory mini-game to hack.

- You can now enter turn-based mode as soon as you see the enemy, giving you the opportunity to attack before they do.

- New Cyberware skill-tree and new Cyberweapons, weapons, spells, and enemy types.

- Improved item handling. You can now use medkits on anybody on the team when not in combat, and item pickups can now go to teammates instead of stash if your character doesn't have room for it.

Nothing groundbreaking for sure, but it makes for an altogether more refined experience, and a thoroughly enjoyable Turnbased RPG with a strong story. reviewText:
I write this review mainly for one reason; the game is fantastic, if you're interested then go ahead and get it - if you enjoyed Dragonfall in the least, you'll get about the exact same enjoyment here most likely, and therein lies the point I wanna make.

Some game series', once you've played the newest sequel with the shinest new mechanics, it can make it very hard to go back to previous games; this is NOT the case with Shadowrun, there are a couple of new gameplay mechanics in regards to the in-game Matrix but FUNDAMENTALLY its the same as before, with a small bit of new gameplay added on (which is fun, don't get me wrong, its just not a game-maker or -breaker).  If you were to go back, you wouldn't get that sensation you get from when you, say, go back and play Grand Theft Auto III and try to jump out of a moving car (remember that? sucked â™¥â™¥â™¥ didn't it!), its perfectly fine, you can play these in any order you want.

As for the story, I'll give this one a couple points above Dragonfall but honestly not by an awful lot, they're both good and both take place in very different yet interesting places, Returns being in Seattle, Dragonfall in Berlin and Hong Kong in.....yeah, and each has VERY different politics and mindsets.  One thing I would point out, if you dunno jack about Shadowrun (and I didn't before I played Returns), you should play Dragonfall before Hong Kong, so that you're not spending the whole game coming to grips with the really strange cyber-fantasy world you're in and all the terminology that goes along with it, Returns was a great primer in that regard.  None of the games really offer you a hand-holding introduction into the setting except perhaps Returns (kinda?), so unless you feel like reading a lot of unwieldy wiki articles I would advise putting some time into that - its cheap - or Dragonfall before buying Hong Kong =)

All of that said, Dragonfall seems to have the most user-created content, in particular the Shadowrun Unlimited mod, so in terms of bang-for-buck, I'd go there. Hopefully some of those user-campaigns get ported up to HK, but if not then not a huge loss since again the older games are easy to go back to.

reviewText:
Played and loved SRR and Dragonfall, found this on Kickstarter and started to wonder if Santa really did exist after all...
(see end for TL:DR)

It's a good sequel, the matrix has been totally revamped and is a lot more challenging, there are additional spells and cyberware - plus cyberweapons! - the (large) pile of cash from the kickstarter seems to have been well used.  The fights are generally quite short, but some of them can be lethal if you get caught unawares... so about right for a gun fight then.

There is a lot of dialogue and it can be a bit overfacing early on, as these total strangers start with their wall o text life stories, but it's worth sticking with and adds to the whole RPG experience type thing and can open up side quests for some of your crew.  Which leads me to the NPCs, very well written, same sort of quality as Dragonfall's NPCs, but DIFFERENT, just as your relationship with Fixer and introduction to the team is different.  Gobbet is, IMO, probably as memorable as Minsc from Baldurs Gate and I can't think of a weak link in the team - all of them bring something to a fight and all of them are pretty well written and usually have things to say on missions, so it's worth doing additional playthroughs with a different PC types to get different NPC input.

The ending feels more Shadowrun-like than either of the previous two - no matter what you choose to do, the world rolls on regardless and indifferent.

TL:DR version
is as good as Dragonfall, if not better.  100% achievement easier than Dragonfall by far.

reviewText:
Shadowrun Hong Kong is the third game in the popular cyberpunk RPG series. I really enjoyed the previous two games, Returns and Dragonfall, so I've been looking forward to playing Hong Kong ever since it was announced, and I'm pleased to say that Hong Kong lived up to my expectations.

The story is excellent. Your character has received a mysterious message from your foster-father, indicating that he's in trouble and asking for your help. After arriving in Hong Kong, you get dragged into a massive conspiracy involving organised crime, corporate espionage and supernatural wierdness. There are lots of interesting characters and the dialogue is well written.

The turn based combat system is pretty much the same as previous games. You have a team of 4 characters, and each round they spend action points to move, attack (with guns, melee or magic) or use items such as medkits and grenades. Its a system that I really like because there's a lot of tactical depth, especially now that you can customise your companions' abilities when they level up (a feature that was also added to the director's cut of Dragonfall).

Most missions are designed to allow non combat skills to be useful, for example using dialogue options to avoid fighting guards, or hacking a computer to unlock a door.

The biggest new feature for Hong Kong is the improved matrix system. There's more of a stealth element - some enemies patrol along a set path and they won't attack until you enter their vision cone, so if you're careful you can avoid them. And hacking nodes within the matrix is now a two part mini-game involving remembering sequences of numbers and symbols.

My only disappointment is the continued lack of voice acting. It didn't spoil my enjoyment of the game, but its something that I would like to see added if there's a fourth Shadowrun, because I think it would elevate a good game into a great game.

It took me 20 hours to finish the main story and I think I completed all the side quests as well. I didn't encounter any bugs or crashes. I also want to say that the music is pretty good and matches the oriental theme.

Overall Hong Kong is a really good game, fans of the series will certainly enjoy it, and its worth a full price purchase. The story is not connected to the previous games, so if you're new to Shadowrun, you could choose to play the games in any order.

reviewText:
Latest installment of Shadowrun franchise is more of the same, but it is better same.
In short, Shadowrun Hong Kong can be described as the oriental PC-game edition of the cyberpunk fantasy world of the series, with core mechanic established in Shadowrun Returns, and general choice driven style of Dragonfall.

However, it is a pleasing surprise indeed that Hong Kong can not only stand on its own, it continues Harebrained Schemeâ€™s journey of evolution and shows more polish, less bugs, and better writing than both earlier releases. Combat runs smoother than before, and is more engaging, introducing few nifty little new mechanics to the turn-based battle. Matrix is revamped for the better, offering more immersive experience of gliding through shadow world of information that runs at the very core of Shadowrun. From technical standpoint, it seems to run better and more reliably than earlier releases as well.

If you liked either of the earlier titles, I can safely vouch on the life of my firstborn that you will like this one too. For any newcomers to the franchise or the game series, this is, if not the ideal, so far the best entry point storywise to the world.

Full reviewFirst, let me state that I will not shy away from occasional spoiler if review so demands. Secondly, the game reviewed is Deluxe Edition, which may or may not be reflected in the content. Thirdly, bulk of review is on the writing.

The first thing to highlight from this game is the quality of writing. It runs a much more self-contained narrative than its predecessors, thus rewarding it the â€œnewbie friendlyâ€ seal offered to it a paragraph or so above this one. Where Returns was fairly inaccessible due to lore-heaviness that reminds me of titles such as Dragon Age:Origins and certain JRPG approaches that left me wanting a codex as a newly introduced participant in the events, Hong Kong has managed to strike a balance between lore and narrative: Even without knowing a thing about Flux state, Seattle, Tir, dragons, or Robert N. Charrette, you as a protagonist still have easily definable purpose (save yourself and your adopted father), complex relationship with your brother (slowly revealed in very natural dialogue and built by your decisions), and life as you make it in the city of Heoi and rest of Hong Kong while pursuing the said purpose.

Obviously a mammoth world spawning few DM core rule books will be reflected in any story set in it, but this time it is like a beautiful set piece draping around the narrative, further softened by intelligent references to modern day events and politics. This could have been a merely annoying wink aimed to stroke the egos of clammy neck-bearded armchair generals of game community, still weeping the loss of uniqueness as established by the first Fallout game, but instead they manage to serve as a pathway for original scifi thought-experiments aimed to describe possible futures of technology. While Shadowrun still stands with its chrome covered feet solely planted in contemporary sci-fantasy soil, it is small touches such as discussion of Euro Wars and Russian politics that distill the old school scifi into mix, elevating experience that could have been, completely legitimate, bare entertainment into something more.

The NPCs are more complex than seen before, relying, if not less, on stereotypes, different and by their own right interesting stereotypes. By giving character such as disgraced Red Samurai a personality that runs against the expected redemption arc, the game is playing player expectations resulting in refreshing take on the tropes of the industry. Not perhaps the most novel of ways, but much appreciated in its execution, which is both serious enough to not result in tiring fourth-wall breaking hipster winks, but not too serious. Same can be said about entire game, it avoids both pitfalls that could potentially ruin it: overbearing pathos and crippling self-awareness.

Final point about writing is a double edged sword: the interactions and reactions of the protagonist are more varied than before, allowing more free headcanon building than earlier. However, it is somewhat obvious it is just that, written (and mostly typo free) representation of how the player portrays their character inside their mind. I doubt most dialogue choices actually change anything in the game, merely the way I think about it. And even then, it is corralling the character into certain mold. For me this is enough, the illusion of choice is oftentimes as good as actual choice. However, keep in mind I say this having played 500 hours of Crusader Kings II with most elaborate narratives running inside my mind.

There is not much to say about actual gameplay, as it remains largely unchanged from Dragonfall. You point, you click, and move about in a beautiful handpainted isometric world. Your team has turns, enemy team has turns. Occasionally someone does damage. For me it is a plus, since I have enjoyed the fights since first installment. There are some novel elements, such as Gaichuâ€™s sword styles or Koscheiâ€™s melee, but whether this is refreshing enough for those who want novelties, I cannot say. The battles do run more smoothly though, with less waiting and faster animation.

The major revamp of the game is that of Matrix, and despite resounding grumbling heard across interwebs, I argue it is an excellent revamp. You have to time yourself to glide through watcher IC occupied systems unseen, and use your memory and reflexes to hack gates to access information you need. For the first time, the Matrix provides some challenge and immersion.

As conclusion, Shadowrun: HK is a very good game. Due to its smart writing and integration of both game and real world lore I would hazard to say it is excellent specimen in its genre. The gameplay is familiar, but more polished, with one or two larger changes, for better. The game is as beautiful as the mechanic allows it to be, with excellent music. Setting is organic and interesting, and much more welcoming than earlier titles have had. However, certain gameplay issues, such as clunky inventory and illusion of choice, do remain in this one too. Yet it gives hope that the next title will continue the steady learning process and increase in quality Harebrained has shown throughout the series.

reviewText:
I realy love the Shadowrun Games. Played Returnes and Dragonfall catched up in the great storyline. And this is why i must say that i was expecting ... more. Dont get me wrong. The Story still is good but i feeled that it was a bit rushed.

Matrix is now more complex. I dont think it was a bad call. But i also dont think it was the best. Especialy the BlockerID minimgame is one that i could do without.

Charakters are nicely done but dont come quiet close to someone like Dlory and Dietrich. But you get to see some people out of the Fluxstate and releated ones. As example Zack Flash, the Girlfried of Blitz, a commerad tells you Lucky Strike was his runnermate back in the day. Overall good but not great.

Runs are in my opinion very limited. Would have been nice if the devs had made more of them with a deeper storyinteraction. But its okay.

All in all you get what you see. A Game for 20 Euro. Not as great as the Shadowruns before it but still good. Must buy for fans. Can buy for everyone who enjoys as good Story.

8/10

reviewText:
Played and loved SRR and Dragonfall, found this on Kickstarter and started to wonder if Santa really did exist after all...
(see end for TL:DR)

It's a good sequel, the matrix has been totally revamped and is a lot more challenging, there are additional spells and cyberware - plus cyberweapons! - the (large) pile of cash from the kickstarter seems to have been well used.  The fights are generally quite short, but some of them can be lethal if you get caught unawares... so about right for a gun fight then.

There is a lot of dialogue and it can be a bit overfacing early on, as these total strangers start with their wall o text life stories, but it's worth sticking with and adds to the whole RPG experience type thing and can open up side quests for some of your crew.  Which leads me to the NPCs, very well written, same sort of quality as Dragonfall's NPCs, but DIFFERENT, just as your relationship with Fixer and introduction to the team is different.  Gobbet is, IMO, probably as memorable as Minsc from Baldurs Gate and I can't think of a weak link in the team - all of them bring something to a fight and all of them are pretty well written and usually have things to say on missions, so it's worth doing additional playthroughs with a different PC types to get different NPC input.

The ending feels more Shadowrun-like than either of the previous two - no matter what you choose to do, the world rolls on regardless and indifferent.

TL:DR version
is as good as Dragonfall, if not better.  100% achievement easier than Dragonfall by far.

reviewText:
Hong Kong is a great addition to the series so far.
>The heavily improved sound effects and animations mean that combat feels more satisfying than ever, and there are many more options to talk your way through problems rather than gunning everything down.
> New cyberware skill tree lets you essentially become Glory from SR:DF.
> New decking is passable (YAY), compared to last two games where it was insufferable. The matrix looks a lot cooler, feels a lot more tense, and the gameplay is actually fun. You wouldn't want a whole game made up of matrix sections, but you no longer dread having to jack in.
> It has Gobbet in it.

reviewText:
And Harebrained Studios has done it again.
What we have here is a beautifully done CRPG in traditional Isometric style, that provides a very close experiance to Pen and Papper Shadowrun.

Hong Kong makes a major improvement over Dragonfall in its animation and texture quality, the game looks better, it's smoother, and provides a much more fluid experiance than previous titles. Load times are longer than I'd like, but I am running the game on a fairly low end machine, your milage may vary. Dialogue is excellent, the characters interact more with each other, their dialogue is interesting and engaging.

If I have a complaint it's that the Campaign, while well made and interesting, is short. as of this Writing I have played for 36.2 hours, the main campaign can be completed significantly quicker than that. While the premade campaign is short the Shadowrun games have a history of fan-made campaigns and content. If your willing to wait for user made content this game will be an excellent game, and the best of the Shadowrun games to date.

My personnal favorite is the addition of a viable non-lethal route. I had criticized Dragonfall and Returns because as a devoted Pen and Papper player I am commited to the role of The Face, the talker of the group whose charisma will get a shadowrun team through the door and all the way to the objective. Hong Kong, while still lacking many of the Charisma based skills, does feature many non-violent options on most runs.

I would Highly recomend this game to anyone who has played Shadowrun, or is a fan of CRPGs, Cyberpunk or crime-stategies.

reviewText:
Shadowrun Returns: Hong Kong is a science fiction / fantasy turn based tactical role-playing game developed and self-published by Harebrained Schemes. It takes place in the Shadowrun campaign setting from the science fantasy tabletop role-playing game. This is the third release in the line of games that Harebrained Schemes done for Shadowrun.

If you liked the CyberPunk themed Pencil and Paper RPGs (Shadowrun, Cyberpunk 2020, Gurps Cyberpunk), Cyberpunk themed games and playing turn-based single player campaign games, you might love this game.  If you played the first two Shadowrun Returns games, you might love this one too.

It has a game editor for making new missions that the community been using to improve it with and to extend the life of the game. Go through the Workshop and subscribe to the large selection of community made campaigns. It comes with the HBS campaign called Hong Kong.

You play a character that can choose others to his team and do a mission. You have four free teammates in your crew. You control the actions of each member of the team. While gameplay is mostly linear, some small amount of exploration is possible while completing objectives and optional objectives. The player can enter into dialogue with various characters, with different choices and skills giving new dialogue options.

It comes with the new campaign called Hong Kong which is based in Hong Kong, China.  They have worked the bugs out and added more Shadowrun items to this newer version.   There are new features like inventory trading, improved character creation, improved Matrix maps, improved Drones, Party members can help on contextual choices on map objects.  The story is different from the other Shadowrun Returns game.  The artwork and sound is great.

Other players been saying this game has more bugs.

Has Steam Achievements and steam badge cards. Has community workshop.

reviewText:
SR: Hong Kong is a gem of an RPG thatâ€™s (as of writing) still a few patches away from being a masterpiece.

Pros

Itâ€™s a visual delight that is leagues ahead of the previous games in *almost* every aspect of itâ€™s presentation and finish. Between the great visual design and sharp writing, it truly feels like a cyber dystopian version of Hong Kong. Thereâ€™s also surprising insight into Asian culture and conduct that most western games miss. The music is great but doesnâ€™t feel as memorable as it did in previous games but definitely adds to every scene.

Every major character is interesting and memorable. I thought it would be hard to beat SR: Dragonfall on how much you learn to like your party members but SR: Hong Kong really exceeds expectations. One of the characters you start with, your adopted brother seemed like a pretty generic type of angry ex-cop. Over many conversations with him throughout the game, however, you effectively pick what your history and relationship with him and your adoptive father was. And as the â€˜mutually agreed on historyâ€™ comes back into play throughout the game, you start to feel less like a person clicking through dialogue options and more like youâ€™re in an improv play. The story, although nothing dramatically new, does things in interesting new ways and feels fresh and great.
The other aspects of the game are also well done and a marked improvement from previous games.

Cons

The story feels more personal than in most RPGs but it I wish there were a few more main story missions. By the time end game rolled around, it felt like there was a slight disconnect between the plot and the rest of the game. Which is not an accident, youâ€™re hired as a shadowrunner while the NPCs run down leads on main plot but it still does feel a bit front and end heavy with the middle being completely unrelated stuff.

I love the changes to the matrix (hacking) sections but until the very last level, you donâ€™t realise how lazy they got with the change. The matrix is simply the same throughout the game until you hack the big corporate servers in one of the last missions and suddenly, *this* matrix is vastly different. Gorgeous even. Why canâ€™t each corporate matrix have itâ€™s own visual identity? Surely breaking into the Ares research labs on a side mission should have this kind of effort as well. Seems like a lazy omission that is very unfortunate. Some people may also hate the new changes to the matrix but Iâ€™m not one of them.

Bugs, so many bugs. Nothing too dramatic but the game definitely needed a few more weeks of QA. They may have hotfixed the progress blocking bugs but a plethora of bugs remain ranging from:

- An NPC you spoke to for ages and used dialogue options to advance the story with: talk to them again and they have no memory of talking to you and all the dialogue options you had previously selected are missing. Progress isnâ€™t stopped as the dialogue options all triggered stuff in the game itâ€™s just weird and super immersion breaking. This happened MANY times but mostly in the last 25% of the campaign.
- 2 side-quest lines somehow resolved themselves as failures without me doing anything. One of these quests was both tied to an achievement and also glitched the relevant NPCs so there were 2 people where there should have been one (1 should exist in a mission success state and the other in a fail state, not both).
- The NPCs in club 88 and numerous NPCs in the epilogue all have a plethora of disappointing and immersion breaking dialogue bugs.
- During the final boss fight, there wasâ€¦ unusual behaviour among the NPCs. Instead of the character that was upgraded to throw back grenades doing that, a completely different party member was picking up projectiles and hurling them at friends. Very weird.

Overall this game is amazing but I did miss out on achievements and some good memories because of the bugs. If youâ€™re a huge fan of the SR series then get it now, play it, and play it a second time after the bugs are gone (which I intend to do). If youâ€™re on the fence and just looking for a good RPG, go play SR: Dragonfall while they patch out the bugs out of this one â€“ but definitely revisit after patches. This game is fantastic.

reviewText:
So the third installment of the SR series is pretty good, but not as good as Dragonfall.

I will highlight two problems and two virtues.

Problems:

1) The writing is still solid, but at times it goes on too much.

In the mid game I felt like I was drowning in all the stories that NPCs had to tell. I would be sitting there for a solid hour listening to my party members and shopkeepers talking about their lives and all that. There's a whole lot of telling and not so much showing. I feel that if you'd just done two actual missions for party members rather than just one it would've fleshed things out a lot more smoothly.

Couple that with the fact that there are entire missions that you just talk your way through and this started to feel like a Choose Your Own Adventure game after a bit.

Also shopkeepers don't need elaborate backstories, don't waste time on that.

2) The game is pretty easy.

I played through the whole game on 'hard' difficulty and, outside of the first mission when I didn't have any equipment, never had trouble. The AI is just completely terrible and never offers a challenge. They walk through poison gas, they glitch and forget to do an attack and they never focus fire. And there's just never any curve ball that gives you that 'oh â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥' moment like in Dragonfall. No Troll Cyborg hacking, no duels with other Deckers in the Matrix and no crazy duplicating satan fights.

I didn't expect XCom here, but I still pretty much beat the whole game without breaking a sweat.

Virtues:

1) The story and world are genuinely interesting.

After the travesty that was Shadowrun Chronicles, I'm quite relieved to find that this thing was back on track with a compelling story with interesting twists and turns. The game gives you a decent amount of room to develop your own character and her backstory, while also giving you the chance to have interesting relationships with people. I was pleased that the plethora of ways to complete each quest and felt I had built a character with real personality after some time.

2) There's a good diversity of missions.

You get to solve a murder mystery, infiltrate a convention and break down corporate offices. There's nothing quite as good as Glory's mission from Dragonfall, but there's good stuff here.

Overall: If you liked Dragonfall, you'll have something to like here, but it probably won't meet that gold standard.

reviewText:
If you loved the last two Shadowrun games, you'll love this one.

It combines what they've learned of the previous two games and they execute it very well and this time, it feels like you can connect more with your playable character and the people around him/her and now you have the chance to get every etiquette in the game instead of leaving just one!

The matrix has reworked into something beautiful, the new way to hack is amazing and requires a bit more getting used to but it's already much more fun. The new portraits they've done also look great but the older ones look out of place. The campaign is still a bit short but atleast longer (in my opinion) than the previous two games.

A few downsides to me personally, is that I could play the last two perfectly with near to no fps losses, while for some reason a few scenes cause my screen to tear and freeze slightly, plus a few animations are still buggy/the karma system takes quite awhile to open up.

If you are looking for a fun turned-based game to get into, Shadowrun: Hong Kong is a good place to begin!

I just finished the game (well last night) and my experience with it was kind of bland.  Generally speaking the game played almost like a Point-and-Click Interactive Story.  The game played a lot like its previous iterations, from a game design point of view, and the graphical upgrades to the Matrix are pretty neat but not as exciting, it feels like they didnt put too much effort on it as they should have.  The new puzzle system (for hacking) in the Matrix killed it for me, the whole simon-sez / Memory game wasn't well laid out and was boring.  In general the game was good... But not exciting good.

The story itself was interesting at some points but it felt more like the campaign someone back in my highschool days would coin up to play on a saturday afternoon.  It was good but not $30 - $20 good.  There were a lot of flaws in the writing, like I said it was very bland and forgettable and not well thought out specially at the beginning.  A good word to describe it would have been... Meh.

Whatever upgrade they did with the graphics engine is pretty neat.  The artwork in the game is pretty good, it feels almost like being on a painting.  If it were not for the artwork I don't think I would have been compelled to play the game so much if it wasnt because the graphics were that pretty.

The so-called Matrix update artwork-wise was really good, I liked the new representation of it.  I still think at Char-Gen you should be able to pick an avatar for your character instead of the floating generic one, as it doesnt make you feel part of the game just another random icon to be a part of.  The Gameplay in the Matrix was horrible.  I understand the need to put a mechanic for the hacking" part of the game but playing Simon-Sez with the numbers is not it...
