reviewText:
TL:DR: Easily a must buy if you like turn based CRPGs, and a must buy if you like the shadowrun franchise.

Disclaimer: I have only played through the main campaign, so the campaign builder tools and what people have made with them are not included.

If you have played Returns and Dragonfall, Hong Kong is the next logical step in this games development. Notable in that the story is very well told, with some more nuanced approaches to missions as opposed to Dragonfall's tendency to have A or B endings to a mission. They also include several missions where giving up an obvious benefit or doing something right will benefit you later with allies. It still follows in Returns/Dragonfalls steps in including a rather major event that fits well into the history of shadowrun, without retconning anything. The prime runners you get are very likable, and the characters around town you talk to are fleshed out well enough that you don't mind talking to them after each run.

The major change in gameplay is the matrix runs, where they are now half-stealth and half combat. Mostly this comes down to avoiding obvious sight trails with careful movement, and unlocking doors with a rather clever and simple minigame. You can brute force still, but its obviously much harder and more dangerous. I got a bit frustrated with it at times, but I think it fits the hacking a bit better.

My only complaint is a relatively minor one, in that adepts are still restricted to melee. While obviously a CRPG will have a hard time adjusting to Shadowruns huge possibility tables, this still feels like something that would be easy to fix. Also any cyber-weapons in the game are melee, where it seems it would be easy to include a gun on the table as well.

If you haven't played the previous two: Play Dragonfall and this, not in any particular order (the stories don't connect). They are amazingly well done turn based CRPGs, with combat that is similar to X-com with hiding behind cover and action point based turns. Well crafted and unique missions make the twenty-ish hour campaign worth the price.

reviewText:
Shadowrun: Hong Kong is the new chapter in the cyperpunk-with-fantasy RPG series: a good story, great art style, interesting companions and lots of small improvements make this a great game which is sadly marred by some annoying bugs and glitches.

PROS:

-great story, while not as long as Dragonfall this time things are more intimate as you look into the disappearance of your foster father while trying to uncover who ruined your life

-overall writing is really done well, there's tons of dialogues, ambiance descriptions and computer logs to read through

-the art style is really nice and really sells a believable bleak future: the graphics are also pretty detailed and crisp

-the companions you'll meet and recruit all have some deep and interesting backstories: they also all have very good skillsets making everyone useful in a run

-really nice soundtrack

-well-designed and varied missions, some of them can be completed without even firing a shot if you or your companions have the appropriate skills

-tons of skills for you to choose from allow you to create any character you want, even mixing different classes"

-excellent length

NEUTRAL:

-it can really get a bit TOO verbose at times with lots of details to read through and a few conversations that drag a bit

CONS:

-some serious bugs still unpatched as of the last version (3.0.5) the worst being the "stuck in combat" one when you do not return to real time movement after killing all enemies in an area. I got this twice
date:
the first time I had to go back to a previous save thus losing about 15 minutes since it was a big firefight with a matrix run occurring simultaneously. The second time it was towards the end of the game and I had to walk turn-by-turn until I finally entered a new area: I'm pretty sure this glitched an optional encounter that'd have taken place and prevented me from getting an extra companion for the end boss fight.

-dodgy framerate during a mission towards the end of the game (probably related to a bug aswell)

-loading times are quite long when entering a level
recommended:
reloading a save or entering the skill screen

-a few difficulty spikes

-some typos here and there

reviewText:
I played a decker in all the Shadow run games so far.  This one changed up the matrix a lot.  It was a fresh twist, made decking quite a bit different than meatspace combat.  There is a memory mini-game when hacking blocking IRCs.  It was fun, but could be challenging if one had limited brain space.

I liked the story of Dragonfall better, but this one was ok.  I hated that there were not more jobs to get more money.  Never felt like I was fully equiped, but maybe that was the point.  I would have liked to see more optional missions to do before the main story so that I could get everything I wanted.

If I have time I'll rerun the campagn with a troll chocked full of augmentations.  I'd make some decisions differently just to see how they play out.

Overall, 8.5/10.  Would run the shadows again

reviewText:
A pretty good Shadowrun campaign! Some of the better writing to be found in gaming. The combat seems a little easier than the other two previous campaigns, I'd suggest going for the Hard Difficulty.

Maybe the best companions in the series so far, as well as some pretty unique and fun quests. Wish there was more content though, it feels a little short to me. If money per hour is a big deal for you, maybe wait for this to be on sale.

A couple of bugs still present in this at the time of playing. Nothing that stopped my progress, but some weird stuff like on occasion my inventory stash would just empty itself. Not sure what was causing that.

Lastly, for new players to this particular strain of Shadowrun games:

There is a lot of reading. This is a combination interactive novel with RPG elements and X-Com tactical combat. It's an excellent late night game to play before going to bed. Won't get you riled up and it's interesting enough to give you something to think about, keeps you thirsty to get you to play it again.

I'm really glad though they ended up fine tuning and streamlining this -- it's a huge difference between the first one and now, with quality of life changes. So hoooray for this game.

reviewText:
Hong Kong...The place where dreams come from!
Ok, not dreams. More like nightmares. And demons...

Ã—Â°Ã—â˜…Summary Reviewâ˜…Ã—Â°Ã—
Overall Rating: â˜…â˜…â˜…â˜†â˜† [3/5]
Story: â˜…â˜…â˜…â˜†â˜†
Gameplay: â˜…â˜…â˜…â˜†â˜†

â—â–¬â–¬â–¬â–¬à®œÛ©ÛžÛ©à®œâ–¬â–¬â–¬â–¬â—
â˜…OVERALLâ˜…
Reminiscent of expansion packs in the 1990's, Hong Kong is a standalone story staying true to the already established world within the previously released Shadowrun Returns. Once again, just like with the release of Dragonfall, Harebrained Schemes has given us an entirely new game. There have been some much needed improvements to the combat system, a rebuilt UI, new cyber-skills, and the addition of illustrated cinematic transitions for the storyline; however, they made some changes to the Matrix and Decking that you may or may not like. It's not easy to follow up such an epic story with great characters as was in Dragonfall. And if you played it prior to Hong Kong, you may be left feeling a bit wanting by the end. Much like a warm-up band playing after the main concert. You might feel the urge to leave the show early...

â˜…STORYâ˜…
This time, you *don't* start out as a shadowrunner. Long estranged from the man who raised you, you've lived a comfy life in Seattle and have all but forgotten your childhood. Until, without warning, your father sends you a trid requesting you meet him in Hong Kong immediately, but gives you no explanations as to why. So, out of guilt or a sense of loyalty, you drop everything and hop on the next flight to China. But he's not there to greet you when you arrive. Instead, the boy you grew up with, Duncan Wu, now a member of the Seattle police force called 'Lone Star,' is there on the docks. Surprised to see each other, you discover that neither of you know what's going on and quickly things take a turn for the worse. Suddenly, you're forced into the underground and to survive you must become a shadowrunner in one of the most dangerous, and profitable places in the Sixth World- The Hong Kong Free Enterprise Zone.

Unfortunately, SR:HK falls short of the glory that was Dragonfall. Which is disappointing given the interesting and rich setting of Hong Kong, especially since they had a pretty clean slate to work with as Shadowrun lore doesn't touch on much of the Asian side of the world. It has some of the most annoying characters I've ever seen in a video game, the worst of which are Duncan Wu and Is0bel. Their dialog sounds like emo teenagers and I just want to slap them. Hard. With a bullet to the face. And if it were me, I'd outright resent having my father drag my â™¥â™¥â™¥ all the way to China to fix *his* problems! It's no wonder your character left him to begin with. In spite of all this, it might be forgivable if the plot wasn't so predictable. After 25 hours into the story, the only reason I continued was out of a compulsion to complete the damn thing so I could shelve it and never return.

â˜…GAMEPLAYâ˜…
I've come to think of the Shadowrun Returns series more as an interactive virtual novel with tactical and roleplaying elements. Because the true lure of this game is not the gameplay, but the story. I'm not saying that it's bad, it's just not what makes the game entertaining. While you're able to change some elements of the story to your own unique perspective, the main storyline arc remains similar. And customizing your character has little impact on how the story develops, instead offering a different perspective on the same events.

However, there have been some improvements to the combat system. Now the floating combat text includes events such as Dodged
date:
instead of only telling you if you hit or missed. Also, your percent chance to hit seems much more accurate than in previous games. I don't know if a layer of RNG was removed or just tweaked but combat is much more enjoyable than it was in SR:R and SR:DF. Sadly, it seems this improvement has come at the cost of a weak story.

â˜…SOUND & MUSICâ˜…
Jon Everist has composed the music for both Dragonfall and Hong Kong, and he was one of three composers that created the original soundtrack to Shadowrun Returns. As usual, his talent is one of the shining highlights of this series. He successfully mixed traditional asian instruments with modern techno music to create a unique sound that feels appropriate for the futuristic setting of neo-China. I recommend buying the deluxe edition for the added bonus of the game soundtrack. Itâ€™s a welcome addition to anyoneâ€™s music collection.

â˜…BUGS & BOTHERSâ˜…
Unfortunately, there exists a bug that can be very game breaking. Sometimes, items left on your characters will disappear after the mission is completed. Items like weapons, medkits, and spells. It's extremely frustrating to say the leastâ€¦ Thereâ€™s no workaround that I know of and thereâ€™s no sign of a fix in sight.

Now let's talk about the overhauled Matrix. While the look of the Matrix is much improved from the previous Shadowrun games, the mechanics are completely different and not for the better, in my opinion.

Deckers can now â€œejectâ€ from the Matrix at anytime, but doing so severely hurts your Deckerâ€™s HP. Making it an unacceptable risk during combat and basically unnecessary out of combat. Never once did I use the eject ability during my playthrough. Itâ€™s a good idea, but the cost is too high.

Once again Deckers get the shaft. While combat in meatspace has been much improved, combat in the Matrix has become more difficult. In previous games, it wasnâ€™t hard to raise your programs skill high enough to reach a 99% hit chance. In Hong Kong, however, thatâ€™s only possible at max skill. And the further you are from your target, the more severe the penalty to your hit chance. Itâ€™s almost like they swapped combat systems between meatspace and the Matrix. And since you canâ€™t level up your companionâ€™s abilities, Is0bel, your resident Decker, remains a mediocre choice when trying to hack your way through a security system.

While in the Matrix, you must dodge watcher programs that follow a specific path and if they spot you, it will raise the alarm level by +20 each turn for every watcher that has spotted you. And they're absolutely everywhere. Some areas of the Matrix are literally crawling with watcher programs to the point of madness. On top of that, you must bypass Blockers using their new Hacking system. Blockers are basically giant virtual walls that stand between you and your objective. You must hack, enter a password, or override it at the cost of +50 to your alarm level. This wouldn't be so bad if the Hacking system wasn't an annoying mixture of Simon Says" and "Guess Who?" using pseudo-geometric shapes that don't make any sense combined with yet another level of RNG. It's not that hacking is difficult

I have really enjoyed the experience in Shadowrun HK. The design of the game, the music, and the NPCs really made for an immersive Cyberpunk experience. As a tabletop player, it was great to see such a great adaptation of this masterpiece that is Shadowrun.

You can rush through the game, all gun blazing, with minimum interactions and go to the end, or you can stop and talk to everyone around, learn more about the world, the characters, the power in place.

Be aware that the story is text heavy. I personally loved it but it might put some people off. I believe it is the only to have such a complexe game, and I think it is great.

reviewText:
I was able to pick up Shadowrun: Hong Kong on sale at right around 13$, so lets keep that in mind whenever I discuss the worth of the game.  For everyone hoping this was another Shadowrun: Dragonfall, well, it's not - but that's okay, because it's still a strong entry into the franchise.

There is nothing bad about SH:Hong Kong, the only complaints, are those of omissions when compared to it's predecessor.  You won't find multiple sources such as the Lodge lobby for your paydata - that's all going straight to Shadowland BBS.  Not every crew member has their own optional story quest either.  Unfortunately, you can't help a killer AI inhabit a dragon, but I guess you can't really catch lightning in a bottle twice there, now can you?  I wouldn't call the game shallow, because everyone introduced is afforded a good amount of creativity to their personal story.  It's just not to the same extent that we saw in Dragonfall.

Still, the setting is intriguing, the characters are engaging, combat is fluid, and the overall eerie tone of the games voice resonates well.  Just saying teeth isn't scary - but the authorial description of 'too many teeth' and building slums, gnarling innward to consume you is... or it's at least unsettling.

reviewText:
Just finished the campaign an can honestly recommend everyone to do the same. Excellent writing, a fantastic story way of the beaten path and memorable and interesting characters.

The system is basically from Dragfonfall with some improvements (the matrix especially looks WAY better), so all the limitations are also still there. Very limited customization and equipping of team members, very little freedom expect for the order in wich you do the runs. If that irked you before, it'll still do so now, I didn't mind a bit.

The combat system is still well executed and diverse, and every team member has interesting abilities to contribute. Fights are fun, and avoiding them by using other skills can be even more so.

Building you own character is great as ever, and this is one of the few RPGs with a working economy. You'll never have enough money for ALL the goodies you'd really like...

What really annoys a bit, however, are the bugs and glitches. Some left since Shadowrun returns.

- Fights can get stuck on enemies' turn for several reasons, requiring a reload (enemies with no AP not acting and not being skipped, clouds of toxic gas not disappearing and not allowing you to end combat, dropped items freezing your action and so on). Really, folks, turn based games 101 says to always have an alternate trigger if one should fail...

- the to hit number calculated and shown on screen is STILL utter bull****. I played 3.5 hours tonight and among many silly things I had 4 consecutive misses on a 78% chance *3* times - a 1 in 500 occurence. Once per hour. 70+ percent chances miss way to often <30% chances hit way too often. Always been this way since day 1 and never been really looked at.

But no gamestoppers and nothing that really spoils the fun wth this excellent story.

reviewText:
I've played both previous Shadowrun games by Harebrained Schemes, and in my opinion they keep getting better. Hong Kong is far from perfect though. If you're not familiar with the setting, the game is a lore heavy CRPG set in a cyberpunk/fantasy universe. Robots and elves. Expect a lot of neon.

The Good
+ Strong writing and dialogue. Characters have a lot of depth, and the plot is intriguing.
+ Fun and distinct class builds. Word of warning though, don't spread yourself too thin.
+ Multiple ways to approach combat, puzzles, and scenarios (cover mechanics, brute force, skill checks, charisma, chilling out with spirits, etc.)
+ Great art style.

The Not-So Good
- A little too much text. This is subjective, and I personally like all the reading, but there is a ton of it and you may not be into that. It does affect the pacing. Luckily, most of it is optional.
- Spelling errors. I've noticed more in Hong Kong than the previous games.
- The new Matrix. In the previous games, the Matrix was basically standard combat with even more neon painted on it. It was boring. This time around, Harebrained Schemes added a stealth mechanic you can use, and a hacking mechanic that has you memorizing patterns of numbers. I really like the hacking part, because is feels more immersive for that kind of character. I've heard others complain that they don't want something that requires actual skill instead of your character's skill, which is a legit criticism. I will say this though- the stealth option kinda sucks. It requires precise clicking and timing to avoid cones of sight, and the game just isn't built for that. It's not responive enough. The changes in the Matrix are optional though, you can still just kill everything if you prefer,
-I've heard reports of bugs. Haven't encountered anything major myself, but everyone's experience will differ.

Summary- Punch people with a robot arm, read a short story, memorize a few numbers, then upgrade your robot arm.

reviewText:
Finished it some time ago. Overall the game was fun, although far worse than amazing Dragonfall.

-Racter and Gaichu are great. Those two are among the most well written and interesting companions in the genre in recent memory. Both are quite morally ambiguous, shady and somehow maniacal. Talking with them is fun as well as reading their barks during missions.
-Goblet was alright. HBS tried with her dialogues to mirror a way players were taught by Dak'kon in P:T and it was successful enough to be entertaining. I don't care about Duncan and I think Is0bel was bad. She might have been a good character but HBS went for too much drama in her lines and she became tiresome.
-Many of new portraits are amazing, they are the best of all kickstarter cRPGs. They can even compete and win with Baldurs Gate 1 portraits.
-Writing was pretty good. Kindly Cheng scenes often felt quite menacing. Sometimes the writing feels it was suffering from graphomania, and the game is badly paced.
-Story starts really strong, even better than Dragonfall. And then it stops. Game forgets PC is hunted by the police and let him go to the parties and do his businesses. Until endgame the story is nearly completely abandoned. There are less endings than in Dragonfall and there is a lack of wonder if choices made were correct.
-The lack of the Lodge and Schsssomething miniquests makes runs far worse. Loved that those quest were often in conflict with each other and made runs far more varied and richer in C&C.
-New augmentations system was fun. The choices are now quite big, we have new slots and I liked weapons like a whip of being overpowered.
-Dragonfall had a really good encounter design. APEX mission was it highlight. Hong Kong only good encounters are the ambush in the first mission, the boss fight and a battle in the tomb raiding mission. From which only the last 2 are not questionable.
-Runs were often very good conceptually but weakly designed. Great example of that was Feng Shui run where the player is tasked with sabotaging the company Feng Shui flow. It's done by clicking on things...
-Combat difficulty was lowered. Very High setting was cut from the game.
-Most encounters are skipable. Sounds great? Never have I thought it is possible to use this feature to make the game worse. Actually I think it is the first time ever something like this has happened in the cRPG genre. How it failed? It is because skipping combat is easy, does not require much player input. It actually felt I was naturally drifting towards peaceful resolutions which takes fun out of outsmarting foes. I honestly and non cynically think HBS has added something to the pool of knowledge of cRPGs design by this mistake.
-Music was ok, but not as great as Dragonfall. Visuals were an improvement from previous installments.

reviewText:
As a fan of the old SNES Shadowrun, I happily bought all of these 3 new Shadowrun cRPGs.
All of them good, some with more problems than others.

Shadowrun Returns was quite easy and too straightforward; it didnt feel much of a RPG. The base system was solid though, and it captures the lore of Shadowrun very well, so even with limited playability it was a solid game.

Dragonfall mastered the problems of the first game and made it a truly great game. Great story, characters, more challenge. The way it is constructed reminds me a lot of Mass Effect 2-3 games though, heh. Suppose it is because you get to choose which mission to do next, and between the mission you go to your base and talk to your crew, which will make you know about them better and build up your relations. And get their character missions etc.

So the latest/last part to the new Shadowrun games, Hong Kong. After the great Dragonfall, they had to try hard to surpass themselves. In fact, the biggest problem of this game is, that they probably tried too hard. Way too hard in some aspects.

The progression and spacing of the game is just completely broken, compared to most RPG games. You will do a fun but short mission in 20-40 mins, after which you will go to your base city and talk with your crew and other NPCs to learn about their past and opinions... for hours. After every single mission.  They have given a detailed backstory to every NPC in the game, and they sure didnt cut anything out of it, but it all is told to you in very bloaten, repetitive and overly detailed way. The ammount of past stories the characters have is just too much. Its hard to get focus on what part of those backstories they blabber about are meaningful, so at some point you will stop caring at all. But since talking to your crew is also a way to unlock their quests, and sometimes actually interesting as well, you still have to force yourself to read through the thousands of lines of their past history with their past friends. Its shame they didnt just edit the text more and focus on writing what is important instead of just writing every single thing they can come up with, as the characters themselves are super interesting. The Russian rigger is one of the most interesting characters I`ve ever seen in RPGs.

Even though I dont mind some reading, I still see games more of an visual media like films are. When you have a story you want to tell; show it, dont tell it. If Hong Kong was a movie, it would be a 5 hours long movie where characters talk about their past yet you are never shown it but just the faces of the characters talking. If the game actually took you to their past and let you play through them, well that would have been incredible. Obviously it wouldnt have been possible to their budget and time, since the game would need 10x more locations in it then...

Another problem is, that while the missions are super fun and varied in settings, combat wise the game is way too easy even on Hard. Most of the missions only have 1-2, or even 0 combat situations in them. I think I only had to use 1 medkit in the whole game. In later stages where you get 3 AP instead of beginning 2, your team will be next to invincible and its rare that you get hit even once if you utilize tactics even a bit. The game just lacks balls to throw enough strong opponents at you, it just throws the handfull of 3-5 all from 1 direction, which are then easily taken care of, even if you gimp your main character with poor choices. Only hard parts are in the computer world of Matrix, which are hair-pullingly irritating when you dont play as a decker yourself but need to use the NPC decker. Had to do some annoying save&load in some of those. They are not fun either, as controlling 1 character in simple turn-based tactical combat really doesnt give you many tactical possibilities.

Because of how easy the battles are, you really are not encouraged to play the game again with different classes, even though in theory you could play the game in 20+ very different type of characters. The ammount of dialogue between the missions furthermore gimps your interest in giving it a second playthrough. Which is shame. The game has excellent world, full of interesting people, nice grapchis and sound and atmosphere. With edited dialogue and harder combat, this could be a worthy successor to Dragonfall and a cRPG which I could recommend to everyone, but now with the problems I only recommend it to the fans of Dragonfall who dont mind reading a loooot.

For the ones who have not played any of the these Shadowruns yet, I recommend getting Dragonfall first.

reviewText:
This is is the pinnacle of Harebrained Schemes' take on Shadowrun, building on the shaky-but-promising foundations of Shadowrun Returns and the excellent follow-up, Dragonfall. Like its predecessors, SR: Hong Kong is a narrative-based tactical RPG born out of the pen-and-paper Shadowrun setting. The Hong Kong location gives things a different flavour, sufficiently differentiating it from the other two games, but what really sets it apart is the extra attention paid to the NPC runner crew. Shadowrun Returns had only a couple of returning characters, while Dragonfall introduced a true party of the kind you'd expect to find in most computer RPGs. Hong Kong takes that and runs with it, and I think a large part of what you get out of the game will depend on how attached you become to the characters. For me, Hong Kong is easily my favourite of the three games, though I still need to go back and play the Director's Cut of Dragonfall.

Gameplay-wise, things are mostly similar to the other Shadowrun games, but the interface is further refined, while cyberware and Matrix hacking have seen a lot of attention. The Matrix work in particular makes playing a decker a lot more interesting, and the hacking minigame for cracking blocker IC is pretty neat. It's a lengthy story, too, especially with the Shadows of Hong Kong mini-campaign added with the Extended Edition. At time of writing, that epilogue campaign seems a little rough around the edges, but is a welcome follow-up with a couple of interesting runs.

For the right kind of gamer, I really couldn't recommend this enough.

reviewText:
Another great Shadowrun adventure.

Having polished the engine and mechanics with Dragonfall Director's Cut, developers focused on world building and the story. The game is at its most beautiful, music is great, combat is crisp, missions diverse and interesting. Atmosphere sucks you in and you really feel the tension building up to something as the game progresses. The best part? I wasn't disappointed with the conclusion at all. Personally, I find the characters somewhat more alive and peculiar than Dragonfall ones. The game is also more liberal with karma points than Dragonfall so I don't feel as forced into metagaming and can actually allow myself sculpting a roleplayed person and still be an effective runner.

That being said, there's also one major downside that hurts replayability. Harebrained really went overboard with text and exposition to the point where it feels as if you're spending more time reading than doing actual runs. Even if you click through most conversations it still takes a lot of time to visit everyone between missions. This makes Dragonfall feel much more focused and intense. (In particular I feel the whole Ka Fai family business could've and should've been cut. Maybe Spider Shen too.)

One more minor gripe of mine is that the engine isn't particularly well suited for the new stealth mechanics in the matrix and one of the missions. It's bearable at best, but some of the more tricky and complex sections had me savescumming in frustration at how my character was moving. Although overall I like the new matrix minigame. It certainly makes me feel more engaged.

These two issues are why I wouldn't rate the game at 10 (for the record, I named Dragonfall Director's Cut my game of the year for 2014). But then again, despite these the game is certainly worth at least one playthrough for the story and definitely more if you're into Shadowrun and/or turn based combat by Harebrained. Can't wait for the promised mini-expansion.

reviewText:
A pretty good Shadowrun campaign! Some of the better writing to be found in gaming. The combat seems a little easier than the other two previous campaigns, I'd suggest going for the Hard Difficulty.

Maybe the best companions in the series so far, as well as some pretty unique and fun quests. Wish there was more content though, it feels a little short to me. If money per hour is a big deal for you, maybe wait for this to be on sale.

A couple of bugs still present in this at the time of playing. Nothing that stopped my progress, but some weird stuff like on occasion my inventory stash would just empty itself. Not sure what was causing that.

Lastly, for new players to this particular strain of Shadowrun games:

There is a lot of reading. This is a combination interactive novel with RPG elements and X-Com tactical combat. It's an excellent late night game to play before going to bed. Won't get you riled up and it's interesting enough to give you something to think about, keeps you thirsty to get you to play it again.

I'm really glad though they ended up fine tuning and streamlining this -- it's a huge difference between the first one and now, with quality of life changes. So hoooray for this game.

reviewText:
The Extended Edition and its new campaign again provide amazing story-telling. And while the bonus campaign is definitely shorter than the main campaign (as was announced beforehand), I was surprised at the length and the presence of side quest. One of the side quest provided one of the - in my opinion - most memorable stand-offs. Of course, depending on how you chose.
So I was again masterfully entertained - until the end. The end left me rather unhappy. While it did have plausible choices - there was an obvious, additional, only slightly different choice missing. Obviously, this being a comment on the ending, here come the spoilers...

Basically the choices are Qiu, Cheng and a middleground. While the extrems feel right, the middleground lacks subleties. Especially, if your character (like mine) was not only story-wise the face of the group but also accordingly skilled: With enough charisma (or the right etiquette) it should have been possible to choose burning the warehouse while letting Qiu live AND plead for Duncan to still get a SIN. Not only did my character have enough charisma to pull this off, there could have been a few lines of thinking up how to still produce evidence for Qiu before setting everything on fire. With that it would make sense for Qiu to stick to only half her promised payment - Duncan's SIN.
To me, this slight variation seems pretty self-evident - and it doesn't seem to be too difficult to implement with a little bit of work. So despite the game being the solid and fun Shadowrun experience you know and can expect of Harebrained Schemes, this detail at the very end left a slightly unsatisfactory aftertaste.

reviewText:
I was consistently impressed with the writing and design of this game. Many RPGs profess to let you build your character and play the way you want, but Shadowrun Hong Kong delivers in ways that other games do not. There are a variety of intriguing character options from spirit-summoning street shaman to hacker drone commander to cyborg warrior. In terms of character personality and history, the story lets you flesh out your character's backstory through dialogue in surprising ways. Most importantly, you can play through virtually any mission without violence if you select the correct dialogue options and your character is skilled and charismatic enough. This is a role-playing game in the purest sense,

There's more than one way to skin a cat in Shadowrun Hong Kong, and I found myself reloading misions to try them all. Particular standouts for me are the mission where you solve a murder mystery in one of Hong Kong's tech district and the mission which requires you to infiltrate a party hosted by TV serial producer who has a mysterious new girlfriend.

Most of the characters you recruit are fairly intriguing; true to the genre they have dark secrets in their past that come back to haunt them in one way or another. Conversations with your teammates are alternately thought-provoking and comedic, depending on who you talk to. The game is incredibly text-heavy, if you do not enjoy reading or dislike Hamnett-esque noir prose, this is not a game for you.

I was also impressed by the game's respectful use of Chinese culture. The game draws heavily on Hong Kong action film stereotypes and settings, but the writing suggests a familiarity and depth of research beyond a few viewings of Hard Boiled and Infernal Affairs.

reviewText:
Finished it some time ago. Overall the game was fun, although far worse than amazing Dragonfall.

-Racter and Gaichu are great. Those two are among the most well written and interesting companions in the genre in recent memory. Both are quite morally ambiguous, shady and somehow maniacal. Talking with them is fun as well as reading their barks during missions.
-Goblet was alright. HBS tried with her dialogues to mirror a way players were taught by Dak'kon in P:T and it was successful enough to be entertaining. I don't care about Duncan and I think Is0bel was bad. She might have been a good character but HBS went for too much drama in her lines and she became tiresome.
-Many of new portraits are amazing, they are the best of all kickstarter cRPGs. They can even compete and win with Baldurs Gate 1 portraits.
-Writing was pretty good. Kindly Cheng scenes often felt quite menacing. Sometimes the writing feels it was suffering from graphomania, and the game is badly paced.
-Story starts really strong, even better than Dragonfall. And then it stops. Game forgets PC is hunted by the police and let him go to the parties and do his businesses. Until endgame the story is nearly completely abandoned. There are less endings than in Dragonfall and there is a lack of wonder if choices made were correct.
-The lack of the Lodge and Schsssomething miniquests makes runs far worse. Loved that those quest were often in conflict with each other and made runs far more varied and richer in C&C.
-New augmentations system was fun. The choices are now quite big, we have new slots and I liked weapons like a whip of being overpowered.
-Dragonfall had a really good encounter design. APEX mission was it highlight. Hong Kong only good encounters are the ambush in the first mission, the boss fight and a battle in the tomb raiding mission. From which only the last 2 are not questionable.
-Runs were often very good conceptually but weakly designed. Great example of that was Feng Shui run where the player is tasked with sabotaging the company Feng Shui flow. It's done by clicking on things...
-Combat difficulty was lowered. Very High setting was cut from the game.
-Most encounters are skipable. Sounds great? Never have I thought it is possible to use this feature to make the game worse. Actually I think it is the first time ever something like this has happened in the cRPG genre. How it failed? It is because skipping combat is easy, does not require much player input. It actually felt I was naturally drifting towards peaceful resolutions which takes fun out of outsmarting foes. I honestly and non cynically think HBS has added something to the pool of knowledge of cRPGs design by this mistake.
-Music was ok, but not as great as Dragonfall. Visuals were an improvement from previous installments.
-New matrix was a total letdown. Instead of improving it, HBS made it worse. Was actually cursing when playing it, cannot imagine how somebody thought the design was good and was not slapped for it by his colleagues. Gone are the simultaneous meatspace/matrix battles, instead we have minigames.

reviewText:
A very good, old school RPG with modern style and gameplay concessions.  You control a group of 4 shadow runners, taking various jobs to stay alive, all the while trying to figure out who put a hit on your head.

The Good:
Beautiful, pre-rendered back grounds with 3d characters in front.
Spellbinding story that keeps you hooked.
Interesting characters.  I'd put them above Icewind Dale/Baldur's Gate, but less than Baldur's Gate II.
Great visual style.
The character classes seem very ballanced - didn't find anything obviously game-breakingly-overpowered in my first playthrough.
Oh yeah, and fantastic music!  Doesn't get tired or annoying.

The Bad:
Interface can be a bit glitchy - doesn't always detect mouse clicks.
Some lag when switching scenes.
Game starves you for money in the last couple of chapters.
About it.

Overall, highly recommended!

reviewText:
If you've played either of the other recent Shadowrun games from Harebrained Studios, then you basically know what to expect with this title. I can thoroughly recommend it to previous players, although I would say that, personally, I feel Dragonfall was the better game. And to interested parties who have never experienced a Shadowrun game before, I would say to go and try Dragonfall before trying Hong Kong: while I really enjoyed Hong Kong, I think a new player would get much more out of Dragonfall.

Shadowrun: Hong Kong plays like a rather standard tactical RPG. You create a main character, load him up with whatever stats you want (I prefer a gun-toting Bear Shaman, who can place barriers as personal cover to snipe from long distances, Haste himself to shoot up to two times more often per round, and use the Bear totem for the game's only AoE heal). You have a group of pre-determined party members, each with their own strengths and weaknesses. In addition, each mission provides you with a list of alternate Shadowrunners you can take instead of your standard party members, although why you would do this remains a mystery to me.

Said party members, I feel, are one of the ways Hong Kong falls flat compared to Dragonfall. Granted, several of Dragonfall's party members didn't have fleshed out stories until the Director's Cut update, but since it DOES have a Director's Cut update, that's what I have to compare Hong Kong to, and most of HK's party isn't as interesting comparatively. Duncan's story is hamstrung by the fact that it has to be tied into the main character's backstory; he doesn't have a defined history, you make up half of it as you go along, and that prevents him from being an interesting character in his own right. Gobbet's history is really only barely touched upon, and her personal mission, if you can refer to it as such, doesn't have much emotional weight (certainly not as much emotional weight as Glory's personal mission, and the comparison has to be made because of how similar the two are). is0bel is the most disappointing in this regard. Out of the entire cast she had the most potential to have an emotional effect on the player, but it's just squandered. Her personal mission happens before her storyline really even starts, killing any possibility of true connection or closure. Racter doesn't even really have his own mission, he simply requests to tag along on mission you already have, and his personal connection to the mission is barely there at all.

The story, however, makes up for the characters in many ways. The change in location to Hong Kong is welcome, given that both prior games had decidedly Western locations and aesthetics. Hong Kong brings with it a new subject in the form of qi, the lifeforce that drives much of Hong Kong's magic and forms a focal point for both the main story and several of the side missions. I was a little disappointed with how similar Heoi, the main city, was to the hub in Dragonfall. However, several of the characters are great. I especially liked Ambrose and Crafty Xu (fans of the series may be interested to note that Aljernon is NOT the proprietor of the magic shop in this title; I was never really a fan and much prefer Crafty Xu, personally). The main story fades into the background for large sections of the game while you run various jobs, which I felt was a little strange. Dragonfall set up the goal very early on, and every side job was a means to that end; while the missions were all disconnected, you knew why you were doing them and they all served a definite purpose to the main goal. In HK, you're basically just Shadowrunning because you have no other choice, and the missions you take have almost no bearing in any situation on the main story or your party's situation. And the ending is a major letdown, too.

Luckily, the gameplay is as good as ever, for the most part. There are tons of dialogue options available to the player (although this comes with its own negative, which I'll get into later), giving you the option to avoid several fights, if that's your prerogative. Many problems the game presents have several solutions; combat is always one of them, and often times it is a requirement, but not always. The difficulty curve is fair, keeping things entertaining with some level of difficulty, until about 75% of the way through the game where your party will simply power through everything if you've built it right. This is especially evident for the final boss fights, which were almost criminally easy.

However, the same targeting issues I've had with the series since Shadowrun Returns still haven't been fixed. Due to the game's isometric camera, it can be infuriatingly difficult at times to select the tile you're looking for. If the tile you want to move to is behind a crate and another character, you can spend a lot of time waving your mouse around trying to get the selector to acknowledge the tile and not the cover (or character) in front of it. I had really expected this to be fixed somehow by the third game. This wouldn't be as aggravating if the game had some way to reverse a command, but once your character moves you're stuck with whatever you've done; accidentally command your character to attack an enemy, when all you really wanted to do was move to the tile behind him, and you might find yourself unfairly down a Shadowrunner.

Another problem endemic to the series are the dialogue options. Earlier on I praised the game for giving you so many, but now I have to raise a gripe that I had with Returns and Dragonfall: the main character, in order to experience much of the dialog, is basically forced into leveling Charisma in order to get Etiquettes. Why is my main character FORCED into having Security etiquette if I want to use this speech option even though I have Duncan in the party? He's an ex-Lone Star, which is basically the police force; why can HE not bring up this rather obvious point? Why do I have to be the one to do it? Gobbett spends half of the game lording over you the fact that she's been Shadowrunning for years and you're a newbie; why do I have to choose this Shadowrunner Etiquette dialogue option while she's in the party? It's mind-boggling. Additionally, giving party members Etiquettes would add another layer of complexity into forming a party.

My next gripe is with the new decking mechanics. I understand why there was a call for a new format; decking in previous games was basically the exact same gameplay as the standard tactical combat (hide behind cover and shoot at enemies), and it shouldnt be. It should be different, and I applaud the decision and effort to shake it up. However, I feel the new mechanics are even worse. Decking is now, in large part, a stealth section; the decker moves around attempting to avoid entering the LoS of enemies; if one spots you, you enter combat, and if you're in combat long enough you set of a system alert (I'm simplifying it a little, but that's the gist). However, the game is NOT set up for stealth sections. They simply don't feel right. There's one stealth" section in one side mission
date: and that is redeemed (SLIGHTLY) by the fact that you can enter turn-based mode and therefore have more control over character movement and cover; this option is missing while decking
recommended: and this combined with the floaty movement end up causing you to enter combat far more often than you probably should. I was so annoyed with the new decking mechanics that I simply avoided decking where possible.\n\nI'll reiterate what I said in the opening: I really enjoyed HK. I enjoyed Dragonfall more
hoursPlayed: and I would point interested players to play that title first

reviewText:
The third installment of the Shadowrun Returns franchise, Hong Kong again captures the feel of the setting exceptionally well. The mechanics have been adjusted (mages have been rightfully nerfed and decking runs very differently now), and that's OK. The studio is making adjustments based upon how people have responded to the previous games. If Hong Kong suffers from anything (aside from numerous text bugs) it is that as the third game, its story formula is starting to feel stale. Where the story is still good, it is following the same pattern as before. That and copious extraneous text has actually left me bored and skipping text that I wouldn't have in an earlier game.

Also, decking needs to go. I really wasn't a fan of it in table top. It meant the GM dealt with one character exclusively while everyone else waited around. The computer game doesn't suffere from that. Instead it suffers from it being equal measures boring and frustrating. Sometimes there's just a dialog choice to hack an interface. This is wonderful because it moves the plot along and makes you feel like your karma (copious karma in this case) was well spent. A five to ten minute aside that climaxes in a ten key version of Simon just makes me want to skip decking altogether. And since decking is both so specialized and not a regular occurance, you are discouraged from playing that sort of a character rather than a straight combat monkey.

At the end of the day, if you like the Shadowrun world or you just like this style of game, then Shadowrun: Hong Kong is totally for you. If not, skip it.

reviewText:
After the awesomeness that was Dragonfall, Hong Kong really feels like a poor attempt at achieving the same glory and failing badly.

Systems wise, the game is the best in the series. The Matrix has been revamped, perhaps not entirely sucessfully, but it feels more dangerous and more exciting than the old Matrix system did where you were essentially a hacker god no matter what kind of deck you ran. Cyberware has been greatly expanded, allowing you to build a very cool street sam. Companions are now actually useful and can more than hold their own in combat, which means that your character finally does not have to focus so much attention on being able to kill everything in sight just to pick up the slack from your crappy team members. The missions seem to have more varied goals and other solutions, and take you through a nicely varied set of set pieces and some beautiful scenery. A lot of the fights in game can be bypassed through use of varied skills and etiquettes, and there are multiple outcomes to a lot of the scenarios. All of the NPCs also seem to have a bit more to say, so if you like reading a lot of lore and exposition, you'll be happy here. All of this is great. (The one sad thing is that Mages and Adepts are really still just kind of terrible, adepts especially. Why they can't come up with a way to make Mages as dangerous and powerful as they are in the PnP game is beyond me. It can't be THAT hard to put a 'drain' system into the unity engine, can it? Your mage is still just casting Haste and Aim on your street sams over and over again to be useful.)

Yet the problem with Hong Kong is its story. Throughout the entire game, it commits the most deadly of movie/game sins, in that it doesn't follow the Show me

reviewText:
More.

That's the emphasis compared to the previous Shadowrun games by Harebrained. More art, more space, more writing (a *lot* more writing), more choice, more flavor, more everything.

Hong Kong as a setting in this cyberpunk Shadowrun game is fleshed out incredibly well - the mix of corporate power, corruption, and eastern magic flows together intimately. The characters are superb, the world is more open in terms of design and mission choice compared to previous Shadowrun games...

Here and now, this is the best Shadowrun game to date. And one of the best games I've played in my life. The story is tight, the characters superb, the mission design and choices offered for social, magic, or combat are very well done. Oh, and the Matrix is evolved considerably.

HBS, you have far surpassed my expectations. If the planned mini-campaign of extra content is just as good or better, you'll have my appreciation for a long time to come.

reviewText:
So I was very impressed with this game's balance versus the last few.  The last few had issues with scaling difficulty, one fight would be a simple matter, the next would be like god himself wanted you to fail. LOL.

Also the matrix redesign is genius, I played through as a decker and loved every minute of it.  It's smart and well done for the most part, though I wish there weren't those auto aggressive rooms in the matrix to deal with.

It felt short to me, but I guess I can't complain when I only paid 20 bucks for the game.  I always have that sense of longing when I play a game that's not open world and RPG focused like this.  I spend so much time getting to know my characters and the world them am disappointed when it eventually ends.  But thus is life.

Overall a really good game, and I highly recommend it.

reviewText:
If you've played either of the other recent Shadowrun games from Harebrained Studios, then you basically know what to expect with this title. I can thoroughly recommend it to previous players, although I would say that, personally, I feel Dragonfall was the better game. And to interested parties who have never experienced a Shadowrun game before, I would say to go and try Dragonfall before trying Hong Kong: while I really enjoyed Hong Kong, I think a new player would get much more out of Dragonfall.

Shadowrun: Hong Kong plays like a rather standard tactical RPG. You create a main character, load him up with whatever stats you want (I prefer a gun-toting Bear Shaman, who can place barriers as personal cover to snipe from long distances, Haste himself to shoot up to two times more often per round, and use the Bear totem for the game's only AoE heal). You have a group of pre-determined party members, each with their own strengths and weaknesses. In addition, each mission provides you with a list of alternate Shadowrunners you can take instead of your standard party members, although why you would do this remains a mystery to me.

Said party members, I feel, are one of the ways Hong Kong falls flat compared to Dragonfall. Granted, several of Dragonfall's party members didn't have fleshed out stories until the Director's Cut update, but since it DOES have a Director's Cut update, that's what I have to compare Hong Kong to, and most of HK's party isn't as interesting comparatively. Duncan's story is hamstrung by the fact that it has to be tied into the main character's backstory; he doesn't have a defined history, you make up half of it as you go along, and that prevents him from being an interesting character in his own right. Gobbet's history is really only barely touched upon, and her personal mission, if you can refer to it as such, doesn't have much emotional weight (certainly not as much emotional weight as Glory's personal mission, and the comparison has to be made because of how similar the two are). is0bel is the most disappointing in this regard. Out of the entire cast she had the most potential to have an emotional effect on the player, but it's just squandered. Her personal mission happens before her storyline really even starts, killing any possibility of true connection or closure. Racter doesn't even really have his own mission, he simply requests to tag along on mission you already have, and his personal connection to the mission is barely there at all.

The story, however, makes up for the characters in many ways. The change in location to Hong Kong is welcome, given that both prior games had decidedly Western locations and aesthetics. Hong Kong brings with it a new subject in the form of qi, the lifeforce that drives much of Hong Kong's magic and forms a focal point for both the main story and several of the side missions. I was a little disappointed with how similar Heoi, the main city, was to the hub in Dragonfall. However, several of the characters are great. I especially liked Ambrose and Crafty Xu (fans of the series may be interested to note that Aljernon is NOT the proprietor of the magic shop in this title; I was never really a fan and much prefer Crafty Xu, personally). The main story fades into the background for large sections of the game while you run various jobs, which I felt was a little strange. Dragonfall set up the goal very early on, and every side job was a means to that end; while the missions were all disconnected, you knew why you were doing them and they all served a definite purpose to the main goal. In HK, you're basically just Shadowrunning because you have no other choice, and the missions you take have almost no bearing in any situation on the main story or your party's situation. And the ending is a major letdown, too.

Luckily, the gameplay is as good as ever, for the most part. There are tons of dialogue options available to the player (although this comes with its own negative, which I'll get into later), giving you the option to avoid several fights, if that's your prerogative. Many problems the game presents have several solutions; combat is always one of them, and often times it is a requirement, but not always. The difficulty curve is fair, keeping things entertaining with some level of difficulty, until about 75% of the way through the game where your party will simply power through everything if you've built it right. This is especially evident for the final boss fights, which were almost criminally easy.

However, the same targeting issues I've had with the series since Shadowrun Returns still haven't been fixed. Due to the game's isometric camera, it can be infuriatingly difficult at times to select the tile you're looking for. If the tile you want to move to is behind a crate and another character, you can spend a lot of time waving your mouse around trying to get the selector to acknowledge the tile and not the cover (or character) in front of it. I had really expected this to be fixed somehow by the third game. This wouldn't be as aggravating if the game had some way to reverse a command, but once your character moves you're stuck with whatever you've done; accidentally command your character to attack an enemy, when all you really wanted to do was move to the tile behind him, and you might find yourself unfairly down a Shadowrunner.

Another problem endemic to the series are the dialogue options. Earlier on I praised the game for giving you so many, but now I have to raise a gripe that I had with Returns and Dragonfall: the main character, in order to experience much of the dialog, is basically forced into leveling Charisma in order to get Etiquettes. Why is my main character FORCED into having Security etiquette if I want to use this speech option even though I have Duncan in the party? He's an ex-Lone Star, which is basically the police force; why can HE not bring up this rather obvious point? Why do I have to be the one to do it? Gobbett spends half of the game lording over you the fact that she's been Shadowrunning for years and you're a newbie; why do I have to choose this Shadowrunner Etiquette dialogue option while she's in the party? It's mind-boggling. Additionally, giving party members Etiquettes would add another layer of complexity into forming a party.

My next gripe is with the new decking mechanics. I understand why there was a call for a new format; decking in previous games was basically the exact same gameplay as the standard tactical combat (hide behind cover and shoot at enemies), and it shouldnt be. It should be different, and I applaud the decision and effort to shake it up. However, I feel the new mechanics are even worse. Decking is now, in large part, a stealth section; the decker moves around attempting to avoid entering the LoS of enemies; if one spots you, you enter combat, and if you're in combat long enough you set of a system alert (I'm simplifying it a little, but that's the gist). However, the game is NOT set up for stealth sections. They simply don't feel right. There's one stealth" section in one side mission
date: and that is redeemed (SLIGHTLY) by the fact that you can enter turn-based mode and therefore have more control over character movement and cover; this option is missing while decking
recommended: and this combined with the floaty movement end up causing you to enter combat far more often than you probably should. I was so annoyed with the new decking mechanics that I simply avoided decking where possible.\n\nI'll reiterate what I said in the opening: I really enjoyed HK. I enjoyed Dragonfall more
hoursPlayed: and I would point interested players to play that title first

reviewText:
Shortish version first (because that's more useful than at the end):
SR:HK keeps most of the qualities of the previous games, largely following the standard set by Dragonfall both in terms of gameplay, characters and the quality of its writing. It improves on various aspects of the previous games, including richer graphics and deeper gameplay mechanics (with more varied cyberware, drones and magic as some examples), and well crafted missions. Unfortunately, the overall narrative feels a little weaker than Dragonfall's, and the early versions of the game (as completed on build 3.0.5) contain a lot of minor bugs, that while not game-breaking, can put a damper on the enjoyment.

Regardless: highly recommended for fans of the first two games, and already well worth a consideration for anyone looking for a solidly-written cRPG, especially if you're interested in the Shadowrun setting or cyberpunk in general. For everyone else, maybe wait for a few more bugfixes, the release of the mini-expansion and/or an eventual Director's Cut".

reviewText:
Don't think that you can breeze through combat because you've mastered XCOM. Hit percentages are perpetually low (point blank with shotgun/sword = ~65%?) and the flanking mechanic makes no sense.

Don't think that you can min-max your character and play an ugly â™¥â™¥â™¥ troll so you can put more skill points into damage. You need around 8 Charisma to get through the game without tripping alarms everywhere.

Don't think that you can go on a mission without a Decker lest you be tormented by what goodies could have been nabbed from behind that jackpoint.

Don't play this game if you don't like reading flowery text.

Don't brush off that little orange triangle on the bottom right of your screen. That's where you level up your team.

Don't think that Gobbet's gun will do any damage.

Don't think that Is0bel's won't.

Regardless, I quite liked this game. Enjoyed returning on other playthroughs to see what I missed the first time around. Though I am hoping there are better ones of its like somewhere out on Steam.

reviewText:
The game itself is nice and I like this futuristic sci-fi fantasy stuff ... but:

NEGATIVES:
* Why are there no translations available? This game is 100% text based. Is it that difficult to translate?
* The leveling-system for the character looks very boring and feels pretty unfinished. Why did you change the last one?
* The game itself has not really improved ... I don't expect a game to be totally different to the previous ones ... but a little enhancement would be very nice.
* Why is the text/dialogsystem on the right side? If I play full hd on my monitor then I have to move my eyes from one side to another to follow the dialog and scenery. I mean ... in any other rpg etc. the dialog is on the bottom and it's fine this way.
* Text is sometimes to long for a single dialog ... especially if you are in hurry (school or work) and can not save in between.
* How does the save-system work? I nearly never am able to save the game except I exit it. If this is how it's meant to be ... so why don't just use an autosave-checkpoint-system during whole game?
* Do I see some propagandistic tries to connect russia with the ukraine? Such stuff does not belong into a game. (The guy living under your room who tells this funny fairytale about the european war.) Or is it this way in the books? This one I am really not sure about.

POSITIVES:
* Atmosphere is A+ ... the environment is pretty nice.
* The characters seem to be worked out very well (not fully finished the game).
* The story is (till now) very interesting.
* The hacking stuff for the decker is super ... but I nearly always triggered some of the security drones (maybe too difficult for the strange controls)

These seems to be some minor topics ... but if you played the other both games then you will see that it somehow sucks that the game seems not to improve. If it stays this way in the future ... I won't buy it.

EDIT:
I'm not sure about this game ... it looks more like an community MOD or something. I won't say it is bad ... but not worth the full price.
Maybe I'm just too stupid for this game but why am I not able to upgrade the weapons etc. of my teammates? I was a shaman and bought some ESPs for my decker ... but I was not able to replace the existing ones. Is it supposed to be this way?

In my opinion this sequel is the worst of all the three ... but not bad. It's okay. I wish there were a little more improvements (like building/equipt the ship - your base - etc. ... making new rooms).

Aw yeah ... I figured out that you can not save while any of your characters is moving. And one thing I don't understand:
* What is the difference between Rewinding and Loading a savegame? I tried both some times and I ended up restarting the whole level ... yeah ... nice ... T.T

reviewText:
Shadowrun Hong Kong, a game I helped to Kickstart after thoroughly enjoying both Shadowrun Returns and the incredibly good Dragonfall campaign.

Currently I'm some fifteen hours in and this is like living up to the Dragonfall experience all over again, the same core elements are there. The storytelling and the writing, an interesting locale and of course the companions who all have their own stories and backgrounds.
The runs themselves are much the same, with different solutions and variables playing out, you can go in loud or you can try and play things out quietly. You can be the 'good' guy or the bad guy, whichever you prefer.

Everything else is more or less the same or improved. Some new gear for all sorts of classes, I'm sure adepts will find the new weapon additions interesting. And as for cyberware, well.. hand razors, spurs and even monofilament whips are in, street samurais rejoice? Graphics are updated, backgrounds and the environments are still amazing.

And while I'm sure there's all sort of needs for fixes and such, I haven't encountered anything game-breaking or bothersome so far, in fact, I think it's a more solid piece of work than the original Dragonfall release which did suffer from some bugs.

The biggest complaint I have is that.. well.. the game will eventually end.. and I want more. I just want more! :p

I hope Harebrained Schemes will push out an expansion/add-on/possible directors cut version again in future.. and Ihope they'll keep working on the Shadowrun title, because they know how to treat the franchise.

So, a solid yes on recommendation. If you enjoyed Shadowrun Returns or Dragonfall, this game is definitely for you!

reviewText: Let me first say, I love Dragonfall. It was a fabulous game and I pre-ordered Hong Kong anticipating a similar experience. However, as some others have correctly pointed out -- Hong Kong's balance between interactive reading and actual gameplay is dramatically lopsided to me. I love a good story and the game does well to pull you into its world and characters. However, my karma points, weapons, armor and cyberware feel almost pointless as the last two missions I've accepted -- and completed -- were done without any need for them. Both missions were completed by clicking between endless dialogue windows between characters.\n\nWhile it makes for sometimes intriguing story-telling, it does little to satisfy my interest in video game interactivity. So far, it's been little more than a choose-your-own adventure book with some beautiful static artwork. Even stranger is that for a game that chooses to focus so heavily on written word, there are a remarkable amount of typos, missing words and other seemingly obvious grammatical errors. To me, Dragonfall struck a better balance between story-telling and interactive gameplay than Hong Kong seems to (so far). I will say, I have not finished Hong Kong (I'm 35+ hours in) as I'm finding it a little difficult to do so at this point. However, should I complete it and discover a different result, I will gladly modify my review and recommend it. I will say, if you haven't yet played Dragonfall, you owe it to yourself to do so!

reviewText:
Still quite early on, but as things stand this is, if anything, even superior to Dragonfall. Of particular note is the huge number of etiquette/skill dependent dialogue options. These etiquettes were rarely used in Dragonfall, but almost every conversation in HK seems to feature multiple special options.  The Matrix has also been revamped, with gameplay there now allowing you to try and stealth your way through systems - a very welcome change.

The new crew are well written and engaging - I was skeptical that they could match DF's party, but they've managed superbly. Gobbet is lots of fun, and the brotherly camaraderie with Wu is something you don't often see in RPGs which are usually bogged down in melodrama and brooding.

The art and design are all lavish, the environments sprawling and a delight to explore (DF might seem rather drab and cramped in retrospect), and missions so far are offering many varied options for completion ranging from fighting, talking, or simply bypassing threats through manipulation of the environment.

There are one or two bugs - a few conversations which seem to be misfiring, saying you screwed up a run when you didn't (no actual gameplay impact here), but I'm sure these will be ironed out quickly. Beyond that I don't have a bad word to say.

I you've played the previous SRR games you know what you're in for - but this experience is honed and refined almost to perfection (I would appreciate more meatspace stealth, but I believe even that is in this game later on). If you're new to SR this is a fine point to jump into the series. Highly recommended.

reviewText: Short and sweet thoughts: more of what I loved and wanted from previous SR:R titles, with progressive, albeit baby steps, towards improving the team system. Truly another labor of love and care that exceeds mere expansion status, while still not yet radically improving upon the existing formula to make a next-level product. Detractors of previous SR:R titles won't likely find enough reason to give Hong Kong a shot; fans of the methodology behind Dragonfall - Director's Cut 's collective design goals will find plenty to keep them happy for the duration. Prepare for heavy reading.\n\nEDIT: I simply -must- also mention that, as of 8-21-15, there are an alarming number of odd gramatical errors at numerous points of character dialogue, from duplicate words, to incorrect plural usage to entirely wrong words all together. Fortunately, not to the extent of wrecking immersion, plot understanding or game functionality, but for as experienced and seasoned a writing team as can be found at Harebrained Studios, these flubs are cropping up more frequently than I would personally be comfortable with seeing, coming from a professional game development studio and writing team.

First off I'd like to thank HBS for making a wounderful game. They updated and improved just about everything from the last game. Graphics are much better, no more hunched over bridge troll or Orc males. Better sound. From the background music to the sound of gun shots far better. Normaly I just pass them by and skip all the dialoge to get to the action, but I am drawn so far into the story I just can't. All and all, it is by FAR the best game HBS has put out. Again thanks to HBS

reviewText:
I am only 4 hours in but I'm already enjoying Shadowrun: Hong Kong far more than the original Shadowrun Returns. The UI is much cleaner and usable. The addition of free party members with interesting backstories is very welcome - they actually feel like they have personalities and I want to keep them alive and take them on runs with me whenever possible. The story is much more engaging from the start and I really like how you can craft your own backstory through dialogue options with Duncan - your foster brother. The matrix runs are much more interesting and have puzzle, sort of platforming and stealth elements. There is a much bigger diversity of sidequest runs that do not directly impact the main quest, and those for the most part are enjoyable. I also really liked the support for a street monk subclass, I'm definitely going to be playing one the second time through! The final positive note is the music (har har). I love the new soundtrack, it's very moody and often fits the theme of a particular run perfectly - it reminds me of Deus Ex and Vampire: Requiem soundtracks a lot.

On the negative side there still isn't a great diversity of gear (rifle, better rifle, even better rifle, cyberdeck, better cyberdeck, and so on), there isn't a whole lot of new gear or spells either, although I like the look of some of the new drones. A lot of art assets are recycled (sometimes bizzarely so - what is a Berlin parking booth doing in Hong Kong?), but overall the game looks crisp.

Tl;dr If you liked Shadowrun Returns, you will love Shadowrun HK. It is better in every way. If you haven't played Shadowrun Returns, I highly recommend playing Shadowrun HK instead.

reviewText:
Since SR:R I always vote these games 10/10 even before they come out. Therefore the expectations for SR:HK were high and I can't really say if the following list of mostly disappointments is a valid evaluation of the game. While reading please keep in mind that I rated the previous SR games exremely highly and had, due to the success on Kickstarter, the believe that this would get rid of some of the quirks of the previous game, but instead added some.

Matrix: The best comes first. I was shocked, positiveley, how well you can do the matrix. I really thought what we had in previous games was good enough, given the scenario and the game engine limitations. This is so much more fun. It feels intense. And you really need to apply some skills software developers and hackers need to employ, like recognizing patterns, looking for that one spot that isn't covered by your assertions (or IC) yet, and memorizing seemingly irrelevant details like numbers. There is also real skill involved, because sometimes the spot that is not covered by the watchers is dynamic and you need to move on fast to really not be spotted. The sounds for the number pad at first are really confusing which stopped me from getting more than 4 numbers. But after you get used to them they start to help you and you can sometimes complete the number game, even though it's not really necessary for the pattern game that follows. A huge plus, this whole new matrix thing. I'm so happy I played a decker.

Size: All the SR games are way too short. Maybe because of my expectations this one felt the shortest. The missions are very short, often just contain one little quirk and then you are done with it. You don't have enough character dialogues for all the missions. And how many missions were that, 10? When all the dialogues were finished and I could head out to the final mission there were about 3 or 4 runs left. But I felt like I just warmed up and started. All RPGs are rather boring in the beginning. Only after you develop some of your skills and get some better items you can really start playing. But that's when you were almost finished. Due to the sucess of Kickstarter and co I can't understand that.

Story: It's basically the story from SR:R. Even the endboss looks like a bug. After the runs were finished it got really really boring for me and I just wanted to be done with it. That's the first time this happened in SR to me. Sad.

Characters: I like to take a Shaman on every run. Because of that and the general dialogues Gobbet was basically the only character I really liked here. If the rest lives or dies, I can't say.

Fights: They were also quite boring. In every fight with the end boss I killed in at most 3 rounds. Maybe it's time to play on higher difficulty, I don't know.

Environment: Maybe it's because the Shadowrun Pen&Paper designers didn't know about China and HK, but the representation is much worse than with Berlin. Simplified Chinese characters here, wrong characters there. Everything looks like a Chinarestaurant in the US, not like China. Some of the jokes are a copy&paste from the internet, some even are jokes that foreigners make about Chinese not jokes that Chinese people make. I don't know. Getting an HK intern to do your due diligence on the language and cultural stuff is quite cheap. Why do people never do it?

RPG Engine: Can't say, because I only completed my character only about 60% percent. But it seems at least from the items there is not more to get. There was one better uniform to buy than what I had, but there was only one opportunity. Money and Karma wasn't even close to enough to get done with my char.

Replayability: For me, none. The game isn't free enough to try different things. It feels really scripted. You can choose between different paths, but each one of them is layed out clearly in front of you and often has no real impact on the result.




Conclusion: For me it was not a good game. Just something I finished because I'm a real fan of SR world and the previous games. The new Matrix was top, but nearly everything else was mamahuhu". I really hope there will be a Dragonfall version with that Matrix though. I can't choose to give no opinion if I recommend it
date: so I can only give my personal opinion which is: I can't recommend it. Objectively it might be worth it. Can't say."

reviewText:
TL&DR: Fan of the previous shadowrun games? y: buy this game, n: buy the older (cheaper) versions to see if you like it, the core mechanics have not chagned., nor the graphics.

What a story. It's right up there with the previous versions. Top notch writing, the music blending perfectly with the portrayed atmosphere. The game really makes you think about the choices you have your characters making to the point of actually feeling bad for some of the choices you're forced to make.

The atmosphere is amazing, parts of the game are really terrifying if you keep up with the reading and have the in-game sound on.

It's not all sunshine and rainbows though. It took me exactly 13.9 hours on focusing on the main story line to finish this game. So it's pretty short. I've not gone out of my way to rush the game so it's definitively on the short side for those who are experienced shadow runners.

I've also got mixed feelings about the innovations, or lack thereof, in SRHK. I understand that on some level the creators want to stay true to the previous versions, and not break much with what is obviously a winning formula. There's nothing wrong with that. But I do feel that there is too little iterative improvement in this version. I mean that while it's ok to leave the game's fundamentals as they are, it's not ok to have them stagnate and age. I would have very much liked to see more quantitative improvements: more spells, more guns, more enemies, more effects, more locations, etc.

None of these improvements would have impeded or changed the series' main draw and mechanics.

All in all this is a top notch game in my option. But I hope that the next story will have some definitive expansion in terms of scope and quantity of content.
