reviewText:
Shadowrun Hong Kong Review
Let me just start by establishing that shadowrun already has one of the richest fantasy universes in all of tabletop/rpg gaming. Their successful blend of cyberpunk, corporate espionage, and traditional fantasy elements gives it a lore vastly superior to most games. This game successfully builds on this creating once again an immersive setting which will hook you from the get go.

It features an epic story line which combines familiar elements from a known world setting to a dystopian future. A crew comprised of well fleshed out party members with their own motivations which sometimes tangle with your own and at other times branch out into over the top side missions. I also must commend the developers of the game on paying attention to details when it comes to your party members who will all have their own specific dialogue and interactions on each different mission. They also can turn out very different depending on your characters interactions with them. That's somewhere that I notice a lot of RPG's cheap out.

Your character has many diverse builds and can rely on hacking and charisma as much as combat prowess and magical ability. The best part remains the customizing of your body through cybernetically enhanced synthetic body parts. Nothing like getting rid of your pathetic normal eyeballs in favor of accuracy enhancing sniper cyborg eyes or getting rid of your soft humanoid skin in favor of a bullet proof carapace.

The combat is still very similar to Dragonfall and the original which is a good thing. Think X-com with a smaller budget its fast paced turn based tactics make it seem like a superhuman swat team basically going from floor to floor in gang ridden neighborhoods and evil corporate labs. On the downside the AI could use a few tweaks it sometimes does stupid things like go out of it's way to gain cover midway through it's turn when it will ultimately finish it's turn elsewhere, thus wasting valuable actions points. If you're familiar at all with the games I'd recommend playing it on hard to compensate for the AI lacking in the decision making department.

The new matrix(alternate world when hacking) feels a lot smoother and polished than in the previous iterations. It's more stealth based and differentiates better from regular combat. I'd recommend playing the game as a decker(hacker) because to get the most opportunities and rewards from the game you need a hacker on every single mission yet the hacker that joins your crew is depressingly boring while the rest of your crew are memorable and fun.

As a final note I'd like to tip my hat to harebrain schemes who basically have resurrected a dead franchise, produced three high quality affordable games from it. Games that always feel fresh and better than the previous one. All that on a crowdfunded budget which is a fraction of what bigger studios who most of the time make uninspired sequels with generic stories who don't interest anyone. 9/10

reviewText:
Shadowrun Hong Kong Review
Let me just start by establishing that shadowrun already has one of the richest fantasy universes in all of tabletop/rpg gaming. Their successful blend of cyberpunk, corporate espionage, and traditional fantasy elements gives it a lore vastly superior to most games. This game successfully builds on this creating once again an immersive setting which will hook you from the get go.

It features an epic story line which combines familiar elements from a known world setting to a dystopian future. A crew comprised of well fleshed out party members with their own motivations which sometimes tangle with your own and at other times branch out into over the top side missions. I also must commend the developers of the game on paying attention to details when it comes to your party members who will all have their own specific dialogue and interactions on each different mission. They also can turn out very different depending on your characters interactions with them. That's somewhere that I notice a lot of RPG's cheap out.

Your character has many diverse builds and can rely on hacking and charisma as much as combat prowess and magical ability. The best part remains the customizing of your body through cybernetically enhanced synthetic body parts. Nothing like getting rid of your pathetic normal eyeballs in favor of accuracy enhancing sniper cyborg eyes or getting rid of your soft humanoid skin in favor of a bullet proof carapace.

The combat is still very similar to Dragonfall and the original which is a good thing. Think X-com with a smaller budget its fast paced turn based tactics make it seem like a superhuman swat team basically going from floor to floor in gang ridden neighborhoods and evil corporate labs. The new matrix(alternate world when hacking) feels a lot smoother and polished than in the previous iterations. It's more stealth based and differentiates better from regular combat. I'd recommend playing the game as a decker(hacker) because to get the most opportunities and rewards from the game you need a hacker on every single mission yet the hacker that joins your crew is depressingly boring while the rest of your crew are memorable and fun.

reviewText:
If you're into narratives, this is the game for you.

Pros
> The characters are wonderful, and not just your team mates. NPCs have their own personalities and storylines rather than just being shopkeeper A and B. Cast very diverse, and that's always a plus for me.

Cons

> Text heavy. Although some lore is fun to read, some convos just drag on a lot. A few formatting and grammar errors here and there.

Overall, an absolute delight. 4/5

reviewText:
A deep and compelling story, exactly what you would expect from the nitty gritty world of Shadowrun. The devs learned a great deal from their first run in this world, and it shows.

First off, the combat of the game has changed very little from the previous Shadowrun. It didn't need to. It already provided what it needed and was robust enough, if breakable.

Where this game truly shines is the decisions you make, and the story you participate in. It. Is. INCREDIBLE. Unlike the original, you are not railroaded into combat and over-arching decisions. I am currently playing as a charismatic shaman with an acedmic and scholarly backgrounds, with the intent of smooth-talking through most of my problems. And I can!! And I've seen many options that other builds could explore but I could not, BUT! I've done 4 missions so far, and I've really only had 1-2 fights outside of the tutorial start. I've been able to bluff, lie, negotiate and silver-tongue my way to victory almost every time!

And the depth of the characters is just INCREDIBLE. I actually timed myself and I will spend an hour just running around talking to people. Everyone's got a story, everyone's got a background, and they all convey it in their own way. It is just obscenely great.

I can't comment on the Hong Kong in the game too much, because I know I'm only scratching the surface right now. Hopefully someone will remind me 300 hours in to finish up this review.

Get this game and enjoy it. ;)

reviewText:
It is another Shadowrun game. I must admit however, that even though I really enjoyed Dragonfall (playing through it twice - upon original release and later the directors cut) Shadowrun Hong Kong just didn't click for me. It might be that I am simply tired with the same formula and engine, or that recent excellent and more ambitious RPG like Pillars of Eternity & Wasteland 2 make me want a more complex game.

The good stuff - there are many tweaks to the game which are welcome. The UI is much better this time around. You can also enter turn based combat mode at will, so if you spot an enemy you can set up and get a drop on them. There is also the new decking system however it does not bring changes I hope for. It would be nice if decking allowed player to interact with enviroment in some interesting way, but all it changed is the way Matrix works on the inside. It plays a bit like a stealth game but it is very basic and not very fun.

The story is weaker than in DF. You end up chasing after a person you never met ingame, which makes it very difficult to care about him. It doesn't help that writing isn't as tight. reviewText: I am a fan of the series. Very disappointing. I've played about nine missions and eight of them were bugged. I only got through the first three missions before several missions were made in-completable due to buggy programming and the game made unplayable. These were fixed in the first patch but, but considering these early missions were so badly broken, they should have been fixed before release. On several occasions the character tabs for all but one team member disappeared from the UI during combat. The matrix looks better but the new mechanics are ridiculous. For instance you can buy a program to reduce alert status but it takes several rounds to use again and, unlike every other program in your kit, doesn't reset once matrix combat has finished. The next matrix combat can start several minutes later and you've still got seven rounds before you can use this programme to reduce your threat level. Your matrix avatar glides, as opposed to walking at the same pace as your non-matrix character in the first two games, at such a slow pace defence programs can over take it initiating raised alert status and combat, and clicking on some points of the flooring can be faulty producing no movement whatsoever. Some of the mission and level design is poor. All I've done for three nights since it's release is consistently swear at my computer and have hot showers to release endorphins in order to cool down. Younger gamers might accept this situation, but after forty years of being a gamer a brand spanking new release in a series by a respected production house shouldn't have this many problems at the time of it's release. Again, considering how good Shadowrun and Shadowrun Dragonfall were, very disappointing. I'm hoping several more patches will rectify many of the problems I have with SHK. Not up to Hairbrained Schemes usual standards. 3/5

reviewText:
I thought Dragonfall was a step down from DMS due to it being longwinded.  The strategic element of this degenerates things even further.  I should not call it strategy...I should call it economic management.  You have 2 choices: 1) Specialize to the hilt and only partly play a role in your party or 2) Be so inept that you have to rely completely on your party.  Your fellow shadowrunners are far more powerful than you are so you are basically the face of your group rather than being a part of it.

The reason you must specialize is not the reason you might think either.  Most of the time it is because of Karma...not so this time.  This time there are 2 factors.  The first and biggest reason is money...there is just not enough for you to load out your character with better gear to make use of the skills you have if you try to split specialities.  Even as a specialist if you make a mistake choosing gear it could take you 2-3 runs just to correct that mistake.  The second is the badly scaled missions.  You are offered missions...but who knows if you are actually god enough to do them.  You either have an easy time of it or get your face ripped off and find yourself respecing and redoing content.  This is a save fest game.

The story is fragmented and does not really flow like the previous two.  It is open ended but so much so that you really don't have a focal point.  You are constantly pushed away from your RPG plot goal by NPCs who are dismissive and disgruntled.  Lots and lots of text to red through...a lot of which has nothing to with the main story or any missions, as well as plot lines that go nowhere.

Verdict: Buy on sale.  I am glad I did not kickstart this.  I think HBS should stick to the story telling and let somoene else deal with the rest of the games design.

reviewText:
Sorry if you are looking foward to an experience at least similar to SR: Dragonfall. SR: Hong Kong's story is shallow. Choice of dialogue hardly matters at all: NPCs will go on and on about their backstories in walls of text with lots of unimportant and overdetailed info about the SR setting. And that's coming from a tabletop rpg player.

Good luck moving (real-time action!) stealthly in the all new, different and awful hacking system, where it's still hard to correctly click on tiles behind walls or elements (and the idea here is to stay hidden!). Hacking is memory minigames now. Turn-based? Mostly when things already went wrong. Seriously, you MUST look for some video and check it out yourself before buying this game.

Mission design is horribly done. Things like a NPC saying that just sent me a message about a job and asks me later, after I checked that nothing arrived (dial-up internet in my cyberpunk?), IF I ALREADY READ IT? Can't call that a bug. That's poor execution. Leaves the impression nobody tried beta-testing this. It's a shame. For now I'll wait for a couple of months and start a new game from scratch.

reviewText:
While not bad, this was my least favorite of the series, the story is marginal and unfolds poorly, I had hoped this one would be more open like the 16 bit era games meaning more open ended(like some awesome stuff on the creator), and after 3 games in a row there are some lingering issues that should have been fixed by now(hit percentages and dialogue options that give you five way of saying the same thing). Like many have said this game is overly texty especially in the beginning, and you're forced to shift through tons of text that has little impact on the game(I'm all for details but not forced on the player the way this game does it).

I also wasn't huge on the improvements to the Matrix(The hacking mini game inside the hacking mini game is just annoying) and the karma interface(It was nice being able to see everything at once). Overall some of the tweaks were nice(the new chain shot spell is awesome), but I wish they had spent more time making inventory management less of a chore). Also, the attempt as stealth does't really work and sometimes when you enter combat you'll find half your team nowhere close to you which makes the movement extremely frustrating.

However, some of the missions were pretty good, the music is top notch, They hit the nail on the head with the improved cyberware system, and at one point I had a vampire and ghoul on my team biting demons to death which was quite enjoyable.

Overall I was disappointed, Dragonfall was a great evolution from Returns but this one is just kinda trading water. On the bright side I'm sure some people will make some awesome stuff with the creator, but Dragonfall already has TONS of good content with a better campaign.

reviewText:
To me this is a serious disappointment after the Berlin run which was a lot more imaginative. I can't see much of the magic overhaul that was promised beforehand, and the changes in the Matrix simply make the game boring and tedious instead of adding more flair. The campaign is a lot less intricate and addictive than Seattle or Berlin. I miss the tiny tidbits of information being hidden in interesting background stories. The odd sidequest within a level. The odd extra loot you could get for being familiar with some obscure etiquette.
Whether I'd recommend the game: sure. For if you like Shadowrun this series is your only option. However, if you're new to the world and new to this series: start with the two other campaigns. They're much more fun. Less bugs. And cheaper, too.

reviewText:
The great thing about a having a sequel that reuses an easily customizable RPG engine is that the developers can concentrate entirely on writing and quest content, which are generally the strongest parts of the genre. I've played Shadowrun Returns before this and it's easy to see how immersion and character building has greatly improved thanks to this increased focus on storytelling.

Each of your main companions have interesting and varied backgrounds, can have detailed conversations with you after every mission you take, and eventually grow as individuals as the story progresses. My favorite is Racter- a reserved, pragmatic rigger who can be pressed into revealing having such extremist views on the future of humanity that he could have easily filled in as a sympathetic supervillain in another game. Seeing my relationships with these characters grow and learning about their history was one of the biggest draws for me to keep progressing. Ironically, you also have the option to ignore these character stories entirely and focus entirely on missions- don't do this or you will miss a great deal of the game's content! This is a game for slow enjoyment, not rushing around mowing down enemies as quickly as possible.

However, people who do like Shadowrun's mishmash of magic and gunplay will find plenty to enjoy here. Gone are the long, grueling combat gauntlets and gimmicky boss fights of Shadowrun Returns, mainly replaced by short but intense firefights centered around interesting environmental pieces. The vast majority of combat in the game can be entirely avoided, and since your companions are more than capable of standing up to enemies at any point in the game you can feel free to upgrade your main character entirely into diplomatic/non-combat skills if you so choose. Or if you want to effortlessly kill everyone, be an Elf and invest all your Karma points into Quickness and Ranged Weapons. Seriously, no amount of reality warping magic and techological wizardry can match an ungodly accurate guy with an assault rifle.

I really liked all the creative ways the player can infiltrate corporations and trick NPCs during quests. However I think the game drops the ball a bit here by making combat much easier than it ever was in Returns or most other RPGs. Enemies tend to rarely be much of a threat except in huge numbers, and you generally can get away with mindlessly charging an enemy's defensive position instead of trying to intelligently make use of the environment. Compare this to a game like Wasteland 2 where trying to rush down a sniper will get your characters killed in a hurry. Sure, this isn't supposed to be a combat focused game, but it takes out a lot of the reward in trying to outsmart and avoid a group of guards when I can easily just mow them down without any consequence.

Overall this is a fun RPG with great quests and characters that suffers from being way too easy in terms of combat and a lack of replayability. If you're the type of player who enjoys reading a lot of dialogue and finding creative solutions to quests you will probably enjoy this game quite a bit.

reviewText:
As a fan of the Pen and Paper version I absolutely love this game. If you are a fan of the lore and don't hate cRPGs, then this is money well spent. If you liked the first two games, then this is money well spent.
After my first playthrough I can say, that the game entertained me greatly all the way through, even though the story was kind of predictable after some point. Nonetheless engaging and the writing is excellent. So overall I love most about everything about this game, but there are some minor nitpicks.
Please bear in mind that I played on hard, if you're playing it on a lower difficulty your experience may vary.

The MatrixThe matrix got an overhaul. Even though I was one of the few that liked the matrix in the old games, I still think this is an improvement. However, there are some things that might put people off. Note that I have not yet played a PC decker, the experience may therefore vary.
Movement in stealth sections is way to imprecise
isometric view can obscure important details in stealth sections.
No access to programs in stealth sections.
No possibility to get into combat-mode without getting caught first.
The Blocker-IC minigame can become kind of irritating after a while.
Is0bels matrix accuracy is way to low...
The DifficultyIt is way to easy. I played on hard and finished the game as a Face (max. Charisma, all etiquettes) with some cyberware and some rifle-skill in about 27 hours. There wer only very few parts of the game where I felt actually challenged. And I am someone who seldom finnishes a game, even less so on the hardest possibility. The most bothersome thing was the grenade-love of NPCs, and you can get past that quite easily with a nice little cyberarm. The only thing, that was remotely challenging was the matrix and that is most likely only because I had to use Is0bel, who is only okay at matrix combat.
I have now started another playthrough, where I changed to normal difficulty, just to check things out and because I wanted to build an even less optimized character (burn-out adept-cyberweapon-shaman-grenade girl). It is ridiculously easy...

The Loading TimeLoading times are long. Really long, and tehy got progressively worse. I had up to 30 seconds of black space before a loading screen even appeared. And when you're reloading your quicksave over and over again, because Is0bel screwed up in the matrix, but you want to get it just perfect, then you're going to wait. A lot. I think I can attribute at least one hour of my playtime, only to loading screens.

The Small StuffOne nitpick of mine is the fact, that when you start up a drone, the controlls automatically switch to the drone. I can't even remember how often I have tried to relocate Racter after activating Koshei and relocating Koshei instead. But that was also the problem in the previous games, so that's old news.

The Good StuffWell, I already said, that I actually love most all of this game, but there are some things that stand out.
The writing. It's good. It's real good. At least on the same level as in Dragonfall. I can't really decide which one I like more.
The ability to engage combat-mode before the enemy sees you. Glorious, wouldn't want to miss that anymore.
The stealthy matrix. It might have problems in the execution, but the overall feel is just right.

reviewText:
I'm disappointed. Don't get me wrong, i still like the game and if you're familliar with its predecessors and enjoyed them, then you'll like this game too - but maybe with the same sense of 'if only' that i have after wading through it.

Finally, the game mechanics run smoothly with no gaping omissions or unfinished corners (though I found the new matrix 'run & dodge' more irritating than fun). The art is pleasing but the text side of the game (not necessarily the story itself) is like some socially inept bore at a party who pins you to the wall with tedious rhetoric only he finds interesting and has no comprehension of actual conversation. There's so much useless text in this game that my eyes glazed over far too quickly, and i generally like text heavy games. For mood, theme and function (and it was the lack of the last that was particularly notable) presented in text, Baldur's Gate or Planescape Torment this is not. Hong Kong's predecessors were tight and slick in their text use and storytelling while Hong Kong just isn't, it becomes a laborious 'click through' that swamps the better features of what could have been the best iteration of Shadowrun by Harebrained yet.

Ultimately, its the editing of the game that is flawed, not the game itself. What a shame. Still, at least it /has/ a good plot and two dimensional characters in gaming are always better than the conventional one. I also think that this game will be much more palatable on a tablet rather than hunched in front of a desktop. Something i think proved true of the other two games too, so maybe wait for that... Of course then you probably won't have access to the user content again if you do.

reviewText:
I find myself continually impressed by Harebrained. As I havenâ€™t played the table-top / P&P Shadowrun, I can only speak to the game itself. (TL;DR: Skip to last sentence)

The Shadowrun Returns series have brought me back to enjoying overhead sprite based games. Since the early Fallout games, Iâ€™ve never found RPGs with this style to be particularly engaging.
As the latest iteration of the Shadowrun Returns games, Hong Kong provides a lot of polish and features that were missing while improving upon the foundation that was already pruned from the previous two games. This is not to say it is perfect, but Iâ€™ll touch on that in a bit.

The characters you run with are quite interesting. Iâ€™d say that they kept a lot of the improvements from Returns to Dragonfall in this new game. How do these characters compete with Dragonfallâ€™s? The conclusion I come to here is that your perception of this depends upon your personality. Iâ€™d say it was an improvement (especially since there are more character to get to know), but perhaps some may find them slightly less engaging than before.

New skills have been added that, I felt, increased the immersion. They allowed for greater specialization and seem to level the field for greater viability between classes. On that note, cyberware as a whole has seen a massive facelift which made me very excited.

The matrix has been revamped and personally, I love it. I have heard the complaints concerning the difficulty of some tasks within the matrix, but I found the difficulty refreshing and overcoming it equally satisfying. It is worth mentioning that it doesnâ€™t seem to be common knowledge that you can skip pieces of these puzzles by hitting the â€œnextâ€ button. While it increases the challenge of the following section, I usually found that final section easier than the rest of the â€œmemory testâ€ combined.

The story and atmosphere are, once again, to die for. For me, this is the real appeal of these games and Hong Kong is absolutely no exception. If magic seems a stretch in a cyberpunk universe, I promise, these games make it feel right at home in the dark, seedy, grimy world of dystopian cyberpunk. Further, I would strongly assert that the addition of magic adds significantly to the universe. Its addition makes the universe feel that much more uncontrollable (yet very tightly controlled), dark, and dangerous.

I wonâ€™t try to tell you that the game is flawless. There are certainly bugs and problems--I havenâ€™t experienced nearly as many as some and I beat the game before the first major patch was announced so I donâ€™t believe they are as prolific as some claim--but many of these have been patched out.
*Edit: On my second playthrough, I have noticed quite a few more bugs. Most of them have no effect on gameplay.

The biggest complaint I can offer you (which is a meagre gripe in comparison to the gameâ€™s merits) is that it is text based instead of being voice acted. For its predecessors, I didnâ€™t see this as a flaw in the slightest because the dialogue was either minimal or very engaging. In this game, while the dialogue retains its very interesting dialogue, there is simply so much of it that I sometimes found it difficult to want to speak to many of the NPCs and simply gave priority to the ones who I found interesting. As a counter to my own complain though, I do like that I didnâ€™t spend all my time talking to every single NPC in the small little village of a home as that felt closer to real life. So, ultimately, Iâ€™m conflicted on the matter.
*Edit: Aside from this, the loading times are quite sad. I moved the game from my secondary hard-drive to my SSDs and it's still an issue. This is really the only thing about the game that I find unnacceptable.

In the end, I can say this: if you liked the original Fallout games, if you like cyberpunk themed stories or games, or if you like RPGs, you really ought to pick these games up. Iâ€™d be a bit surprised if you didnâ€™t enjoy them.

reviewText:
Contains spoilers.

A worthwhile successor to Dragonfall.  Buggy at times, SR:HK recreates the tabletop experience with a plot that loses coherence and drive somewhere in the middle before whipping everything back together for the finale like an actual game master would have happen - complete with a literal deus ex machina as an end boss.

The maps are much larger, but most of it is empty space populated with nice atmospheric setpieces.  Nice scenery does kind of wear thin after a while when you're criss-crossing the hub area to buy things or advance the little subplots the NPCs have.

The new Matrix gameplay emphasizes sneaking around and playing Simon/a memory game.  It was novel, but wore that novelty out quickly.

Despite it all, would still recommend the game if only for one run through.  The story is nice and all the little details and in-jokes are appreciated.  Replayability is something I'm on the fence about - there's parts of this game's combat and Matrix mechanics that are simply a slog and the different avenues of conversation/story really just determine how much of a jerk you are to random people in Hong Kong/your team exemplified best in the end-of-game dialogue with the end boss.  In short, replayability doesn't look good to me on the effort/payoff scale.

Also kind of salty that there's a Hong Kong game and you can't dual-wield pistols I mean seriously now this is a terrible oversight.

reviewText:
Better than Shadowrun Returns, not as good as Dragonfall. Definitely in-between. Combat-wise, it's not that different from the previous two installments save a few tweaks and the fact you can choose your allies' upgrades, which is a plus.

Like other reviewers have said, the story is a little wanting. At no point are you really drawn into the mystery the same way you were in Dragonfall. Everything kind of happens behind the scenes and it isn't until the very end that your characters figure out what the hell is going on. Compare this to Dragonfall where in learning about the history and the politics of the f-state, you slowly begin to figure out why things are the way they are. There's no deus ex machina, everything in Dragonfall is laid out at the start and you just sink deeper and deeper into the story. Unfortunately, this installment is not as well thought out storywise and in the end, you feel a little cheated.

When it comes to tone and atmosphere, it just doesn't feel as sinister as the flux state of Dragonfall. I think the traditional Chinese cultural references feel a little campy. Compared to Berlin, where very little traditional German culture is poking through, it seems strange that futuristic Hong Kong retains so many traditional Chinese values. Real, present day Hong Kong doesn't even act this Chinese.

On a side note, I understand this is based on a tabletop series and that this Chinese-ness is a staple of cyberpunk, but come on. It's 2015. People should look at actual Hong Kong today and extrapolate from there, the same way they did when conceputalizing the anarchy state of Berlin (which is a mashup of antifa with East Berlin).  Furthermore, many people in Hong Kong can speak English, don't you think a 2050 Hong Kong would have even more English speakers?

Despite these flaws, it has its strengths. Kindly Cheng is a memorable character. The new level up system for your allies is neat. This installment had a lot of potential and if they ever revisit it, I hope they focus more on the corporate espionnage angle/gang warfare. It was a much more interesting subplot than the main arc.

Money was somewhat of an issue so sometimes you gotta bite your lip and hold out for the best stuff without going for the middle level equipment. Matrix gameplay is different and neat, but still just not that fun. And in certains missions you have to do the decking no matter what, with a time limit no less. I had a great time playing it, maybe not as much as Daggerfall but more than Dead Man's Switch. If they kept making these games, I'd keep buying them. Always feel like they are a good bang for your buck and you'll spend the next few days thinking about the story and looking up alternate endings. The biggest complaint of the entire series is the lack of customization for party members dealing with Karma Points so I imagine replays would get repetitive. But I know it takes alot to balance everything just right for gameplay and storytelling, so that's the price you pay when you run the shadows.

just finished... its a magnificent effort! congrats to HBS on their success!

spoilers eh







i thought DFDC was more thrilling overall - the set pieces were just mad - APEX mission... Blitz mission... the decimated Flux and the awesome reveal of DOG being an uber-hound - the mad orc with a minigun, the gargoyles... the slow decay of the dragonslayer... etc etc eh? Comparing each game is just inevitable.

Hong Kong is pretty awesome in its own right though - great commentary from the runners - the reactivity to each mission de-brief was really great. And interesting companion missions. The non-lethal approaches to missions was really refreshing. Kindly Cheng is one of the best characters ive met in the SR games so far - brutal dialogue + very likeable character overall. Ambrose is great, Reliable Matt, Gin, and Crafty all a lot of fun, cyberman and monk not so much. Of the companions Racter is the clear winner - such a cool story. Gaichu gets the 2nd place - but hes â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ in combat - if he had some 'samurai haste' we could see a far better vision of his intended combat.

Matrix is .. as everyone else has said - not properly scalable to character levels. This makes it look unfinished and all. A simple solution is to have the 'watcher IC' speed slow down after each level-up of the decker... so the initial twitch game becomes less and less important - and high-level deckers feel amazing because they can dodge all the heat like champions. ... plus the mini game is â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥, just â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥.

The art is great as expected the walled city props and maps are really great - not as dark as i'd thought i'd be seeing i mean lighting .... but damn so PRETTY.  I found seeing the 'umbrella squads' as the only vfx 'crowds' and no new 'crowd vfx' disappointing. there is devil rats though - thats one tick on the wishlist done Really loved all the new corporate maps and props - some beautiful work.

The endgame was ... hell it was as what it should have been - the epilogue counts more to me. The finish to the story was great imo - the epilogue ... - and the surprise that Ray survives - pretty damned cool. ...I am left wanting to have a go at the mini-campaign - and possibly the DC version if it ever gets made.  The writing deserves some credits for being awesome - thanks! - if a minor niggle - i was guessing that there could be a political game of all the yama kings - i was dissapointed and then ok because of their nature being properly revealed.

Back to comparisons - DFDC is better - but ive always felt more effort went into that game.. the devs were really pulling all the stops there . SR Hong Kong is also great - but not a trophy game - therefore it is lesser, generally. This shows - and i dont care really - thats 3.5 entertaining games these cats have made. Keep making more I say! Change it up from time to time and im sure we are all gold.

reviewText:
Before going to the pros & cons, let me just say: Get this game.

Let's start with the cons:

>The sneak feature/aspect of the Matrix could have been done better or removed entirely. The point & click controls of SRHK aren't well suited for the kind of navigation you need to do while sneaking. It ends up being more of a source of frustration than something that makes the gameplay more enjoyable.
>While I enjoy reading through a lot of the dialogue & description of events, sometimes the descriptions were excessive.
>There are still a fair amount of grammatical errors & formatting errors, especially as you near endgame.
> Inclredibly long loading times that sometimes end up with the game lagging.
>The economy in the game isn't sustainable; the profit from selling items is unbelievably small compared to buying them.

Pros:
>The graphics have definitely improved & the atmosphere of the game is much easier to get lost in.
>Spells & abilities are much more effective compared to the previous games & can actually make a difference in combat.
>The characters; more than your companions in runs, other characters in Heoi have their own stories & personalities that are varied, & interesting.
>There are a variety of missions that feel different from each other.
>While Dragonfall still had the better story imo, Hong Kong also has a solid story with decent pacing & a good amount of depth to leave you invested.
>The writing is superb as always, & despite being excessive in narration sometimes, the writing can still evoke a lot of emotions & is still full of wit & humor in the right places.

Admittedly, there are still a lot of cons but hopefully with more patches these issues will be addressed. If you aren't too picky & don't mind a few grammatical errors & formatting, some bugs (none of the ones I got were gamebreaking), and long loading times, then get this game now. Otherwise, wait for a sale. The experience overall has been worth it.

reviewText:
This is the third Shadowrun game coming from Harebrained Schemes, which crafted both Shadowrun Returns and Shadowrun:Dragonfall. Shadowrun:Hong Kong takes place in a futuristic rendition of its namesake, where technology and magic co-exist alongside with several fantasy sub-human races.


This is a very narrative-driven RPG. The camera is locked in an isometric view with 3d characters running around in a mostly static 2D environment. The graphics are beautiful and lovingly crafted, while the excellent asian-themed musical scores set the mood for your 20~30-hour trek through Hong Kong. In all,  Hong Kong is a fascinating setting for a cyberpunk adventure.


General gameplay flow have you undertaking various tasks in Hong Kong while at the same time making progress on the main storyline. After every mission you will return to your base of operations, where you can purchase new equipment, talk to NPCs or check your computer for new missions. Talking to your party members after every mission will allow you to gain new insights into their personality and background, and eventually you'll be able to embark on their own personal quests.


Progression is made by mostly clicking on static icons which hover above static NPCS or objects of interest, which I can't help but feel is a missed opportunity. NPCS walking around would've made the beautiful but static environment seem more alive. The missions themselves are very well crafted. There are often multiple solutions to the same problem(although some of them are limited by your team composition and skills), highly increasing replayability and the sense that you're a true Shadowrunner, able to complete the missions in the way you see fitting. Combat is the same as the previous two games, which is a turn-based tactical affair not unlike x-com. There're a variety of skills and weapons at your disposal, understanding your team and making use of cover is key to winning the battles. The matrix system had been revamped from the previous two games. While the idea is good, the game's movement system isn't really suited for the stealth-based parts in the matrix(imagine trying to play Metal Gear with RTS controls) and the actual hacking itself could get repetitive after a few tries.


The true star of the game, however, is its writing. Very few RPGs can write at the level that Shadowrun:Hong Kong does and the writers had truly done a phenomenal job. There are sometimes so much dialogue between missions it felt like it slows down the pacing, but they're all very well written and if you love reading, you're in a for a treat.


Shadowrun:Hong Kong knows which audience it is catering to, and fans of the first two games are very likely to enjoy this one.


Pros:
+Writing is top-notch
+Hong Kong is an interesting setting
+Beautiful aesthetics
+Excellent music
+Memorable characters
+Strategic combat

Cons:
-Some overlooked bugs need to be fixed
-Some solutions are tied to skills rather than real decision-making
-Not much interactivity with the environment
-Movement system is not quite suited for stealth sections

reviewText:
First of:
Shadowrun: Hong Kong is a really good cRPG and it takes all the good stuff of the previous titles and builds upon that.

Your crew is cool, the characters are well made. I, for example, never considered hiring mercenary runners, because I very quickly learned to appreciate Gobbet and Is0bel.
The artstyle is once again on point, the portraits are fitting and the score definetly fits in.
HB also did a good job on building your home district, Heoi. It catches the flair of a cyberpunky/scifiesque chinatown slum, but you still get to feel at home there.
The gameplay is not too different from Dragonfall, but I already liked it back then. If you are into isometric RPGs with turn-based combat, you will feel comfortable here and love the huge amount of possibilities this game offers.

The story. It's not a bad story. I got pretty absorbed.
But it is really straightforward imo. You have the main continuing main quest which progresses really fast and aside from that, only a few runs. The game felt a lot shorter than Dragonfall. Also I miss gimmicks like the Schockwellenreiter or missions in which your crew is personally involved. You do not get that here (or I was too stupid to notice , but then again, I noticed in Dragonfall, where that was really well made).
You also do not get to make as many impactful decisions or if you do, they do not feel impactful and I have overlooked them.

So, this review is a mess, but summing things up:

Pro

-Story itself is nice
-Nice character, level and gameplay design
-Artstyle and score
-Well concepted runs

Cons

-Feels a bit empty (feel like DF had more runs, also no gimmicks like Schockwellenreiter or that secret dragon guy who always messed with you)
-No really impactful decisions. It's like an action movie, you have your mission and with the exception of one or two cases, you just gonna stick to it. Of course you have freedom of how to achieve your goal, but you cannot change your goal.
-Minor Bugs

Final Statement:
I had a blast with Shadowrun: Hong Kong. But it felt more like an Addon to me than Dragonfall did.
A rerun with a different character might change that opinion, but I am not too hopeful about it.
(Also what exactly was the Deluxe Edition Content?)

reviewText:
I own and have completed Shadowrun Returns, Shadowrun: Dragonfall, and Shadowrun: Hong Kong, and I can say with confidence that Shadowrun: Hong Kong is, in my opinion, the best campaign out of the Shadowrun Returns franchise so far. The storyline is great, the NPCs are flavorful, and the gameplay is some of the best yet. Cyberware feels much improved, decking is far, far better than it was in the earlier two games, and the changes/upgrades to the body design of the characters is a welcome one, at least for me.

The only things I can really complain about are the (mostly annoying) bugs and the enormous amount of text errors. The former mostly includes load times steadily increasing as the game goes on and some minor hitching or freezing; I never encountered a CTD or game-breaking error. The latter is nit-picky, but literally the last half of the game has either missing or misplaced words every other text box or so. It really seems like they just used spellcheck and called it done, which is pretty disappointing for such a text-heavy and nicely-written game.

All-in-all, I would happily recommend this game to anyone who enjoys RPGs, the Shadowrun universe, or is simply in the mood for a good story with interesting characters.

Fun follow-up to Shadowrun: Dragonfall. Hong Kong refines many of the elements present in Dragonfall. For example, there is a new stealth oriented matrix (still some combat involved) and more non-lethal options on missions.

reviewText:
Another fantastic Shadowrun campaign~! I'd just like to take a moment to compare Shadowrun: Hong Kong, to it's predecessor, Shadowrun: Dragonfall.

Pros:


+Better UI. Feels more organic and less blocky. Limitations on the Karma screen are more apparent. It is now possible to do a number of simple things that you couldn't before, like equip teammates, distribute acquired items, and swap equipped items with one another.

+The Game does a better job at characterization. Not only with members of the team like Duncan Wu (with whom dialogue choices reveal your history together) but with characterizing some of the other Random NPC shadowrunners you can choose to hire. Note that I'm not saying that the characters are better this time around (that's a matter of personal preference), the game just does a better job presenting them.

+The story is more cinematic. A few motion-comic sequences penctuate key moments of the plot. Not that many though (I think there were three or four).

+Combat is improved and more balanced. Diffrent approaches to combat are more balanced than before. With additional skills and a dedicated merchant, playing a Physical Adept is actually viable this time around. Body has found a derived skill in Cyberware Affinity, which grants additional options to Street Samurai. Mages get a few new tricks like Blood Magic which are kinda OP, but for the most part the balance is welcoming. New items and drugs provide additional options, and are more important than before because...

+AI and Difficulty are improved. IN my honest opinion, both the original  Shadowrun Returns, and Shadowrun:Dragonfall were too easy. Shadowrun: Hong Kong, on it's highest difficulty, is more challenging, and I welcome it.

+Additional options for the Editor. This last one won't matter to most people, but the Shadowrun Editor has gained some new options with this game, like Ambient Sounds and Ley Line control.

Cons:


-Movement is clunky as â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥. So you click to move, which normally would be fine, except that your squad does a pretty unpredictable job of following you. Sometimes they're right behind you like they should be, other times they inexplicably end up a half mile behind you for no reason, so that when combat suddenly engages 'cause an enemy you didn't see ambushes you, your team needs to waste several turns getting in position. The clunky movement is worsened by the fact that Hong Kong adss STEALTH missions. Thankfully, these aren't instant-fail like some other games, but EVERY time you enter cyberspace, and even for some missions in meatspace, you'll have to fight against the movement system to remain undetected.

-Load times are pretty bad. Loads take much longer in Hong Kong than they did in Dragonfall. This might not be an issue if there weren't so many damn loading screens in Shadowrun. In any case expect to be doing a lot of waiting around. At least the load screens have text.

-Limited Replayablity. This is a problem that Shadowrun: Hong Kong shares with the others, but whereas both previous entries have community-made campaigns availble for them (some pretty damn good ones too, like Antumbra Saga) Time will tell if Hong Kong gets the same kind of support.

-Bugs. This one's still getting worked on, but there are a lot of bugs here that I just didn't see in Dragonfall. Dialogue boxes often have the wrong portraits attatched to them, missions sometimes crash, and NPC conversation trees don't always advance. It may get fixed later, but as of posting it's still an issue.

-Little connection to Shadowrun Lore. Okay, so only hardcore nerds will have a problem with this one, but I think it was a huge missed oppurtunity to explore some of the lore of Shadowrun and of China. reviewText:
I don't normally write recommendations, but this game is the first game I've played where I'm actually happy about the concept of DLC. Firstly, If you've played the previous 2 games and liked them you will definitely enjoy this as it is essentially the same with a few improvements. If you haven't played the previous two (Shadowrun Returns, Shadowrun Dragonfall) I do suggest that if this game interests you that you start with those as the improvements do drastically increase the overall game experience and you might find it hard to go backwards.

The main improvements, in my opinion, are as follows:

- Charisma plays a very large role in this campaign and most of the ettiquettes are also useful, though I felt academic seemed to be the most important and I only recall seeing gang once. I think the hardest Charisma check is 7, meaning you can dump quite a lot into it and still see some return.

- Allies that have a level up tree, even if it is a little limited.

- Allies that you can talk to out of mission and make you actually care about them. (Think Mass Effect before the ending they wrote with laxatives and stencils.)

- Decking feels much improved generally, with better level design and a minigame that I felt was relatively fun, though the harder ones might frustrate people who dislike being on a timer. Also, it took me a couple of runs to notice that you can flip your bars between ESPs and Programs.

- Melee (At least, the cyber-melee) is actually pretty good due to the ability to stunlock enemies. Haste on my main character meant that I could stunlock 2 enemies at a time with a little luck on my side.

- Equipment... There was always something I wanted to buy that I couldn't afford. In the previous games I felt a little underwhelmed by a lot of stuff, but in this game I feel as if the money income and equipment prices have been nicely paced to make it so that you're always looking out for that little bit of paydata to make all the difference.

All in all the game took me about 15 hours to complete which means it's about Â£1 per hour, which is pretty good these days for most non roguelikes.

reviewText:
Tl;dr: This series is just getting better and better.

Shadowrun is an isometric RPG set in a dystopian cyberpunk future. This is the 3rd game in the series by Harebrained Schemes and also the best. No knowledge of the previous games is needed to play this one.

In Shadowrun: Hong Kong, you follow your main character (which you create) and his/her childhood friend to Hong Kong as a request from your childhood father figure. When you arrive, you're ambushed by the police and forced underground to attempt to clear your names of a mythical crime and locate the man who brought you to Hong Kong.

What defines this series has always been the writing. You care about this story. You care about the characters. That's really hard to pull off so well and consistently in a video game. You *want* to spend time talking to your partners between missions and learn their backstories. You sympathize with everyone, even your main protagonist. By the end of Dragonfall I missed those characters and thought about them long after the story ended. This is a marvel in modern gaming.

As for the gameplay, it's another rock-solid progression in the series. Great and fluid and fun tactical combat that doesn't feel slow, a highly detailed world to explore, great characters and missions... there's really nothing to not like about this game.

I just can't recommend this series enough.

reviewText:
Before going to the pros & cons, let me just say: Get this game.

Let's start with the cons:

>The sneak feature/aspect of the Matrix could have been done better or removed entirely. The point & click controls of SRHK aren't well suited for the kind of navigation you need to do while sneaking. It ends up being more of a source of frustration than something that makes the gameplay more enjoyable.
>While I enjoy reading through a lot of the dialogue & description of events, sometimes the descriptions were excessive.
>There are still a fair amount of grammatical errors & formatting errors, especially as you near endgame.
> Inclredibly long loading times that sometimes end up with the game lagging.
>The economy in the game isn't sustainable; the profit from selling items is unbelievably small compared to buying them.

Pros:
>The graphics have definitely improved & the atmosphere of the game is much easier to get lost in.
>Spells & abilities are much more effective compared to the previous games & can actually make a difference in combat.
>The characters; more than your companions in runs, other characters in Heoi have their own stories & personalities that are varied, & interesting.
>There are a variety of missions that feel different from each other.
>While Dragonfall still had the better story imo, Hong Kong also has a solid story with decent pacing & a good amount of depth to leave you invested.
>The writing is superb as always, & despite being excessive in narration sometimes, the writing can still evoke a lot of emotions & is still full of wit & humor in the right places.

Admittedly, there are still a lot of cons but hopefully with more patches these issues will be addressed. If you aren't too picky & don't mind a few grammatical errors & formatting, some bugs (none of the ones I got were gamebreaking), and long loading times, then get this game now. Otherwise, wait for a sale. The experience overall has been worth it.

reviewText:
This is one great refinement of the formula Harebrained Schemes attained with the series' previous statements, especially Dragonfall. Choices are still mostly cosmetic, but the combat is still fun and the story is even better.

Speaking of which, prepare to read. It's like the game's filled with a hundred little short stories, and from the oddest sources, like store sellers. Seriously: everybody you're buying stuff from has a very nice story to tell.

Just don't rush it. I OCD'ed through a lot of content and ended up not only not experiencing it very well, but also got an endgame that was like 4 missions in a row without any new dialogue from anyone. The talks provide actually nice breaks between corporate invasions and the occasional plot mission.

The gameplay: new stuff -

cyberspace has been revamped (though now you have to stealth around in real time in every which place you jack in, which I didn't enjoy, really - ended up tripping alarms without caring too much and blasting my way through places, which is quite the same as before in Returns & Dragonfall)

the addition of plot-NPC-specific skills was quite charming; between the cast no one truly sucked, although some were visibly overpowered maybe (looking at Racter here)

cyberweapons! really fun to use

Missions were very well-designed. Little sameyness between them.

Now, the only bad thing about SR Hong Kong:

It's easy as hell. Seriously, there are about three real challenges in this 30 hour game, even on Hard. And I'm not even a powergamer, though I mostly didn't bother with diplomacy (here's another minus, actually - still didn't seem that diplomatic dialogue would offer any meaningful changes to the way a mission would go. And the etiquette system still sucks).

Do play it like there's no tomorrow if you like the original Fallouts etc. anyhow. This indie CRPG revival is like good sex after a long drought.

Also, there's one character itg that almost goes the Way of the Carth but doesn't really. Very, very pleasing.

reviewText:
This is the third Shadowrun game coming from Harebrained Schemes, which crafted both Shadowrun Returns and Shadowrun:Dragonfall. Shadowrun:Hong Kong takes place in a futuristic rendition of its namesake, where technology and magic co-exist alongside with several fantasy sub-human races.


This is a very narrative-driven RPG. The camera is locked in an isometric view with 3d characters running around in a mostly static 2D environment. The graphics are beautiful and lovingly crafted, while the excellent asian-themed musical scores set the mood for your 20~30-hour trek through Hong Kong. In all,  Hong Kong is a fascinating setting for a cyberpunk adventure.


General gameplay flow have you undertaking various tasks in Hong Kong while at the same time making progress on the main storyline. After every mission you will return to your base of operations, where you can purchase new equipment, talk to NPCs or check your computer for new missions. Talking to your party members after every mission will allow you to gain new insights into their personality and background, and eventually you'll be able to embark on their own personal quests.


Progression is made by mostly clicking on static icons which hover above static NPCS or objects of interest, which I can't help but feel is a missed opportunity. NPCS walking around would've made the beautiful but static environment seem more alive. The missions themselves are very well crafted. There are often multiple solutions to the same problem(although some of them are limited by your team composition and skills), highly increasing replayability and the sense that you're a true Shadowrunner, able to complete the missions in the way you see fitting. Combat is the same as the previous two games, which is a turn-based tactical affair not unlike x-com. There're a variety of skills and weapons at your disposal, understanding your team and making use of cover is key to winning the battles. The matrix system had been revamped from the previous two games. While the idea is good, the game's movement system isn't really suited for the stealth-based parts in the matrix(imagine trying to play Metal Gear with RTS controls) and the actual hacking itself could get repetitive after a few tries.


The true star of the game, however, is its writing. Very few RPGs can write at the level that Shadowrun:Hong Kong does and the writers had truly done a phenomenal job. There are sometimes so much dialogue between missions it felt like it slows down the pacing, but they're all very well written and if you love reading, you're in a for a treat.


Shadowrun:Hong Kong knows which audience it is catering to, and fans of the first two games are very likely to enjoy this one.


Pros:
+Writing is top-notch
+Hong Kong is an interesting setting
+Beautiful aesthetics
+Excellent music
+Memorable characters
+Strategic combat

Cons:
-Some overlooked bugs need to be fixed
-Some solutions are tied to skills rather than real decision-making
-Not much interactivity with the environment
-Movement system is not quite suited for stealth sections

And thus another adventure ends. I'll admit, the series didn't glue to me until Dragonfall, interesting premise that Returns wasn't able to execute properly. After another Kickstarter, Hairbrained Studios come in to deliver a third journey to the dark deep magical and corrupt world of Shadowrun, this time, in the bustling ciy of Hong Kong. Hope you know how to speak cantonease.

So here's the the intro of the story: you're an ork, a human or whatever that was just released from a max security corp prison and have been summoned by your foster father to join him in Hong Kong, along with your foster brother. No doubt, nothing will inevitably hit the fan and everything will be alright. In fact, that's what happens, your father wanted to meet up with you and your brother so you can have a nice family reunion. Kind of anti climatic, but enjoyable and simple... ok that doesn't happen. Stuff does go south, rather a bit slowly, and the whole of Honk Kong's police force are looking for you and the party you met upon arrival. At least it's not the London bobbies. Even more, your farther is missing and nothing is making sense. Why were you attacked? Who attacked you? What's behind the fridge?

So from on there, the story preety much takes the same formula as of Dragonfall: peal out layers from the conspirancy surrounding you, take on varying missions that test you with hard choices, meet fantastic characters and do the Bioware thing where you help them in a Loyalty Mission. AMAZING MISSIONS, ranging from opening a pickle jar for a character to opening TWO pickle jars! I might add that the majority of the 47 hours spent in the game was me reading every line that the game presented me, the dialogue is more than spot on! Can't and couldn't stop reading it! I'm also glad that the game now features a more diverse race of a crewmen, not for the sake of race equality, just to get a more varying story.

I prefer a different location from Hong Kong, but it's nonetheless interesting and the asian background is also explained within the universe's rules and it's quite intriguing.

As for the combat and general gameplay, it's preety much the same as that of Dragonfall. Read it in my review of it here if you want to: http://steamcommunity.com/profiles/76561198014021112/recommended/300550/ . You can now also ambush enemies and plan proper door breach-in" situations. reviewText:
Shadowrun: Hong Kong is a turn-based action RPG. This game encourages you to spend a lot of time reading. There is no spoken dialogue, so a lot comes down to your own imagination. I know reading lots of text is not for everyone, but the dialogue in the game is well-written. If you allow yourself some time to follow the conversations between your character and the personas you encounter in a tumultuous, futuristic Hong Kong, the story will suck you in. The beautiful art style of the game really helps the story gain a foothold and the areas in which combat takes place seemlessly blend in with the surrounding environment. The music in this game is great and diverse, and in each different area of Hong Kong  you will hear various background noises that make the game come to life.

When you are not busy delving into the rich background stories of your fellow Shadowrunners inside your headquarters, you can embark on missions (so-called Shadow Runs) that you can select via your mission computer. Each Run consists of completing verious objectives, such as kidnapping a target or infiltrating a building. Each mission contains plenty of turn-based violence for you to enjoy. Tactically positioning your squad is a must, for the enemy will try to flank your Shadowrunners whenever possible; increasing the damage you and your squadmates take. Combat is fun, challenging and dynamic, and there are often multiple ways to deal with your opponents: Be it engaging them from afar with heavy (sniper)rifles while your melee fighters sneak in to finish the job, using mages and riggers to summon powerful spiritual and robotic allies to wreak havoc from multiple directions, or even by jacking into the matrix (lol) to cripple the enemy's infrastructure before taking the fight to them head-on. You decide how you want to play.

Even when you are not much into reading the story, the game's combat system is challenging and diverse enough to encourage multiple playthroughs. Having the ability to create a completely different character that you can heavily customize by spending points in different skill trees will make each playthrough significantly different from the last.

The only minor point of criticism I have is that the choices you make often only have a minor impact on the main storyline. In an RPG, I would expect the (dialogue) options you choose to have a little more impact on how the story unfolds.

Overall, I would definitely recommend this game, provided you don't mind reading a lot of dialogue.

reviewText:
I'm disappointed. Don't get me wrong, i still like the game and if you're familliar with its predecessors and enjoyed them, then you'll like this game too - but maybe with the same sense of 'if only' that i have after wading through it.

Finally, the game mechanics run smoothly with no gaping omissions or unfinished corners (though I found the new matrix 'run & dodge' more irritating than fun). The art is pleasing but the text side of the game (not necessarily the story itself) is like some socially inept bore at a party who pins you to the wall with tedious rhetoric only he finds interesting and has no comprehension of actual conversation. There's so much useless text in this game that my eyes glazed over far too quickly, and i generally like text heavy games. For mood, theme and function (and it was the lack of the last that was particularly notable) presented in text, Baldur's Gate or Planescape Torment this is not. Hong Kong's predecessors were tight and slick in their text use and storytelling while Hong Kong just isn't, it becomes a laborious 'click through' that swamps the better features of what could have been the best iteration of Shadowrun by Harebrained yet.

Ultimately, its the editing of the game that is flawed, not the game itself. What a shame. Still, at least it /has/ a good plot and two dimensional characters in gaming are always better than the conventional one. I also think that this game will be much more palatable on a tablet rather than hunched in front of a desktop. Something i think proved true of the other two games too, so maybe wait for that... Of course then you probably won't have access to the user content again if you do.

reviewText:
I own and have completed Shadowrun Returns, Shadowrun: Dragonfall, and Shadowrun: Hong Kong, and I can say with confidence that Shadowrun: Hong Kong is, in my opinion, the best campaign out of the Shadowrun Returns franchise so far. The storyline is great, the NPCs are flavorful, and the gameplay is some of the best yet. Cyberware feels much improved, decking is far, far better than it was in the earlier two games, and the changes/upgrades to the body design of the characters is a welcome one, at least for me.

The only things I can really complain about are the (mostly annoying) bugs and the enormous amount of text errors. The former mostly includes load times steadily increasing as the game goes on and some minor hitching or freezing; I never encountered a CTD or game-breaking error. The latter is nit-picky, but literally the last half of the game has either missing or misplaced words every other text box or so. It really seems like they just used spellcheck and called it done, which is pretty disappointing for such a text-heavy and nicely-written game.

All-in-all, I would happily recommend this game to anyone who enjoys RPGs, the Shadowrun universe, or is simply in the mood for a good story with interesting characters.

reviewText:
After some needed patches the game is now running pretty stable (still suffering some bugs..but that`s to be expected....sadly)

Shadowrun Returns was a good game, rough at the edges, but offered a great plot; interesting characters and lots of fan-service.
Dragonfall was better in every way; more indepth mechanics, better art-work, music and alot more polish on the core-gamelay, all in all a 100% improvement.

Shadowrun Hong Kong follwos right on, making hefty jumps in quality over Dragonfall; grafics have been improved alot, soundtrack is fantastic as always (better quality yet), there`s even more art-work everywhere, the whole immersion works even better than in SR:R and SR:D, combat, char-building, and lots of other gameplay aspects have again been worked on a lot; also the save-everywhere-feature is now part of the core SR-mechanic.

reviewText:
Full disclosure: I backed this game on Kickstarter, and I backed it because I loved playing Shadowrun Returns and Shadowrun: Dragonfall.

The game starts out with our hero, after you create him or her, getting off a boat to meet their childhood friend and foster brother in Hong Kong. You've been asked to go there by your foster father.

There are three battles before you even become a shadowrunner; one of them is avoidable, but yeah, there's a high probability of being killed first time out. There's even a Steam achievement for it.

The Shadowrun games involve a lot of reading. The writers seem to be more novelists than screenwriters, so they're really not concerned with anything seeming too much like a monologue. The balance between reading and playing is good, though. The reading lets you take a break from trying to shoot, fight, or magic your way out of the many encounters. Talking to your group is also encouraged, as some of them will give you missions. Some of the side characters you'll meet along the way will also help you in surprising ways.

In addition to the character quests, there are many hidden little things in the game that can be easily missed if you don't look around. There are other runners you can meet, more goodies to buy if you have the cash, and some entertaining characters.

There's also a heavier necessity for a decker, which seems to be why the decking virtual world has been given a major upgrade since the last game. It looks much better, and has a few more challenges to it. There are times in the game when a decker is absolutely necessary, and other times when a decker can help to avoid a battle, or even save everyone's lives.

Ultimately, though, the Shadowrun gameplay experience is looking very dated, especially after XCOM, and the upcoming XCOM2. Ideally, for the next Shadowrun game, I'd like to see more 3D, a rotatable map, and a lot more voice acting. Harebrained Schemes have improved their storytelling immensely since Shawrun Returns, but now it's time for them to improve the gameplay experience with some new technologies.

reviewText:
Better than Shadowrun Returns, not as good as Dragonfall. Definitely in-between. Combat-wise, it's not that different from the previous two installments save a few tweaks and the fact you can choose your allies' upgrades, which is a plus.

Like other reviewers have said, the story is a little wanting. At no point are you really drawn into the mystery the same way you were in Dragonfall. Everything kind of happens behind the scenes and it isn't until the very end that your characters figure out what the hell is going on. Compare this to Dragonfall where in learning about the history and the politics of the f-state, you slowly begin to figure out why things are the way they are. There's no deus ex machina, everything in Dragonfall is laid out at the start and you just sink deeper and deeper into the story. Unfortunately, this installment is not as well thought out storywise and in the end, you feel a little cheated.

When it comes to tone and atmosphere, it just doesn't feel as sinister as the flux state of Dragonfall. I think the traditional Chinese cultural references feel a little campy. Compared to Berlin, where very little traditional German culture is poking through, it seems strange that futuristic Hong Kong retains so many traditional Chinese values. Real, present day Hong Kong doesn't even act this Chinese.

On a side note, I understand this is based on a tabletop series and that this Chinese-ness is a staple of cyberpunk, but come on. It's 2015. People should look at actual Hong Kong today and extrapolate from there, the same way they did when conceputalizing the anarchy state of Berlin (which is a mashup of antifa with East Berlin).  Furthermore, many people in Hong Kong can speak English, don't you think a 2050 Hong Kong would have even more English speakers?

Despite these flaws, it has its strengths. Kindly Cheng is a memorable character. The new level up system for your allies is neat. This installment had a lot of potential and if they ever revisit it, I hope they focus more on the corporate espionnage angle/gang warfare. It was a much more interesting subplot than the main arc.

reviewText:
This is one great refinement of the formula Harebrained Schemes attained with the series' previous statements, especially Dragonfall. Choices are still mostly cosmetic, but the combat is still fun and the story is even better.

Speaking of which, prepare to read. It's like the game's filled with a hundred little short stories, and from the oddest sources, like store sellers. Seriously: everybody you're buying stuff from has a very nice story to tell.

Just don't rush it. I OCD'ed through a lot of content and ended up not only not experiencing it very well, but also got an endgame that was like 4 missions in a row without any new dialogue from anyone. The talks provide actually nice breaks between corporate invasions and the occasional plot mission.

The gameplay: new stuff -

cyberspace has been revamped (though now you have to stealth around in real time in every which place you jack in, which I didn't enjoy, really - ended up tripping alarms without caring too much and blasting my way through places, which is quite the same as before in Returns & Dragonfall)

the addition of plot-NPC-specific skills was quite charming; between the cast no one truly sucked, although some were visibly overpowered maybe (looking at Racter here)

cyberweapons! really fun to use

Missions were very well-designed. Little sameyness between them.

Now, the only bad thing about SR Hong Kong:

It's easy as hell. Seriously, there are about three real challenges in this 30 hour game, even on Hard. And I'm not even a powergamer, though I mostly didn't bother with diplomacy (here's another minus, actually - still didn't seem that diplomatic dialogue would offer any meaningful changes to the way a mission would go. And the etiquette system still sucks).

Do play it like there's no tomorrow if you like the original Fallouts etc. anyhow. This indie CRPG revival is like good sex after a long drought.

Also, there's one character itg that almost goes the Way of the Carth but doesn't really. Very, very pleasing.

reviewText:
I don't normally write recommendations, but this game is the first game I've played where I'm actually happy about the concept of DLC. Firstly, If you've played the previous 2 games and liked them you will definitely enjoy this as it is essentially the same with a few improvements. If you haven't played the previous two (Shadowrun Returns, Shadowrun Dragonfall) I do suggest that if this game interests you that you start with those as the improvements do drastically increase the overall game experience and you might find it hard to go backwards.

The main improvements, in my opinion, are as follows:

- Charisma plays a very large role in this campaign and most of the ettiquettes are also useful, though I felt academic seemed to be the most important and I only recall seeing gang once. I think the hardest Charisma check is 7, meaning you can dump quite a lot into it and still see some return.

- Allies that have a level up tree, even if it is a little limited.

- Allies that you can talk to out of mission and make you actually care about them. (Think Mass Effect before the ending they wrote with laxatives and stencils.)

- Decking feels much improved generally, with better level design and a minigame that I felt was relatively fun, though the harder ones might frustrate people who dislike being on a timer. Also, it took me a couple of runs to notice that you can flip your bars between ESPs and Programs.

- Melee (At least, the cyber-melee) is actually pretty good due to the ability to stunlock enemies. Haste on my main character meant that I could stunlock 2 enemies at a time with a little luck on my side.

- Equipment... There was always something I wanted to buy that I couldn't afford. In the previous games I felt a little underwhelmed by a lot of stuff, but in this game I feel as if the money income and equipment prices have been nicely paced to make it so that you're always looking out for that little bit of paydata to make all the difference.

All in all the game took me about 15 hours to complete which means it's about Â£1 per hour, which is pretty good these days for most non roguelikes.

reviewText:
So first of all the main difference is that decking and the matrix have had a huge overhaul. It runs on some completely new rules and features. Instead of fighting IC turn by turn, you have to play a stealth game where you slip past patrols of IC. If they see you, they keep doing system trace until you kill them. In order to get to data nodes, you also have to get past blocker IC. You can force your way past it, but it adds more system trace. Get too much system trace, and black IC will show up and kill you, so it's not an ideal soloution. Instead, you will have to play a mini simon says game and a matching symbols type thing.

These mini-games are extremely difficult and tedious. They aren't fun and I had no idea what the developers were thinking. It also takes you away from the game and your character, because suddenly you're not relying on your characters' skills, but rather your own skills. Obviously this is anti-thetical to the point of an RPG game. The old matrix system was fun and enjoyable, there was no need to change it. Also, you can't supress except for in combat. What?

Secondly, this game is way too easy. I played through the whole game on the hardest difficulty and easily tore through the combat encounters like they were kleenex. I only died twice, and I think one time it was an accident. The game is so easy that it provides no tactical challenge, and I was honestly losing interest about halfway through. It's twice as easy as Dragonfall, which is actually challenging and keeps you engaged.

Third, this game is unacceptably buggy. I would click an ability and some other ability would be selected, not the one I wanted. I had characters glitch out and be unavailable for dialouge, leading to me not being able to complete conversations, quests, or storylines. What an extreme buzzkill. I also had the screen CONSTANTLY freeze up on me when returning from missions. The bugs in this game are unbelievably frustrating and tedious, and honestly ruin the experience.

reviewText:
I own and have completed Shadowrun Returns, Shadowrun: Dragonfall, and Shadowrun: Hong Kong, and I can say with confidence that Shadowrun: Hong Kong is, in my opinion, the best campaign out of the Shadowrun Returns franchise so far. The storyline is great, the NPCs are flavorful, and the gameplay is some of the best yet. Cyberware feels much improved, decking is far, far better than it was in the earlier two games, and the changes/upgrades to the body design of the characters is a welcome one, at least for me.

The only things I can really complain about are the (mostly annoying) bugs and the enormous amount of text errors. The former mostly includes load times steadily increasing as the game goes on and some minor hitching or freezing; I never encountered a CTD or game-breaking error. The latter is nit-picky, but literally the last half of the game has either missing or misplaced words every other text box or so. It really seems like they just used spellcheck and called it done, which is pretty disappointing for such a text-heavy and nicely-written game.

All-in-all, I would happily recommend this game to anyone who enjoys RPGs, the Shadowrun universe, or is simply in the mood for a good story with interesting characters.
