(Author's note: This is from the perspective of someone who does not play the tabletop RPG. Veteran fans beware.)

Gonna be honest with you here. This is the best version so far. I have all three games, and I can say that, without a doubt, this is the best version so far. Not because it's the newest. Not because it's the shiniest. But because it adds so much to the previous two games that I found myself having to read the tutorials despite playing the previous two games for hours on end. If you've played the previous two games in this series, you will not be disappointed on a gameplay front, as they have added so much since they original game.

In short, among the weapons, new locations, new characters, and whatnot, they have made two major modifications to the core gameplay: Adept alterations and fundamental changes to the roles of the Decker class.

Before, the Adept was a somewhat servicable, if not very specialized, substitute for a melee Street Samurai. Now? Well, they're still a substitute for a melee Street Samurai, but they have added a new mechanic for the class that shakes up so much. Basically, what they have added are stances for the Adepts to adopt to alter their fighting styles, such as increased defense and dodge capabilities in exchange for reduced HP damage or just straight out AP damage, or increased damage in exchange for reduced dodge and defense. Basic stuff, nothing too special or out of the ordinary for most differing stances" in other games

reviewText:
An excellent game that I would recomend to all of my friends. It is a dark setting where you are opperating in shades of grey at best. It is set in a world where magic meets technology. They creators showed a good understanding of hong kong, better than just a quick google search. If you have been to the city, you will have a familiar feeling with this game.

It is a story heavy game, so be prepared to read a lot of dialogue. If you want to skip to the action this may not be the game for you. If you want a rich story with deep characters, though, this is likely to fit the bill. The NPCs are fleshed out and believable with their own story arks. You have a number of options to define your character as well.

Game play wise, it is a fairly tactical game. Be prepared to look for cover and plan your moves carefully. Combat can be slow, especially if you play it like a game of chess. However, it gives you a great deal of options. The matrix section can depend a bit on your tastes. If you like stepping away from combat to solve puzzles you will probably enjoy them more. For the most part, though, the matrix is skippable if you don't want to bother with it.

Your actions will have consequences in the game. Some more long term than others. You can choose to fight or talk your way through many situations. Who you let live or ally with can impact the story later on. While I would have liked to have seen more hard moral choices, over all the options presented seem believable and organic.

reviewText:
Warning: minor spoilers within.

I've only played an hour or two so far, so here's a provisional review.

There are few games which get Hong Kong right. Sleeping Dogs knocked it right out of the park with sheer authenticity, and Shadowrun: Hong Kong has managed to translate Hong Kong effectively into the Shadowrun Universe. Feng shui is an actual thing, there's the typical Chinese obsession with the number 8 everywhere (Club 88, 8 members in the Council) and there are accurate references to how the Hong Kong Triads work. I love it.

Karma levelling system has been given a more coherent UI, and even though most of the combat system is still the same as Dragonfall and Returns, the revamp to the Decking sequences is praiseworthy. Movement in the decking cyberspace is real-time and your avatar gets to evade the roaming ICE Metal Gear-style, which is a huge improvement. The turn-based combat kicks in only when you've been detected.

There's plenty more to be looked at, but based on what I've seen so far? 10/10. Harebrained have once again delivered an excellent game.

reviewText:
It's amazing!

Shadowrun Returns didn't get my interest although I tried it. Now, this game plays the same, but to me, it's exceptional and surpasses Returns in every way! I should note though that I will go back to Returns after playing this.

The main point here is that the story is spectacular. I wanted to pry more into the dialogue options (and there are MANY) and was rewarded with a fleshed out story. It's practically a book inside a game. Now of course, you don't have to divulge into the lore. There's options to prod more into a conversation, which I did. I'd say at least half of my gameplay is reading. It really is interesting though and so very entertaining.

The art is spectacular! Hong Kong looks great as far as a dystopian world goes. The music is very asian-esq and captures the mood.

If you're a fan of XCOM's combat, or turn-based in general, you'll like this. There are plenty of options to choose from. I for one was a shaman that relied on support abilities to help my team, but was also quite adept at the pistol. If I felt like it, I could have focused all on magic, or all on pistols... or I can focus on other weapons too. There are many possibilities!

All in all, if you like Shadowrun, or are in any way intered, I suggest it.

reviewText:
I would only recommend this game if...
- You are a die-hard fan of the SRR series
- You can put up with game-breaking bugs
- You like playing any class except a decker

While I have played the previous two installations and enjoyed them, somewhat, this one struck a few nerves.  There are bugs that will require reloading of save games (make multiple save games, by the way) and cause outright frustration.  Plus, the story seemed lackluster in comparison to the previous iteration.

First off, the reloading bugs.  There are 2 that come to mind immediately.  In the beginning when you have to talk to your new contact, make sure you go to your shelter afterwards.  Do not save and quit, even though it is about 4 hours in and you need a break.  Doing so will cause the shelter to be inaccessible and the new contact to not do anything.  Thus, you will have to reload.  If you are like me, and only made one save, then prepare to play those 4 hours again.  The second majorly annoying bug is towards the end of the campaign.  Gather the four items before interfacing with the computer.  If you interface with the computer first, you'll have to reload and start the battle over again.  Also, even if you do this correctly, there is still a chance it will bug out and you'll have to reload.

The second deal-breaker is that the enemy AI has not improved since the last iteration.  If the main character is in LoS, they will gang up and kill it.  If the main character dies, then it is game over.  Sure, if you like playing the tough type (street samurai / something beefy), you will be fine.  I like playing a decker and was looking forward to the improvements to decking in this version.  However, since AI will hunt out the PC and deckers are not known for their ability to take a beating, it was pretty frustrating to try.

Not really a dealbreaker, but worth a mention is that there are no graphical or combat improvements since the last iteration.  Character development is minimal.  There are very few skills which makes combat pretty repetitive.  After a few chapters, I found the 3 teammates that were most useful and never changed them around.  There was no need to.

reviewText:
Shadowrun: Hong Kong, the third installement in the Shadowrun reboot.
The game is based (just like previous installments) around a protagonist whom gets his/her bum marked as a shadowrunner after bad happenings.  Along the way, the player meets new NPCs, gets info around the current predicament and trots around the hub to talk with people or buy items.
The game's heavy on dialogue, choices and repercussions, just like in the previous installments.
If you're a fan of Shadowrun, then this is quite an easy pickup. If not, I'd highly suggest to start with Shadowrun Returns and Dragonfall.

What I liked about the game is that it's story rich, much like the previous games. The atmosphere is great, the hub area is rather nice to explore. The NPCs are alright, the alternative storylines are alright... And that's sadly it.

There are several NPCs to choose from and have dialogue with. Sadly, aside from 2, they all fall under the 'meh, seen this character before' category. Aside from those 2, I personally didn't care much about their predicament.
Sure, some of it was like: Woah, what's going on... But it fell so flat on its â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥, because it later got the 'we've done it, yay' treatment.

The missions that the player can pick up are, for the most part, well done. Some turn into a complete nightmare, but unlike the previous installments, it's not as well worked out this time around.
It feels more 'safe' compared to the previous installments. There's only 2 missions where I was generally taken by how things turned out (only to be classified as 'yay, we done did it' in the end) which is a huge letdown.

The focus was probably more on the combat and hacking. The combat is amazing, hands down. It's fluid in nearly every way eventhough it feels a little easy.
The hacking is a lot faster and it feels more down to earth. Yet... Did we really need to get a memory game and then a sequence of markings?

The ending is lackluster. I saw it coming a mile away. Not because this is another installment of Shadowrun, but because the game didn't even try to mask it. I do like that there are several different options, but the general showdown felt weak.

The pacing of this game has to be the most horrible thing I've experienced in the last 2 years though.
I felt myself becoming really bored after playing it for a while. You go on a mission which doesn't take 15 minutes, then hang around the hub area for an hour, reading arbitrary dialogues.
Then there's the 'role playing' aspect. I'll compare this to Fallout New Vegas and Fallout 4, because this game does the exact same thing. Aside from some decisive factors, 80% of what you say/respond, doesn't even matter.
The big choices issue has even broken the game in 1 level, where you can't proceed if you didn't spend the right karma points.

Another reason I couldn't play the game in long runs, is, because it's a dialogue heavy game... With LOADS of typos in it. It doesn't just come down to a letter wrong here and there... There are whole sentences that aren't proper English. There are commas missing, misspelled words littering every conversation, as well as plain lazy writing.
As a big fan of Dragonfall, this is a major disapointment. I found myself not caring for some of the dialogue anymore, even when it sort of started to become interesting... (And then it usually dried out right after in most cases).

All in all, even if the review seems mostly negative, because this installment's a huge step down from the previous ones, this is still a pretty enjoyable game. The combat feels good and responsive, the atmosphere is great and it feels like a Shadowrun game. It just lacks what made the previous installments a great game.

I'll not play it again for a while, unless, perhaps, the pacing gets improved and the numerous typos get fixed.
I don't mind a typo here and there, but like I said, the game is riddled with it.

On that note though, the sound and music effects in the game are well done. Some even improved from the previous versions I might add. But I still wonder why my heavy pistol sounds like a dart gun.

reviewText:
My first exposure to the Shadowrun universe came from the 1994 Sega Genesis release  Shadowrun . From that game I segued into the many of the Shadowrun novels, both new and old. Then, in 2007, a new Shadowrun video game was released, which turned out to be massively disappointing. Shortly after that, Shadowrun seemed to fall into troubled times. Fortunately, the magic that is Kickstarter allowed for a resurrection of Shadowrun to the video gaming world in the form of  Shadowrun Returns  in 2013. And then, not long after, we saw the release of   Shadowrun: Dragonfall , and now, here we are at  Shadowrun: Hong Kong . Since  Shadowrun Returns  each subsequent game has proven to be better than the last - Hong Kong is no exception.

Certainly the best thing about the three newest entries into the Shadowrun video game universe has been their writing. From the plot to the dialogue - these have been exceptionally well written and realized games. Hong Kong has proven itself to be the finest of the three, with arguably the best pacing and deepest characters. The combat has seen another overhaul from the previous installment as well.

The combat in Returns was lackluster, and Dragonfall (particularly the Director's Cut) did much to improve upon this system. Now, in Hong Kong, with more weapons, cyber, spells, and an improved UI, combat is even more varied and fun. The amount of variety to the combat, and depth of your fellow shadowrunners, allows for plenty of experimentation and replayability. The visuals and soundtrack have also been improved upon.

From  Shadowrun Returns  onward these games have been beautifully crafted in both their audio and visual design. Each subsequently more so than the last. Hong Kong manages to improve upon the art of the previous game, making the world seem more dense and filled with grim neo-noir neon. Meanwhile the soundtrack blends cyberpunk with Asian-inspired themes to create a sound fitting to the new game setting.

Overall, Hong Kong is an improvement upon an already great gaming experience. Almost every facet of the game has seen improvement.  Shadowrun: Hong Kong  is a game I'd easily recommend to fans of the Shadowrun universe, roleplaying games, or the cyberpunk subgenre.

reviewText:
This is the third of the Shadowrun games I've played so far - and the one I've most enjoyed. The music is creative I found. I liked the ambience. The notes and themes were definetly different than the others. You get to see some specific cultural themes from this one, which really brings out the setting of the game. All in all - it seems to bring itself more into its own as a setting.  While Dragonfall and Returns were nice, you had to really know more about the social structures of the area to discern that you were in two different countries. You're a merc. You do stuff. You get money. You beat the bad guys. Corps are out to get you. Copy Pasta with some nice differences. In Hong Kong, the area is different. The background, the character images available,  the dialogue options and buildings reflect the setting, even some of the Matrix reflects their change in location. Spirits too are caught up in this - and reflect the area; which I thought was a particularly nice touch.

The cyberware system is a bit more friendly. You can finally go whole hog and upgrade your character to be Robocop. The bonus mechanics of basically purchasing more essence with exp is an option. This means that even mages/shamans/adepts with the inclination to do so, can get themselves some of the tuneups without feeling the pinch. In practice, I had an Elf Shaman who had  Kevlar Bone Lacing and Dermal Plating - with the final costs bringing my essence back down to 6. But that being said, I lost some of the versatility I could've otherwise used (like having access to mage spells instead of just shaman spells). Still - a nice customized choice. There are cyberware weapons - which any fan of the dice game can tell you there are a lot of those in the books. Its really nice to see them displayed. You get access to things like throwing grenades back (imagine that in Dragonfall), using powerful stun weapons, built in swords, and even a whip (which works for ranged characters - giving them a reason to go into it).

The NPC's are... very well fleshed out. Every so often you find the 'I'm a jerk because I'm a jerk' stereotype in a game. Some use it more often than not. This game however, is a bit more lenient on the action. Characters have reasons for their motivations. They have backstories and drives. Some dialogue options will recurr in future follow ups - and if you paid attention to the wording, you can change how events go. As with text based games - and a lot of RPG's, it can be a trial to wade through all the dialogue. Not gonna lie, I fast clicked some of these options when my interest was gone. Your character - in a lot of such situations - can also be fatigued by the conversation; and be rude, trying to end and get out of the talk as fast as possible.

Combat is a bit nicer. Weapons still carry over the same as they did before. Your NPC companions have their own unique tasks that make you weigh whether or not you want them in the party based on what you were going up against. Some characters can outright knock out some enemies, while others make excellent tanks. Certain wombo combos are possible - fencing an enemy in with a barrier, then throwing an acid fog or a land mine at their feet; setting up the combat in your favor. You no longer have to necessarily rely on 'I need to hit'. Could just be 'you have to be in this general area'. Spells get ... amazingly modified by ley lines now. Where as before it was like 'this could be cool' - sometimes it more along the lines of ... I really do not want to step on this". A single spell meant to hit an enemy suddenly bounces three times

Hong Kong is very much a case of Shadowrun: More Of The Same
It's a game that leans very heavily on the writing in order to tell the story, which does a wonderful job of using the imagination to paint a picture of the world in which you inhabit. The gameplay is rock solid, with abilities well balanced, giving a real sense of meaninful tactics and risk-reward mechanics. Many times I found myself gambling on a 50% one turn kill over a guaranteed two turn kill with less chance for harm to my party overall.

reviewText:
(Spoilers here and there)
I was gonna give this a proper review, but honestly, I feel like it just needs nitpicking rather than a full overview.

In short - It's easily as good as SR: Returns, but it falls short of Dragonfall.

Dragonfall took everything that was wrong with Returns, and just bumped it up. All +1 and everything.

Hong Kong manages to do that as well, redefined some of your character choices - Armor now just gives armor, no more stat buffs, so it's down now to your cyberware to see enchanced stats which I like more. Stops making you more powerful than what you are. Adept got scaled to par as well, the mixing of Qi spells was pretty cool I thought, and there is a large selection of weapons available, which ultimately might lead to arbitrary choices but, it's still cool nonetheless.

The story, while fine, doesn't give me the closure I got from Returns and Shadowrun, I didn't feel satisfied where it ended, like there was still things to do but ultimately, you got denied.
Though they went all out with the additional storylines - Everyone you talk to on the side has pages and pages of text... Though, sometimes, too much to make your head spin.

The Matrix got a complete revamp and damn, was it worth it. Jacking in never felt so good. Combat is still roughly the same but the espionage part of it is what makes it tick now.

The soundtrack in Dragonfall was awesome, and while Hong Kong's is good, it doesn't evoke any feelings you'd come to expect from running shadows. You need some heavy beats when you're out there in cyberland and whatnot, but HK just gives you more.. Mellow" asian sounding tunes

reviewText:
This is the third Shadowrun game coming from Harebrained Schemes, which crafted both Shadowrun Returns and Shadowrun:Dragonfall. Shadowrun:Hong Kong takes place in a futuristic rendition of its namesake, where technology and magic co-exist alongside with several fantasy sub-human races.


This is a very narrative-driven RPG. The camera is locked in an isometric view with 3d characters running around in a mostly static 2D environment. The graphics are beautiful and lovingly crafted, while the excellent asian-themed musical scores set the mood for your 20~30-hour trek through Hong Kong. In all,  Hong Kong is a fascinating setting for a cyberpunk adventure.


General gameplay flow have you undertaking various tasks in Hong Kong while at the same time making progress on the main storyline. After every mission you will return to your base of operations, where you can purchase new equipment, talk to NPCs or check your computer for new missions. Talking to your party members after every mission will allow you to gain new insights into their personality and background, and eventually you'll be able to embark on their own personal quests.


Progression is made by mostly clicking on static icons which hover above static NPCS or objects of interest, which I can't help but feel is a missed opportunity. NPCS walking around would've made the beautiful but static environment seem more alive. The missions themselves are very well crafted. There are often multiple solutions to the same problem(although some of them are limited by your team composition and skills), highly increasing replayability and the sense that you're a true Shadowrunner, able to complete the missions in the way you see fitting. Combat is the same as the previous two games, which is a turn-based tactical affair not unlike x-com. There're a variety of skills and weapons at your disposal, understanding your team and making use of cover is key to winning the battles. The matrix system had been revamped from the previous two games. While the idea is good, the game's movement system isn't really suited for the stealth-based parts in the matrix(imagine trying to play Metal Gear with RTS controls) and the actual hacking itself could get repetitive after a few tries.


The true star of the game, however, is its writing. Very few RPGs can write at the level that Shadowrun:Hong Kong does and the writers had truly done a phenomenal job. There are sometimes so much dialogue between missions it felt like it slows down the pacing, but they're all very well written and if you love reading, you're in a for a treat.


Shadowrun:Hong Kong knows which audience it is catering to, and fans of the first two games are very likely to enjoy this one.


Pros:
+Writing is top-notch
+Hong Kong is an interesting setting
+Beautiful aesthetics
+Excellent music
+Memorable characters
+Strategic combat

Cons:
-Some overlooked bugs need to be fixed
-Some solutions are tied to skills rather than real decision-making
-Not much interactivity with the environment
-Movement system is not quite suited for stealth sections

reviewText:
Fun follow-up to Shadowrun: Dragonfall. Hong Kong refines many of the elements present in Dragonfall. For example, there is a new stealth oriented matrix (still some combat involved) and more non-lethal options on missions.

Some pros:
- great dialogue especially with the Rachter and Gaichu companions
- combat is the same fun system as Dragonfall with a few tweaks
- more choices on how to complete missions
- some of the etiquettes are very useful (I hear others are almost useless - so a bit of a pro and con here)

Some cons:
- money is very rare, it is very difficult to completely kit out your own character (or any others). This is especially true if you play a decker like me and you want to buy guns, a deck, programs and cyberware.
- the game isn't as difficult as Dragonfall. I'm better at the game now, but it was much easier than Dragonfall. I didn't come close to dieing once (on hard) and rarely had to heal
- it seemed like the AI often made some questionable decisions, hopefully they will smarten it up through future patches

If you enjoyed Dragonfall, you will enjoy this. If you haven't played it I would start there and then play this one (and shadowrun returns eventually as well). The game took me 27 hours on hard. I completed all available missions.

reviewText:
The only one bad thing I have to say about this game is that it should have been a DLC for Shadowrun Returns, as Shadowrun Dragonfall used to be. That's the one big issue I have with all the Shadowrun games right now, because the campaigns as they are are about as rock-solid as you're expecting from this sort of game.

The story is rich in characters- and places- background information, and there is a whole lot to do. I thoroughly enjoyed it.

The decker overhaul made me cringe at first until I got the hang of the new approach to cyberspace, but it works well in my eyes and makes you think twice before jumping into a system.

Again, as with the other games, this game's only flaw is that the main campaign is too short. Having made this into a third game forces community creators to take their creations from Shadowrun Returns and Shadowrun Dragonfall and port it over, leaving those other two games with abandoned or broken content. This could have really been done better.

Here's to hoping the next Shadowrun game combines the previous three campaigns under one banner and releases more official campaigns as DLC, allowing community creators to use content from new DLC in their workshop builds without having to port to yet another game with changed GUI.

reviewText:
An excellent game that I would recomend to all of my friends. It is a dark setting where you are opperating in shades of grey at best. It is set in a world where magic meets technology. They creators showed a good understanding of hong kong, better than just a quick google search. If you have been to the city, you will have a familiar feeling with this game.

It is a story heavy game, so be prepared to read a lot of dialogue. If you want to skip to the action this may not be the game for you. If you want a rich story with deep characters, though, this is likely to fit the bill. The NPCs are fleshed out and believable with their own story arks. You have a number of options to define your character as well.

Game play wise, it is a fairly tactical game. Be prepared to look for cover and plan your moves carefully. Combat can be slow, especially if you play it like a game of chess. However, it gives you a great deal of options. The matrix section can depend a bit on your tastes. If you like stepping away from combat to solve puzzles you will probably enjoy them more. For the most part, though, the matrix is skippable if you don't want to bother with it.

Your actions will have consequences in the game. Some more long term than others. You can choose to fight or talk your way through many situations. Who you let live or ally with can impact the story later on. While I would have liked to have seen more hard moral choices, over all the options presented seem believable and organic.

reviewText:
The thing you have to keep in mind when looking at Shadowrun: Hong Kong is that it is not Dragonfall. They have similarities, and many of the mechanics are the same, but they are not the same game both in feel and in gameplay.

I really liked the amount of dialogue you get from the NPCs. It is clear as you talk to these characters that there was a lot of writing that had to be done. I'd say that for each major NPC (the party, the townsfolk, etc.) there is at least 2-3 hours of dialogue available. Not only that, but the options and conversation was much more advanced and flowed much more realistically than Dragonfall. In prequels, you would bombard NPCs with dialogue options until you exhausted all they could tell you; in Hong Kong, NPCs will remember what you tell them and conversation will follow a life-like pattern.

The companions are really amazing in Shadowrun: Hong Kong as well. They all have an interesting and developed backstory, and their behavior ties into the setting of the Sixth World. The only one I didn't quite like was Is0bel, as I found her behavior childish and she was abnormally quite. Then again, this was what she was supposed to be, if you look at her backstory.

reviewText:
The only one bad thing I have to say about this game is that it should have been a DLC for Shadowrun Returns, as Shadowrun Dragonfall used to be. That's the one big issue I have with all the Shadowrun games right now, because the campaigns as they are are about as rock-solid as you're expecting from this sort of game.

The story is rich in characters- and places- background information, and there is a whole lot to do. I thoroughly enjoyed it.

The decker overhaul made me cringe at first until I got the hang of the new approach to cyberspace, but it works well in my eyes and makes you think twice before jumping into a system.

Again, as with the other games, this game's only flaw is that the main campaign is too short. Having made this into a third game forces community creators to take their creations from Shadowrun Returns and Shadowrun Dragonfall and port it over, leaving those other two games with abandoned or broken content. This could have really been done better.

Here's to hoping the next Shadowrun game combines the previous three campaigns under one banner and releases more official campaigns as DLC, allowing community creators to use content from new DLC in their workshop builds without having to port to yet another game with changed GUI.

reviewText:
As a fan of the Pen and Paper version I absolutely love this game. If you are a fan of the lore and don't hate cRPGs, then this is money well spent. If you liked the first two games, then this is money well spent.
After my first playthrough I can say, that the game entertained me greatly all the way through, even though the story was kind of predictable after some point. Nonetheless engaging and the writing is excellent. So overall I love most about everything about this game, but there are some minor nitpicks.
Please bear in mind that I played on hard, if you're playing it on a lower difficulty your experience may vary.

The MatrixThe matrix got an overhaul. Even though I was one of the few that liked the matrix in the old games, I still think this is an improvement. However, there are some things that might put people off. Note that I have not yet played a PC decker, the experience may therefore vary.
Movement in stealth sections is way to imprecise
isometric view can obscure important details in stealth sections.
No access to programs in stealth sections.
No possibility to get into combat-mode without getting caught first.
The Blocker-IC minigame can become kind of irritating after a while.
Is0bels matrix accuracy is way to low...
The DifficultyIt is way to easy. I played on hard and finished the game as a Face (max. Charisma, all etiquettes) with some cyberware and some rifle-skill in about 27 hours. There wer only very few parts of the game where I felt actually challenged. And I am someone who seldom finnishes a game, even less so on the hardest possibility. The most bothersome thing was the grenade-love of NPCs, and you can get past that quite easily with a nice little cyberarm. The only thing, that was remotely challenging was the matrix and that is most likely only because I had to use Is0bel, who is only okay at matrix combat.
I have now started another playthrough, where I changed to normal difficulty, just to check things out and because I wanted to build an even less optimized character (burn-out adept-cyberweapon-shaman-grenade girl). It is ridiculously easy...

The Loading TimeLoading times are long. Really long, and tehy got progressively worse. I had up to 30 seconds of black space before a loading screen even appeared. And when you're reloading your quicksave over and over again, because Is0bel screwed up in the matrix, but you want to get it just perfect, then you're going to wait. A lot. I think I can attribute at least one hour of my playtime, only to loading screens.

The Small StuffOne nitpick of mine is the fact, that when you start up a drone, the controlls automatically switch to the drone. I can't even remember how often I have tried to relocate Racter after activating Koshei and relocating Koshei instead. But that was also the problem in the previous games, so that's old news.

The Good StuffWell, I already said, that I actually love most all of this game, but there are some things that stand out.
The writing. It's good. It's real good. At least on the same level as in Dragonfall. I can't really decide which one I like more.
The ability to engage combat-mode before the enemy sees you. Glorious, wouldn't want to miss that anymore.
The stealthy matrix. It might have problems in the execution, but the overall feel is just right.

reviewText:
Contains spoilers.

A worthwhile successor to Dragonfall.  Buggy at times, SR:HK recreates the tabletop experience with a plot that loses coherence and drive somewhere in the middle before whipping everything back together for the finale like an actual game master would have happen - complete with a literal deus ex machina as an end boss.

The maps are much larger, but most of it is empty space populated with nice atmospheric setpieces.  Nice scenery does kind of wear thin after a while when you're criss-crossing the hub area to buy things or advance the little subplots the NPCs have.

The new Matrix gameplay emphasizes sneaking around and playing Simon/a memory game.  It was novel, but wore that novelty out quickly.

Despite it all, would still recommend the game if only for one run through.  The story is nice and all the little details and in-jokes are appreciated.  Replayability is something I'm on the fence about - there's parts of this game's combat and Matrix mechanics that are simply a slog and the different avenues of conversation/story really just determine how much of a jerk you are to random people in Hong Kong/your team exemplified best in the end-of-game dialogue with the end boss.  In short, replayability doesn't look good to me on the effort/payoff scale.

Also kind of salty that there's a Hong Kong game and you can't dual-wield pistols I mean seriously now this is a terrible oversight.

reviewText:
What can I say about this game.. Well.. It's an RPG above all else, the gameplay is nothing special, it's not boring but it could use some work too, this is a game you play for the story and atmosphere. It is no secret that there's a severe lacking of modern cyberpunk games and this game certainly delivers on that and gives you a very interesting dystopian future setting with a twist, it has elfs, dwarfs, orcs, mythical creatures and magic but in a modern/futuristic society.

From what I have gathered the Shadowrun Returns series (based on the PnP Shadowrun setting) tends to be a hit or miss with people, as a roleplayer and video game story enthusiast I personally love it! If you care more about story than gameplay elements I would recommend it to you as well.

As for Hong Kong specifically, I haven't finished it yet but I have put in 10 houres or so around the time im writing this review, I would say it rates somewhere in between the other two games.. The first Shadowrun: Returns game, well, it's no secret it was lacking and kind of short, I personally still loved it due to the setting and as an old Inphinity Engine games fan I get my hand on every similar style RPG I can find, you just can't match the roleplaying and immersion you get out of these type of games anywhere else. I am getting a little off track.. The sequal Dragonfall picked up ALOT of slack and was just purely an amazing ride, Hong Kong seems to be somewhere in between, definetely more polished than the original but so far lacking a bit of Oomph, keep in mind though this opinion is formed only 10 houres into the game, and there has been some interesting moments, this opinion might change by the time I have experienced more of the main story. One thing that I am confident will not change however is this; I recommend any RPG fan to play this game, if you are new to the series I would recommend playing the other installments first since there's really no visible technological upgrades between the sequals, only the story differs. At the very least do yourself a favor and pick up Dragonfall, the original might give you a sour first impression, I would still recommend getting it as long as you dont allow it to turn you off the sequals (they are better, much like how Baldurs Gate 2 was better than 1 but both were good).

Welcome to Life, Chummer. Let's do this Batman style, the Good, the Bad and the Bold.

The Good:
- The customization and Karma system has been pretty balanced, honestly. In Dragonfall, it was a bit too harsh with the Karma, making dual-builds almost half-impossible because of how unbalanced reliance to some skills were. It wasn't as good as Dead Mans Switch when it first came out, but the customization was pretty good.
- The character balance is good, a shaman, a decker and a Street Samurai with a Rigger and another Samurai. Each class has their own good sides and the advantages are more defined compared to Dragonfall.
- Great writing. Holy â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥, did they work their butts off for the setting. The boat town looks amazing, the music is atmospheric and the dialogue carry so much impression. (Especially Kindly Cheng, my favorite character out of them all)
- Running Gags. In a game. THAT WORKS. Did I mention the writing is great?!
- Better defined character traits, AKA pacifist runs are (somewhat) possible. At least, you can get far for being a pacifist. And there's bad and good consequences to good and bad choices, AKA you aren't punished for doing bad things and rewarded for doing good things 24/7. AKA a morality system done right.

Con:
- The story. Getting the true story was VERY cryptic. You need to talk with one of your vendors every mission, you need to talk with one of your teammates every mission. And you need to memorize one phrase from a conversation in your head until an event near the end of the game. Did I mention it was cryptic? You need to also talk with another team member constantly also.
- The characters, it felt like two were getting too much attention compared to some others. I liked how dragonfall dealt with teammates, but there needs to be more content on each characters.
- Some problems involving items. It feels like some glitches are here still, but it's workable around. Not excusable for not having some bugs fixed (AKA weapons I give to teammates disappear forever after a mission or unable to give items to teammates).

The Bold: (AKA my opinion)
- Brings me up to the next one: These games feel too short. A huge game for $60 with about 4 times as much missions in an Shadowrun game would make me so happy. An expansion and even maybe multiple hideouts or fronts to operate in. Something like Invisible Inc. except for Shadowrunners and operating against the law.

reviewText:
I played through Shadowrun Returns and Shadowrun: Dragonfall, (and the updated director's cut), and I can safely say that if you liked even a little bit of either of those two games, you'll have a blast with Shadowrun: Hong Kong.

It's 4:30am and I finished the game, and as much as I'd love to write a full review, I'm too dang tired. So let's start with the good:

Improved Matrix: That's right runners! The Matrix is graphically updated, more challenging, and now includes hacking mini games!

Improved Combat: The biggest upgrade for me is that a rigger doesn't need a deck anymore, meaing you can carry a gun and 2 drones with you into battle if you've invested the Karma. That's like having two extra members to the team, plus being able to defend yourself properly. *Very* nice change, and makes riggers even more viable than previously.

Improved Mission Prep and Inventory Management: This was a HUGE improvement. Now swapping gear and items between compansions and party guests is much, much easier with newly designed mission screens, which include tabs for gear, spells, and items. You can see in a glance everyone's loadouts at once and drag and drop items from your stash to the appropriate party. Also, if you find an item in the field and you have space in your characters slots, you can take the item immediately, and either hang onto it or hand it immediately to another party member! That's a big improvement for harder modes when you may be running low on supplies and won't be able to access a stash!

Great Characters: The companion missions are back, and the companions this time around aren't nearly as stereotypical as they were in Dragonfall. Gone are the goth chick, angry chick, and drunk german, (whom I liked, but thought they were severely stereotyped), and now you have a cast that includes an adopted brother, rat shaman millenial, samurai ghoul, and more!

Engrossing Story/Cutscenes: They're sparsely used, but worth noting since the previous games didn't include cutscenes. The storyline this time around runs much like Dragonfall, so you'll get hooked early in, but have a lot of time to run other missions till the main storyline picks back up. Once it does though, you're in it to win it.

New Cyberware and Essence Cap: For me, this was HUGE. You have access to really great cyberware from early on in the game, including some really cool weapons, (laser whips, anyone?!) The essence cap can be increased to 8, (Up from 6 in previous games), meaning that you can judiciously load out a character. There's even a new branch of Karma that expands on your cyber effectiveness.

New Weapons: Flaming and Electric swords, Cyber Claws, and armor stripping shotguns. Oh my!

Better Companion Abilities: The Companion Level Upgrade system is back from Dragonfall: Director's Cut, except now I found the abilities to be downright amazing. For instance, both your samurai ghoul and your shaman can develop abilities that one-shot opponents who meet particular conditions. Having the right party member and planning ahead with their tree can make some fights incredibly rewarding when your forethought pays out in big nuyen.

On the downsides: The story takes a big detour for a good chunk of the game if you're a completionist who like side missions and companion missions. Also, there's not a lot of Nuyen (Cash) to be had in the game in comparison to Dragonfall, so some very judicious spending is in order.


If you've never played either of the first two games, I have good news. This is basically a standalone game, so you can just pick up and play, and learn as you go. It's a thought provoking RPG where strategy, cover, and character building are the key to having a great time. Also, if you're into cyberpunk, this game is for you!

reviewText:
Shadowrun: Dragonfall was already a big improvement over the initial release of Shadowrun: Returns and settled many of the issues the initial game had. Shadowrun: Hong Kong delivers another great story as well as some minor, but nice improvements.

Like in Dragonfall you get a detailed backstory for each of your crew members and talking to them leads to optional missions, which help develop the characters and are good for a change of pace when compared to the other side missions.
Only a few of the side missions have to be completed in order to complete the campaign, but you're really selling yourself short if you don't do all of them and miss out on interesting sideplots.

Personally I like the changes this iteration brings to the matrix and while the minigames can get repetitive, it is a huge step up from the old matrix system, which was a bit of a weakpoint previously.

While other reviews talk about a lot of bugs, I only spotted minor ones usually related to one obscure branch of some sideplot - a side effect when there are tons of different branches to keep track of and many of the choices have some
minor effect you discover only later on.

I definitely recommend this game to anyone interested in the Shadowrun universe, or just a good mix of story and strategy.
If you are only looking for a strategy game, but don't really care about the setting or reading lots of dialog, you probably shouldn't buy this game. The strategy layer is not refined enough to carry the game on its own.

reviewText:
I find myself continually impressed by Harebrained. As I havenâ€™t played the table-top / P&P Shadowrun, I can only speak to the game itself. (TL;DR: Skip to last sentence)

The Shadowrun Returns series have brought me back to enjoying overhead sprite based games. Since the early Fallout games, Iâ€™ve never found RPGs with this style to be particularly engaging.
As the latest iteration of the Shadowrun Returns games, Hong Kong provides a lot of polish and features that were missing while improving upon the foundation that was already pruned from the previous two games. This is not to say it is perfect, but Iâ€™ll touch on that in a bit.

The characters you run with are quite interesting. Iâ€™d say that they kept a lot of the improvements from Returns to Dragonfall in this new game. How do these characters compete with Dragonfallâ€™s? The conclusion I come to here is that your perception of this depends upon your personality. Iâ€™d say it was an improvement (especially since there are more character to get to know), but perhaps some may find them slightly less engaging than before.

New skills have been added that, I felt, increased the immersion. They allowed for greater specialization and seem to level the field for greater viability between classes. On that note, cyberware as a whole has seen a massive facelift which made me very excited.

The matrix has been revamped and personally, I love it. I have heard the complaints concerning the difficulty of some tasks within the matrix, but I found the difficulty refreshing and overcoming it equally satisfying. It is worth mentioning that it doesnâ€™t seem to be common knowledge that you can skip pieces of these puzzles by hitting the â€œnextâ€ button. While it increases the challenge of the following section, I usually found that final section easier than the rest of the â€œmemory testâ€ combined.

The story and atmosphere are, once again, to die for. For me, this is the real appeal of these games and Hong Kong is absolutely no exception. If magic seems a stretch in a cyberpunk universe, I promise, these games make it feel right at home in the dark, seedy, grimy world of dystopian cyberpunk. Further, I would strongly assert that the addition of magic adds significantly to the universe. Its addition makes the universe feel that much more uncontrollable (yet very tightly controlled), dark, and dangerous.

I wonâ€™t try to tell you that the game is flawless. There are certainly bugs and problems--I havenâ€™t experienced nearly as many as some and I beat the game before the first major patch was announced so I donâ€™t believe they are as prolific as some claim--but many of these have been patched out.
*Edit: On my second playthrough, I have noticed quite a few more bugs. Most of them have no effect on gameplay.

The biggest complaint I can offer you (which is a meagre gripe in comparison to the gameâ€™s merits) is that it is text based instead of being voice acted. For its predecessors, I didnâ€™t see this as a flaw in the slightest because the dialogue was either minimal or very engaging. In this game, while the dialogue retains its very interesting dialogue, there is simply so much of it that I sometimes found it difficult to want to speak to many of the NPCs and simply gave priority to the ones who I found interesting. As a counter to my own complain though, I do like that I didnâ€™t spend all my time talking to every single NPC in the small little village of a home as that felt closer to real life. So, ultimately, Iâ€™m conflicted on the matter.
*Edit: Aside from this, the loading times are quite sad. I moved the game from my secondary hard-drive to my SSDs and it's still an issue. This is really the only thing about the game that I find unnacceptable.

In the end, I can say this: if you liked the original Fallout games, if you like cyberpunk themed stories or games, or if you like RPGs, you really ought to pick these games up. Iâ€™d be a bit surprised if you didnâ€™t enjoy them.

reviewText:
Full disclosure: I backed this game on Kickstarter, and I backed it because I loved playing Shadowrun Returns and Shadowrun: Dragonfall.

The game starts out with our hero, after you create him or her, getting off a boat to meet their childhood friend and foster brother in Hong Kong. You've been asked to go there by your foster father.

There are three battles before you even become a shadowrunner; one of them is avoidable, but yeah, there's a high probability of being killed first time out. There's even a Steam achievement for it.

The Shadowrun games involve a lot of reading. The writers seem to be more novelists than screenwriters, so they're really not concerned with anything seeming too much like a monologue. The balance between reading and playing is good, though. The reading lets you take a break from trying to shoot, fight, or magic your way out of the many encounters. Talking to your group is also encouraged, as some of them will give you missions. Some of the side characters you'll meet along the way will also help you in surprising ways.

In addition to the character quests, there are many hidden little things in the game that can be easily missed if you don't look around. There are other runners you can meet, more goodies to buy if you have the cash, and some entertaining characters.

There's also a heavier necessity for a decker, which seems to be why the decking virtual world has been given a major upgrade since the last game. It looks much better, and has a few more challenges to it. There are times in the game when a decker is absolutely necessary, and other times when a decker can help to avoid a battle, or even save everyone's lives.

Ultimately, though, the Shadowrun gameplay experience is looking very dated, especially after XCOM, and the upcoming XCOM2. Ideally, for the next Shadowrun game, I'd like to see more 3D, a rotatable map, and a lot more voice acting. Harebrained Schemes have improved their storytelling immensely since Shawrun Returns, but now it's time for them to improve the gameplay experience with some new technologies.

reviewText:
I still haven't played Shadowrun Returns, but I have played Dragonfall, and I can say that Dragonfall was quite an experience for me as RPG's go, with engaging, well-written characters and a fantastic plot.

Hong Kong definitely strives to meet the expectations it's predecessor has laid out for its fans, but after completing the main storyline, I feel as though it missed its mark, at least in terms of writing.

The characters, though interesting, didn't drag me into the world as well as Dragonfall's did, and for the most part didn't feel as fleshed out either.

As for gameplay, the new Matrix is a substantial upgrade from its previous iteration, a welcome change from what was essentially just the combat with a new paintjob, while the expanded Cyberware upgrades provide more leeway in tooling yourself up with chrome and steel, which I appreciated.

Overall, it's not bad. There are some new mechanics, and the game looks better, both of which are nice, but the writing isn't quite up to par with Dragonfall, which is definitely disappointing.

I suppose that about sums it up, actually.
I'm not angry or upset, just slightly disappointed.

However, Hong Kong still gets my recommendation.
It's a solid RPG with a lot of freedom to play how you want to, presented in a vibrant, beautiful setting, with a decent story behind it. The qualms I have with the writing are most likely present because the writing in Dragonfall spoiled me and set my expectations a little high.

So, make no mistake:
This is a good game.

reviewText:
I got Shadowrun Returns and SR Dragonfall DC from GOG earlier and played through them few months ago before I got this latest game in the series.

I expected that SR HK extended would be more of the same, and in certain way it is, but for me Harebrained managed to create hooking and surprisingly fresh take in the life and adventures in the shadows.

SR HK  added a lot to setting which Harebraned already managed to feel very atmospheric in SRR and SRDF. If you are to lore, world building and dialogue this may very well be the best game in the series.

Dialogue and world building aside combat is much the same as in earlier SR games, at least if you play a decker, but the Matrix was revamped. I felt changes refreshing even I didn't bothered much with the hacking puzzles. Free roaming (unless you are detected) in matrix melds very well with turn based combat in meat space.

Overall I recommend this to anyone who likes earlier games in the series and in general who is to cyberpunk.
